1211121.content:
You left the door to your room cracked open and went downstairs. You would have stayed to keep an eye on him as you both slept, but you decided to give him privacy. And if he needed you, you'd only be a short call away. You set yourself up a comfortable spot on the couch where you read. As you passed the closet outside your room before you cracked the door you also pulled out a hefty comforter.

The rain outside was still a band or downpour. The rain were the pattering of drums, the thunder the chorus, and the lightning the grandeur but never the finale. The rain was pouring down so hard onto your front window you were mesmerized by the abstract painting it made. The scene outside seemingly melting with the rain flowing down. "I always wanted a waterfall on my property..." you thought aloud to your self. Then a sudden whistling startled you, it was the kettle in the kitchen.

You got up and walked into the kitchen thinking of what to drink with the boiling water. It was hard to focus with the rain and thoughts of Aiden. After standing in front of the kettle for what seemed to be minutes you finally decided on cocoa since there was no chocolate left in the house. As you poured a pack into a mug you wondered if you should make Aiden something, but you doubt he'd be able to drink anything right now. "I'll just bring him bottle water if he wants something to drink." As you were about to pour the water in a sudden howling yell came from upstairs. You were not sure nore did you care if it was the yell or the thunder that shook your house. Or that you had dropped the kettle onto the kitchen floor in a steaming mess. You only found yourself running to your room, and pay witness.

You were not able to name what it is you saw, but the lightning had gone into a frenzy outside and shot your power cables making them flicker erratically. You're room was shaking from the constant thunder. But all this was ignored by what you saw. Numerous shifting lights were scattered about your room seemingly pouring in from your window crack. You rushed over to close it, but some of the sparks were still in the air. One you did not notice even touched you. Instantly shocking you but phasing out afterward. "Electricity?! Aiden!!"

You looked down to Aiden, he was cringing in his unnatural sleep and yelling out on occasion. The sparks that had entered your room were slowly being drawn into his body, through your sheet and blanket. His body pulsing with each entrance. You tried blocking them, ignoring the shocks and burns on your skin, but most of them went into his body and probably had been since he yelled. And worst of all he was still asleep in this agonizing pain that you only tasted. Thankfully the sparks were now gone and he was no longer yelling out...at what cost you didn't know...

AS you took out a deep breath, you were relieved to see him in no more pain. But before you could even take in air something else began happening to his body. He started shivering. Not yelling, but his face went into a contorted shape as he seemingly convulsed. Shaking and then pulsing out like he was having a stroke or seizure. You ran to him, yelling for him to wake up as you shook at his fur. But his eyes didn't open and his body was near burning hot. And as you pressed your hands into him, with each convulsion you felt his muscles contracting, farther and farther apart. Then, the gaps being refilled as those muscles expanded.

You looked at the edge of your 9 ft. long bed where his legs already reach over to the base seat beneath it. The sheets were getting farther away from his ankles. He was growing...

That's when you remembered, power sources made him grow. He was growing from the electricity. "It must be from the storm, he attracted the electricity bouncing off the rain from the lightning." You stepped away as his body slowly expanded outward. Reaching another foot, maybe two in size...
1211121.title: Coursing Through His Veins

choices: He wakes okay, but without any memory of what happened while he was asleep.
He wakes up sore and feverish, grumpier than he usually is on waking.
12111212.content:
You sighed with relief when he seemed to calm down. His body was still hot and tense, but his expression seemed to have relaxed somewhat. Your arms and back were still stinging, but it seemed relatively minor compared to what was happening to Aiden. Although you had been surprised at the entire situation, things had become much clearer after witnessing what had just happened. Your heart was still racing, and you weren't sure whether it was a good idea to wake him. Despite the pain he had been through, it seemed as though he was finally sleeping peacefully, and things might calm down a bit.

That was the only thing you could hope for as you got up again, wincing when you moved. You pushed through it before getting up and examining your window frame. The wood had gotten singed by all of the lightning, and the rain was leaking in along the edges. There wasn't anything you could do to seal it any more than it already had been, but it would at least be a little bit of protection.

Still, there wasn't any point in taking any more risks. You spent another minute to make sure Aiden still looked and felt okay. His body still felt far too hot, but his heartbeat seemed stable and his sudden growth didn't seem to aggravate his injuries. With a bit of regret, you left the room, planning on shutting down the power in your house. There was no point in taking any more risks after the storm had just struck your house directly.

It only took a few minutes, but things wore heavily on your mind. You had to stumble through for a flashlight, and even then, navigating your basement was a pain with all of the supports scattered around it. More than anything, you just wanted to be quick. You didn't know what was happening to Aiden, but it wasn’t natural, and there was a very real chance that he would end up injured, or worse.

You had just finished, and had only closed the basement door when you heard another yelp, the sound of it covering the dimmed boom of thunder. "You're kidding! Not again!" You dashed up as fast as you could, your heart racing as you dashed up the stairs. You almost tripped in the darkness, but you managed to get in, flashlight pointed right at Aiden as you slammed the door wide open.

It looked like the lightning was smaller this time. By the time you had arrived, the lightning was gone, and Aiden had quieted down. However, there were new marks along the edges of your window, and his face was tense again, his body clearly shaking as it began to swell again.

This wasn't right. It just wasn't right. It was difficult enough to believe that lightning had somehow managed to get in the space of a barely-opened window, through a room, and strike Aiden directly. There was just no way that it had somehow managed to get through a closed window and hit him a second time. You tried to hold him still as his body pushed and moved, but even unconsciously, he was twisting and shifting a lot harder than you could manage. Even before, you never could've kept him still if he wanted to move. Now, it was a struggle against futility just to keep him on the bed. His body lengthened another few inches as you held him, and it was only a moment more before he bulged out further, his muscles thickening and swelling. His breathing finally seemed to relax.

You didn't know if it had been moments or minutes or hours since it had started, but you were worried. You held his body tight, feeling it slowly cool as the rain raged in the background. It was getting clearer and clearer that it wasn't safe for Aiden to keep staying in the room.

The flashlight next to you seemed to flicker. You had dropped close to Aiden's side when you had tried to get him to relax, and it was amazing that it hadn't been damaged worse when Aiden was thrashing around. You sighed as you picked it up, moving away just enough to try to get a better view of Aiden now. The beam seemed a bit dim, but steadied when you looked. It seemed as though Aiden's growth had managed to help with the wounds he had, and although there was a little scarring, it wasn't very visible under his fur. Despite the pain he had been through, Aiden would probably be okay, as far as you could tell in the low light.

You jerked when you realized it, shaking the flashlight a couple of times and looking at it. It was an emergency flashlight, and had rarely gotten any use in the time that you had it. The batteries in it should've been fresh, and there was no way they would be this weak after less than a couple of hours of use. You tried to figure out what was going on, sitting on the bed against Aiden's body as you examined it. The beam started flickering again, and it was only moments before it went out completely that something in your mind clicked.

"S-sorry, Aiden... I... I didn't..."

You turned suddenly, expecting to hear a shout or a yell from him. However, this time, there was only a gentle growl, almost a smile coming from his mouth. It seemed that he had drained the battery completely, but the electricity in it wasn't nearly enough to cause him pain. You could only give a sigh of relief as you held him, feeling his body warm up a little and stretch out. If he grew from it, it was only fractions of an inch. You were just relieved to have made the discovery without causing any more harm.

"So... you're absorbing electricity... But only if it's huge, or if it gets too close... My house still had power, so as long as we can keep you insulated, or keep you from getting closer to the sources...”

You shook your head. There was still a storm going on outside, and it was pretty clear that Aiden was effectively a lightning rod right now. You had to try to get him covered, but you couldn't think of anything in your house that would be a huge help. The next best bet was to try to get him into the basement, or anywhere where he wouldn't get struck again. Even though he was relaxed now, you shook him as hard as you could, trying to get him up. It took a minute before you heard a loud yawn echo through the room, and saw him start to shift and sit back up.
12111212.title: Striking Twice

choices: He is mortified and sad.
He is traumatized and despondent, somewhat angry as well.
121112121.content:
"Aiden, are you awake?"

"Grghh...yeah...I feel really...good, surprisingly..." he yawned and stretched upward, his powerful muscles bulging out as he took in a deep breath. He rubbed his eyes slowly trying to get accustomed to the light. When he was able to see straight he saw you're face and you holding your side because of the electric spark, "what happened?! Are you hurt?!" He was getting up in nearly no pain whatsoever, he didn't even whince. And as the sheets pulled off of his body you saw that mostly all of his wounds had healed and closed.

He saw you astonished at his body and he looked himself over too. Amazed and worried, he was about to speak but you interjected, "I'll tell you when we get downstairs, it's dangerous while the storm is still going on outside. But I need to turn the power off soon. And while we get down there, do not touch anything connected to a plug or somethign with batteries."

He nodded and slowly got out of bed, "Okay let's...OWWWW!!!" his head had hit your 12 ft. ceiling. The bump had left an impression as well. "What the hell!" he roared.

"Yeah, that's one of the problems," you shuddered as you heard thunder outside, "but please let it wait, follow me and be careful." You led him out of your room after turning off the light. He followed you closely, avoiding every outlet and light he could.

Because of his new bulky body he was havign trouble at every opening and door. Thankfully your living room connected to the upstairs, as such the ceiling was twice as high. But you already knew it was going to be a tight fit under your 8 ft. ceiling downstairs. The door down was under the main staircase, you went in and tried your best to open and move aside things to give Aiden room. You're basement was a partly aboveground one. It had a main room, bathroom, laundry and utilities room, and extra bedroom with a few closets. Very comfortable, you actually spent more time down there with friends than upstairs. You felt bad for Aiden though.

"I'm so sorry Aiden," you set down some candles on a side table next to a couch. Siden himself was sitting on the carpet floor looking to you a bit concerned.

"Nothign is you're fault, please don't say you're sorry when there is no reason to be."

You sighed an "okay," the sorry being just a reaction more than a statement. But he was right. You went into the laundry room and turned off the power after lighting the candles. You came back and looked into the gloomy room after closing the door and grabbing some blankets from the closet.

When you came back in you saw Aiden in a sulking poisition, just laying on the floor looking up at you. He was forcign a smile, but he looked very sad behind it. The candle light over his dark face and the room wasn't helping either. You couldn't help sulking a bit too. Here he was, you're best friend in the world, you've helped him through many of his problems. Studying, getting a part-time job, applying for the army, but this is the one time that all you could do was close to nothign for him. That was what you're sorry was for.

You just sat on the couch next to him, in this uncomfortable and cramped space and told him what happened when he slept.
121112121.title: Till the rain stops

choices: You hear a loud knocking on your door during the night.
You get through the night, but his parents don't show in the morning.
1211121212.content:
By the time you had finished giving your explanation, Aiden seemed oddly quiet. He was curled up a little on the floor, but his body seemed tense and his fur seemed to be standing on end. You tried to think about exactly what you could say, but your throat felt dry and you had trouble thinking of the right words.

It was only a few moments, but you felt the ground shaking a bit as you heard a loud thump. You jumped a bit, but swallowed as you saw a small indent on the floor, his hand clenched into a fist and visibly shaking. "A-aiden? Are you okay?"

"I'm... I'm not." His voice was strained, and as he turned to you, you could see the bitterness held in his eyes. He was clearly upset, and though he seemed to have a bit of restraint, his entire body seemed to shake and tense. "This... All this is happening... Things were tough enough before... And now..." You could hear the tone of his voice change, increasing to a soft growl. "The people who did this... They're going to pay..." You tried to hold yourself a little as you heard him speak, his resentment barely contained in his tone. "Someone's died for this stupid experiment... And I'm going to end up a giant freak... There's no way I can just..." He shook his head violently as you tried to approach him.

"Aiden, things... Things will be okay..."

"They won't!" His shout made you jump. He saw you this time, and before you could speak, his gaze was turned back down, shaking his head quietly. His expression showed shame, but his voice held more anxiety than anything else. "There's no way I can just avoid electricity for the rest of my life... And it's going to be near impossible to hide... I'm already a monster, and it's only going-"

The two of you both jumped and looked around for a moment as you heard the boom of thunder. You were ready to panic, but it seemed to have passed over safely this time. You gave a sigh of relief as you looked at him, but his startled expression didn't change.

“See? I can't... I can't handle something like this! And everybody else... They're still... in danger... I can't just... Grah!” He curled up firmly, visibly shaking and holding himself as he tried to contain it all.

You quietly tried to shift a blanket over him. It barely covered his arms and his side now, you could see him close to tears as you draped a second one over his legs. You tried to collect yourself as you spoke, and managed to keep an even voice. "You'll be okay... Things will work out..." You tried to say it, but you found it difficult to force the words out. "You've... you've grown a lot, but-"

"And you were hurt because of it!" His voice almost cracked as he half-shouted it, and you felt him suddenly pull you into his arms. Even has he held you, you could feel his body rattling against yours. "You... Because you were trying to protect me... You got such a nasty shock... I'm supposed to be the one looking out for you... I'm supposed to make sure that you can... You can live safe..."

You shook your head a little, turning your gaze up to try to look at him. "Aiden..." You press in against him, your head brushing a little against his chest. "I am safe." He jerked a little, a couple of tears trailing down his face as he looked to you. You had to struggle a little to move, but you managed to give him a small nod. "I... I know that... that things could go wrong. But... But I am safe with you." You quietly shift a bit and give his arm a slight pat. "Did you realize it? That... You pulled me in... You're holding me now... You could've easily broken something, but... But I'm still in one piece, aren't I?"

His expression was a little questioning for a moment, but it quickly turned to horror as you spoke. "Y-you're right... I shouldn't be here... You're going to-"

"Aiden!" Your voice was sharp enough to snap him from his concerns. "Look at me, okay? Do I look worried right now?" You tried to put on a small smile, but it didn't seem to fool him. He shook his head quietly before you spoke again. "Okay, not what I mean..." You lifted your arm up as he tried to turn away, and his head held firmly in place the moment he felt your hand against his cheek. "Aiden... I've got a lot on my mind, yes. I'm not sure about... About what we might do... About if you're going to be safe... But I'm definitely not worried about you hurting me... That will never, EVER be a problem." You give him a firm squeeze, and though his body shifted and seemed to resist, his expression softened as his arms loosened over you.

"T-thanks... But you know that... That if it happens again... If it gets to be too much for me to control..." He swallowed and carefully held you, trying to move you but afraid to even let his fingers hold around your side. “I... I mean, I've already done a bit of damage to your home... If I ever end up squeezing you to tight, you could-”

"It'll never get to that point." You weren't sure exactly what was supporting you, but you were able to say it with conviction. "No matter how much you change... I'm safe with you... Even if you're the biggest guy in the world, you're still the same guy I've always known... And you've always kept me safe..."

"Even if... Even if..." He shook his head a little as he looked down at you. "I can't... I can't live like this... And my parents... And they'll still be looking for me..." His voice was so tense, and you weren't sure whether it was from worry or from anger.

"Aiden... One thing at a time... Your parents will be here tomorrow... You'll be safe for that long... And after, we can-" You tried to speak, but you felt your head pulled in against him, firmly pressed against his chest. You could feel him shaking, but his heartbeat seemed to slow a little as he held you.

"I know... I know... Right now, I just... I just can't handle all of this... I can't handle... You know that if things were a little different... Other people have died for this, and it could've easily been me, too... I could've died, or gone insane, and... And... Gruh!” He just seemed to clench his fists, his entire body tensing and pulling you firmly. “This just isn't right! I don't... I don't want this to... to...”

"Shhhhh..." You just put your hand up to his shoulder, squeezing as firmly as you could. "It's okay... It's okay, Aiden. I don't know what else might happen, but right now... You're safe... And you're still you..." His body seemed to relax a little as he held you, the covers forgotten nearby. "No matter what else happens... We have time here and now... So no more worrying, okay?"

"Y-yeah..." He nodded softly before leaning in and giving the top of your head a small lick. "Yeah... I was... More than anything, I was afraid I would never see you again..."

"I'm right here, Aiden." You just nodded again as you felt his shaking slow to a stop. You put your hand against his chest, feeling it gently rise and fall as his arms completely covered you. “So... For now... You'd better rest... You'll probably need it...”
1211121212.title: Coping

choices: That night...
1212.content:
“You are like the sunset, hidden amongst the clouds at the end of the horizon. Saying goodbye to the world. You are like the night, hiding false things so truth may be seen in your guardian moon. You’ve shined brightly in the deepest black. You are like the dawn washing the world of it’s bad. Seeing you rise brings warmth I can’t fathom unless a day could be experienced in a moment. –Sathomia Myfel,” you read aloud to Tilgasse as he sat next to you on the tree. It was your and his favorite poem written on the day of the Equivalence. It was two centuries ago, longer than any can remember besides the older demons. That day a single woman rose between the forces of Hell and the people of Earth. This was her final writing before she died on the battlefield.

It was a bright and sunny day with few clouds in the blue sky, almost Ethereal from the look of the Earth now. Few days were like this. Since the war, the moon was shattered leaving it’s remnants floating around the plant, disconnected from it’s large piece which was still being held together. Some days the sun would reflect off these pieces and create an Aurora in the sky. It was hard to see in the day, but it was there, dancing in its prism like rays.

It’s been exactly 263 years, the mayor said, since the end of the war. When the demon race broke through the surface of our world and began to destroy everything in their paths. Our magic was a match for their strength but their numbers were infinite. It was then that a pious woman, Sathomia, called upon the power of the angels. She struck the moon with her might and the world fell silent as thousands died in a rain of destruction directed towards the hole they tore through. She sacrificed her body and laid her soul to rest, proclaiming her return if chaos returned.

Demons formed a forced pact with humans due to her power. And the world began to rebuild. Things were much nicer than most suspected. Demon’s sheer strength brought about easier methods of rebuilding, both races even gave each other design principles and ideas. From philosophy, culture, did you know demons had a government? Now almost three centuries later you’re laying here next to your friend Tilgasse reading from an old text from the time written by Sathomia and her kinsmen during the war.

Tilgasse had just fallen asleep as you were reading, you could hear him snore. You were about to as well until you heard a familiar sound. Your dog Fray yelping in the distance as he practically galloped to you. Quickly jumping up to you and licking your face. Although you called him a dog he was clearly a black wolf, with a bright yellow and blue eye, but still one of the nicest dogs you’d met. Even more amazing was that he was a three year old wolf that Tilgasse’s father found abandoned in the woods. He became your birthday present the week after and you’ve been together ever since. “Hey Fray, haha, what are you doing all the way out here? Did father call for me?” He ran back and flipped to face you as he barked once. “Okay, I’m coming. Til…hey Til!” you lightly rubbed Tilgasse’s shoulder. You wish he weren’t such a heavy sleeper. “Til, your father’s calling for dinner.”

“What…already? Good thing too…I’m starved…” he sat up groggily. You couldn’t help but burst out laughing as you got up. “Wha-what’s so funny.”

“Oh nothing, ghaha. Just that your plate will be very empty if you went home to eat now.”

“What?! Damn, again? You always get me…every time!”

You ran a little ways away from him, “Maybe if you didn’t walk and sleep on your stomach you wouldn’t be so easy to trick. Hahaha!”

“Grrgh!” he jumped up and started chasing you in a playful manner knowing it was only a joke. And as he did you quickly whispered a spell that made his legs stop in midair as he juts upward. “Damn it, what did I tell you about using magic, haha! I swear when you teach me magic I’ll make you regret it! And don’t take back your word either, you promised!”

“Haha, yes I did. You only specified fire magic though, all else I can let slide. Maybe only teach you a parlor trick or two like being able to catch up to a dear friend who likes to tease you. Hahah…gha…gagh…” your knees buckled under pressure and you fell forward on one.

The spell you put on Tilgasse wore off and he had to catch himself, almost effortlessly as he ran towards you. “What’s wrong!?” He ran next to you and kneeled down to catch you on one arm.

“Uhh…nothing…gah…I held the spell for too long. I need to stop using magic without my staff, my body can’t take it too well. I’ll be fine…”

“You don’t look fine to me, here,” Tilgasse scoot in front of you and held his arms back as he scooped you up over his shoulders.

“Gah, no Til, you don’t have to,” you tried to protest.

“I’m not listening to a word you say till we get back to your house,” he didn’t allow you to say another word. Thankfully he was going where you were supposed to go, instead of trekking to his house then having to tell him to carry you to yours. When things like that happened it always ended up like this; bullies, accidents, magic exasperation. It always ended up with you being carried home on Tilgasse’s back. Even if he was the one injured.
You just lay forward and accepted it and quietly whispered so he couldn’t hear, “thanks TIl…”

…

When you got back your father was in a proud uproar about you getting a letter from the Arch-Mage Academy. “My boy a general Sorcerer!” He never praised more embarrassingly than anyone else. Your father was a business man, more the calm and rational man. But when it came to outward joy, he was awkward to say the least. He began planning a party in your honor, started writing letters as your mother planned the party. Some of your relatives were already there talking about it as well, giving congratulations.

You gave your best smile, through sweat from the overabundance of attention. Then while everyone was preoccupied you took Tilgasse around back to the river bed leading out of town. You sat on the cobblestone bridge over the low water. “What’s wrong? Aren’t you happy about going? I think it’s great you’ll be a genuine sorcerer. Then when you get back we can go adventuring like we planned.”

“It’s not that…I…I never liked things to change, even if it’s for the better…it’s happening so fast. My father isn’t helping either. I want to become a skilled mage. I want to go see the world like we planned. There are still some demons that refuse to comply with us and their people who have joined with us. I’m glad that no one bothers Ms. Rosaline because her son is half human half demon. But I don’t…want to leave yet…” Frey was now next to you, and you pet him with one hand as you kept your balance with the other.

“…it’s not going to be like that.”

“What? What do you mean?” you were surprised to hear him say that.

“You’re really smart, and you like to help people a lot. You’re more skilled than many magic users your age, especially for a sorcerer. I hear it take years to be that class for normal people. Only a few make it to where you are by how old you are…but the point I’m trying to get at is…You’ll be in and out of that school like that!” he snapped his fingers.

“And I’ll be waiting and training every moment you’re gone. So don’t be upset about it. We both need to get better at what we do. After all, you’re the brain and I’m the thing that isn’t a brain!” he held up a partly flexed arm.

You nearly fell off the bridge laughing at his comic sayings, “did you truly forget the word muscles?”

He let his arm over the back of his head and gave a childish smile, “maybe…”

Your sudden burst of laughter made you slip off the bridge, thankfully you suspected it would happen and quickly cast a spell to make yourself float. Tilgasse ran to the edge of the bridge as Frey jumped off, he saw you float down to the shallow water then look up at him as your dog panted and wagged his tail. You whispered another smell that made him trip onto the dirt end of the cobblestone as he was running down to get you, “what was that for?!”

“My wet shoes. and pants,” you said as you walked past him back to your house.
1212.title: Friendship Forged in Fire

choices: The battle took a turn for the worst...
12121.content:
As you walked back the short distance to your door, hearing the commotion had died down, he began to ask you for the hundredth time, "so what does it mean to be..."

"Being a sorcerer means that I have mastered at least three of the five major schools of magic. This includes, for me; at least 4 elements of the 6 primary elements of elemental magic, healing magic, and psychic, which is the lowest form of arcane. Because of that I can become a full Sorcerer and learn about the magic that regular mages can't learn outside academies..." your face grew solemn.

"What's wrong? Isn't that a good thing?" Tilgasse stepped up to you since you had been walking with a brisk step.

"I kind of...cheated...I learned about two of the Sorcerer arts from my grandfather...he kept journals from when he was in school and taught me..."

"But that means you'll have a one up on the group right?"

"Yes...but it also means I broke the law. I have to be an entree in the academy. But I'm not, yet. So once I enter, I'm off the hook...what are you doing...?" Tilgasse was looking into the side of your face and followed behind you examining the back of your head.

He stopped when he noticed you were looking, "sorry, I thought I saw your brain leaking out of your ears from not having enough room."

"...I'll ignore that statement...is there anything else you want to know that I probably told you before?"

"Yeah, what are the two powers you learned that could get you in trouble?"

"Well...the schools of Sorcery are Arcane, Summoning, and the two major elements Darkness and Light. Grandfather taught me about the last two, specifically Darkness and Summoning. I never really wanted to learn about light magic."

"Did you want to learn Summoning and Darkness?"

"Yes, they require that every sorcerer has to have some sort of Familiar. I've been thinking of making Frey into one..."

"Huh...no wait. Never mind, that's way over my head I'm sure. Besides we've been standing on your doorstep for a while so I think you should go inside. I'll see you tomorrow okay?"

"See you tomorrow Til..." you gave each other a quick hug before he ran off back home. You stood there watching him for a moment before going inside.

...

You lay awake that night listening to the crickets outside in the fields, wailing about the rain predicted to come that night. Their clouds had already gathered and blot out the moon. You were awake partly to hear the symphony, but also out of anxiety that kept your eyes open. You lay awake fully thinking upon what Tilgasse and you had spoken of. You had brought a cup of tea with you to drink before you slept but there it was on the desk next to your bed, full and cold. After noticing it you cast a spell to warm it up just before boiling. When it began to steam you lifted it up and took a sip, "...no sugar..."

When you were about to put it back down a sudden rumble came from outside that quickly jerked it from your grip. 'Was that thunder?' It stopped as soon as it had come, but by the time you realized the cup broke on the floor another quake came. This one shook at the foundations of your home as shelves were knocked over. You also saw pyres of yellow lights floating outside your windows, small yellow crystal in the air resembling quartz. "Earth magic?!" you jumped out of bed, taking your staff from the wall and cloak. "Everyone, get out of the house! Earthquake!" No sooner said then everyone snapping to their attention and running from their rooms. Your parents, little brother, and your dog Frey.

The commotion had escalated into something far worse than what you could see on the inside. The ground was shaking horribly and the sky was red with fire coming from the Eastern edge of town. Demons from the ground and the sky were ravaging the town, even killing demons already living here. "Why are they killing everyone, we have a pact!" your little brother yelled out.

"it's going to be okay Eric, I'm sure the town guard and mayor are doing what they can," no sooner had you said that when two guards on horseback came. One firing an arrow of lightning into an oncoming demon. As the other shielded from it's attack. It fell in a twitching rage. You hid your brother from the sight. "We're rounding up what people we can. Especially able mages and healers. We're moving what villagers we can to bunkers but we need the help of all magic users."

"Why, what's happening?!"

"We don't know! Demons began pouring out of the sky and forests, we have as little an idea as you do but we must have the assistance of your son. You all must be move to the bunkers beneath the Town Hall immediately."

Before your parents could protest you quickly stepped forward, "it's okay mother. I have to go, they need me."

"We need you too!"

"No Mariam, it's alright. Let him do what he needs to. No better mage can." Your father led your mother and little brother to the guard while you stepped towards the mage. he took you up on his horse.

But before you both sped off in opposing directions your little brother yelled to you, "I want you back alive big brother!" And the mage snapped the reins before you could yell back.

He led you to a guard's tower where a few demons, mages, and guards were posted. One in heavy armor approached, "this is the junior sorcerer?"

"Yes I am. What do you need me to do sir?"

"They've already taken the Eastern edge of the town, we managed to stop them there but there's still many coming. From the trees, ground, and sky. We need as much help as we can get; ever killed before boy?"

"Monsters in the woods yes with my hunting friend Tilgasse and his father." The moment you said that a familiar voice yelled from the distance. Til and his father were sitting at the far end. His father, Roan, looking as dark as always in his hooded black and scarred eye. He was a kind man in person but had a foreboding air. He must have been doing a lot for them, he was and still is a skilled warrior from the army. "I think it will be much easier for me to work with them around."

"Good then, Syx get him ready for combat.

You were all sent out into the field as soon as ready. Roan part of the squad of guards protecting your group. Even your dog helped in tracking down demon's coming through the ground. The mission was to take back the Eastern edge, someone there sent a message saying he had full intel on a mystics note. It was signed under the villages insignia so it was real.

Dealing with the demons was easy enough, a few men were injured then easily cured. It was a winning battle and some of the men were impressed with your prowess. Conjuring elemental forces that higher leveled magicians barely knew. Added to that, you and Tilgasse worked like a team more than anyone in the group. When you froze an opponent he shattered them. "You know, I was going to stop you from joining!"

"Why didn't you?!" you asked while charging an electric spell in your staff.

"Because I knew it would work out too well if we did join!" he shoved his sword in the way of the spell and wielded the electricity as he pierced through a demon's armor with ease.

Not to say that the battle wasn't hard. It was difficult to keep things as they were. You were sad to see even one man die, but knew grieving was to come later. The East side was worse then imaginable. You couldn't look down for long, the bodies were indistinguishable beneath the rubble or ripped open in horrific scenes. Even one of your teammates stated, "hell," under his breath. That was when Roan said, "no, Hell is nowhere to be seen. This place is Paradise compared to it's dark fires." He would know, Roan was one of the people who went down to the demon world when an insurrection was attempted 20 years ago. Maybe this was from the same group.

He even told you once, "demon's are not mindless monsters roaming the world. They are just like people, but given great power and strength. but what they do with that power is their own choice just like you mages and we humans." He then pointed over to his neighbor and her horned husband holding their baby across the road. You thought of that day while looking down to a small ragdoll half burned in the rubble of a torn down house.
12121.title: That night...

choices: Never!
I'll...I'll be your servant...
121211.content:
The air of the East side was filled with the dark fog of smoke rising from the blaze. As well as choking with the smell of blood and burned corpses that you were thankful not to see through the thick fires and ash. The battles were much more brutal on this side, you were thankful that other assaults were being made by other groups. You and they assisted each other well. The demons were much fiercer and in greater numbers, you and the other mages were also their targets. They knew to attack the magic users within the formation as you were the generators of the most power.

You held your ground with your best spells at your disposal, crippling the horde when able to cast. It was thrilling and hard. Mixed emotions were filling your head as you all pressed onward to the guard tower, now coming into sight. If the group had survived, it must have been of some miracle. The tower was overrun by the time you got there, demons were almost pouring through its windows and crevices.

"Alright, we're splitting into two groups. First squad will clear a path and battle here on the outside so as the draw attention away from the second squad. The second squad will enter the tower and find our men who are holding up in the lower floors."
Roan spoke out, "wait, sir. Isn't this the tower?"

"…yes, this is where the seal is…"

You were perplexed, "seal?"

"One of the great demons, Glasya-Labolas, a count of the demon world who was part of the insurrection 20 years ago is sealed within the tower. We could not kill him; any human who came near him comes under his power. They are still able to speak and think on their own, but their bodies are driven to slaughter each other. Only mages seemed to be unaffected by his power."

"If he was released, it would not be long before this entire town slaughtered itself. Even without the demon's help," the captain said while planning who would go in.

"We'll create the distraction!" Tilgasse yelled.

"What?!"

"Me, dad, and you along with a few others can stay out here and deal with the horde. Captain, you should be the one to deal with the inside. You assign the men here so you know the place best, right? It wouldn't be right for people who didn't know the inside to go."

"…Hmph, smart kid. Roan, your son could grow up to be a descent warrior when he grows up. Good head on his shoulders." He began divided the original 27 into a group of 15 and 12. You, Tilgasse, and Roan stayed out in the group of 15 as the 12 went in along with the captain.

The assignment was brutal, to say the least. The toughest demons were assigned to attack the guard tower. It took all the might you could muster. Eventually leading you and 4 of the other 6 mages assigned to you to gather your powers for a great spell to destroy as large a portion as you all could. You all gathered in place as the other two mages created a barrier to sever the might of the demons that tried to oppose the spell. If it were not for the other 9 warriors as well you would not have been able to gather the power. Eventually the energy encircled among the chanting and the spell was summoned. A great storm of ice. Shards of glistening ice whipping into a freezing eddy. It devoured all fire in the area and freezing all non-human life within the circle around the guard tower.
Exhausted and released of what strength you could give you barely had time to catch yourself as you fell to your hands and knees. The other mages were not as well as you were but better off. You may have had prowess but they had endurance added to their years. Thankfully the spell seemed to work wonders for the outside, what was left of the demons was easily taken care of by the others. So you were given time to rest. "Roan…why was the demon count sealed here..? Couldn't they have sent him to a more secure place?" you asked as you and the others got what rest you could, awaiting the Captain and his crew.

"A good question, but think on this. If we had sent him to a heavily guarded area then two things would have come into place. Wave after wave of demon insurrections till he was found due to how quickly they would have found him. As well as the number of people inflicted by his power. A small town was the best place…I'm sorry to say it was ours…"
It was a bit cold to believe, but it was also true. If it were a larger and more protected town they would have brought a sea of demons to release him; as well as politics coming into play if other higher demons were involved and not known to be traitors. "Why would they even try now though? Sathomia's soul still lives…she'd obliterate the traitors once they had grown to be too much of a threat…"

"Some demons never give up their hatred, just like people," Tilgasse held your shoulder.

He had just returned from cleaning up a small batch of those not caught in the spell. His arm had a gash through it.

"True. Oh you're hurt, here," you held out your hand as a green light emanated from it, closing the wound.

"You didn't have to do that; I could have just wrapped it up."

"It's fine, besides I need to do something besides take up-" as you spoke Frey began barking heedlessly towards the tower. "What's wro-" a massive quake tore through the area as you spoke. The tower's stone wall seemed to squeeze into itself before bursting outward in an array of violet and umbral light mixed into the brick and stone. It took quick thinking of three of the mages to protect the group with a wall of power. And from it came a pillar of dark light rising from the depths of the tower remains.

From the light a shadow came from within, a winged creature. It rose then calmly float downward to the ground at the end of the street. "…damn…we were too late…Hurry, raise a protection spell around us! His power can't reach through another's magic!" 4 mages quickly rose from their rest and formed a barrier around the group. A chartreuse light spiraled around you all, creating a crystal like dome.

The figure's body was like that of a thin wolf in the shape of a man's body. With black wings and gilded embroidery covering it's almost nude but tattooed body it carefully walked down the cobblestone road. Soon its upper body became clear; you saw the full horror of the creature. The arms were chained and shackled over the chest while the hands overlapped and its mouth was bandaged shut with the toothy mouth still showing. Worst of all were the piercing copper eyes staring from the black abyss of its sockets.

Your group had walked before the creature ready to battle. "Glasya-Labolas…Return to hell demon! Your presence is not wanted on this world, by order of Sathomia the Nephilim!" Roan out spoke.

The creature stopped its slow advance as its eyes rose from the ground. The demon's body twitched as its eyes shot at Roan. Its mouth the slowly curled upward into a grin as a hoarse gasp came from it. But within all your minds a loud and dark voice laughed heretically. Then, it spoke, without moving opening its maw. "Are you not…yes, I can smell it…the one called Roan… Gahahahaha!! My it's been a while since I could stretch my wings and still instill terror after two decades of imprisonment in that small box your worthless mages put me in! Did you think a count of Hell Glaysya-Labolas, lord of bloodshed could be trapped forever in a human machination!?" his voice was practically blaring through your skull. "Even 1200 years after devouring the fruit of knowledge. You humans are still worms without us and the angels…truly laughable…but I have no time for your games. Come now, remove that barrier…I don't bite…I may be able to use some of you for slaves…Hahah!"

He inched closer and terror like you never knew filled your mind. "Don't listen to him, the moment we let down this barrier we'll slaughter each other! Focus on him, he cannot act on his own accord!"

"Roan, do not begrudge my sanctity. My charity. I offer much for little in return…If even one of you may come to my side I promise the safety of all this town…what is left…" he was against the side of the barrier now. Tapping and clawing at it with one free finger. One of the mages in the group even went as far as casting a spell towards him out of sheer terror. The fire caused by it was instantly absorbed into the demon.

"Don't bother, higher demons can absorb magic if it is of less power than their rank…" Roan said as the demon licked his lips and replied as to how 'scrumptious' the spell was.

You're fear welled inside of you. It was even allowing thoughts of what may yet come if any of you denied his request. That much power, absorbing magic, was the most frightening thing of all you had seen. But nowhere near what you had imagined from what you heard. What is your reply?
121211.title: The Power of Fear

choices: The fusion was perfect (Til's mind is dominant).
The fusion was flawed (Til's mind and body are unbalanced).
1212111.content:
You're fear caused many things to flutter in your mind. A series of events leading to this night and moment. What you had seen was the prevailing moments of joy throughout your life, crushed, by this day. In your fear; your mother was cooking you dinner. In your dread; your father was giving you praise. In your anguish; your brother was your greatest playmate. In your sorrow, Roan was your greatest wisdom. And in your despair, Tilgasse was a reason to smile. Your actions had gone beyond the grasp of identity. And the words spoken that awoke you from your terror, "NEVER!!!"

When your consciousness caught up with your actions you found yourself outside the barrier, dagger in hand. A gift given to you by Roan for self defense. The tip covered in a dark crimson. And the demon three yards in front of you, his chained hands covering a gaseous wound over his face. He took no care or notice of your exclaim, holding his cheek and looking down on it as if you were not there. His hands moved away as violet and green gas poured out the wound until his skin closed. "We humans are stronger than you'd like to believe! And will never submit to you! You hurt and betray those that can give you loyalty and friendship! People like that...don't deserve the light of day..."

His eyes narrowed onto you, your fear would have welled if you hadn't learned to stand your ground, then he spoke, "you poor, insignificant, and unnatural creature...the truth if I were to tell you would be more then you could bare. A whimpering babe in a storm is what those that have been told wished to be..in the end." A wave of malefic energy pulsed out of him, pushing you back into the barrier. Tilgasse caught you from behind. "So be it! Cower and pray behind that barrier, this poor town will need the power of the angels that will not heed..." his wings flapped and his body shot upward. "If by some miracle that one survives, I will make it my vow to drink from their tears forever!" his voice boomed as he flew Westward.

"No, he's heading towards the Hall!!" Tilgasse called out.

"Hurry everyone, we must defend the bunker! The others do not know of his power!" as Roan spoke Tilgasse ran out the barrier's circle, "No son! Don't be a Fool!!!"

Tilgasse didn't listen to Roan's words, he ran with a blind rage. "Why would he run without us?!" Your group began to give chase as the barrier was kept up.

"My wife, most likely...gahhh...his feelings may very well get him killed. But I understand..."

"..."

"You have to understand that we did not know. The secret was kept between those who fought during the insurrection. If we had told them, the day may be much worse then it is," Roan's words were true. Planning came first before emotion in a situation as dangerous as this. Besides, there were mages stationed at the Hall. Your people weren't fools. You just hoped they were prepared...

"I understand...my family's there too, but...I don't know if I'd have the courage to do what he wants to..."

"It's rationality, you have plenty of courage. You confronted a demon, one of the most dangerous. Because you also have a leveled head. Even if it was a subconscious act you knew that he could not affect you. It's an act Tilgasse would have committed as well. My son has a heart that speaks louder than his mind," Roan held a small smile that quickly turned to a serious face. You nod to his words and kept your pace with them as you neared the Hall.

...

The sight was horrific... Bodies lie in the streets; their faces contorted with their pain. The fires had spread. And already, to your worst imagination, you had seen what was foretold. People killed by each other, ripped and run through by their neighbors. Mages killed by the very people protecting them. Your mouth was a agape and words were unable to leave. "Keep your mind...notice the demons are not to be seen..."

"...yes..."

You all came to the open doors of Town Hall in front of the square, no noise came from within. "I'll go ahead and see if the bunker's been breached. Stay outside, but keep yourselves hidden. If I don't return within ten minutes, go to the West guard tower then leave for Seros and see if the team that went was able to get help. And whatever you do, keep up as small and unnoticeable barriers as you can. Use Fray to smell for danger." You nod as you were scattered around the walls and buildings, keeping to the shadows. As did Roan while he passed from wall to wall.

"Be safe, Roan..."

You kept inside of a small building half destroyed by the fire but safe to be inside of as the fire had little to spread onto there. You were with one soldier, a young man who you had to protect along with yourself from the demon's power. Fray did not need the barrier's power, animal's were not affected either. He sniffed around the floor of the home.

You were not adept at barrier's, although you had learned to create them. It was perfect for the situation. As less power meant the barrier was less noticeable. Keeping below the window, you watched outside for some time. The only sounds coming from the razing fire, but otherwise it was too quiet. As you watched a shadow flickered across the square, then you heard Fray whine from behind you. You and the warrior looked back and saw nothing. "Where'd he go?" You stepped away from the warrior who looked perplexed then suddenly worried. When you turned back you heard a muffled scream, and no one was behind you. Your surprise and fear led you to break down your shield as you prepared to attack whatever came near. Turning round constantly as your magic channeled to your staff you felt something tap at your back. And when you turned, a black tentacle was hanging from the ceiling. And before you could speak you were unconscious.

When you woke your arms were being held up and your legs were bent under you, sprained. Blood was dripping from a cut just below your eye. But you were to weak too yell from the pain. You looked forward and saw Glasya-Labolas standing before a pile of burning bodies. "You spoke...of how strong humans are...these men were not even able to fight back...at least not against me...nor did this one who dealt with them all for me," he stepped away. Revealing a twitching figure behind him. The man stood before the fire and lifted up his sword, pierced through a small corpse. The blade swiped downward toward you as the body fell in front of you, it's blood sprayed on your clothes. It was Fray. And the figure was Tilgasse. As a circle of demons high and low watched apprehensively.

"...no...no..."

"I never liked animals, despite my form. The fruit of wisdom given to them prevents my power from taking them. But, we demons are not without hearts...that is why I'll let you prove your words. Before I have your friend kill you..." The demon next to them threw your staff before you. "One spell...is all I'll give you. If you can defeat me with one spell I promise they will let you go. The bloodshed will be useless if I die..." Tilgasse and Glasya-Labolas came before you. Both you and he were crying, but Tilgasse was unable to control his body. Driven to kill, his body awaited the order to slaughter you. You both looked at each other as the demons that held your arms released you.

You lift your staff, "any spell..?" you said.

"Yes, and I hope you understand that none can kill me...and the moment you cast it you are free prey." You kept your head down as Glasya-Labolas lowered himself before you, awaiting your action.

You looked to your pocket, to Fray's lifeless body, the tears of Tilgasse, then turned back to the muzzle of the cold demon in front of you, "...then I know a spell...Til...please...tell me its alright..."

He spoke, "w-what?"

"Tell me it's okay, please Til," you spoke out to him.

He wasn't sure what you meant but in his trust, he knew it was something he had to say. For any shred of hope left, "...it's okay..."

"Hmph...sacrificing your friend to give yourself the strength to kill me...humans are of no equal power to me..."

"Then you'll die here as you wish Glasya-Labolas..." the demon frowned at your words. "Heed me now power of creation sent from the chaos beyond. I offer the blood of the innocent and of the guilty to you so that new life be born." An red array spread out from beneath you, encircling you four and pushing away the demons that were close. Glasya-Labolas was sent to it's far side, Fray's body to the other, as Tilgaase float in the center.

"What?! A Summoning Spell?!!!" he struggled as demons tried to break into the array to no avail.

"Not at all...you can only absorb magic...a summon only of higher strength then you can kill you, which I can't summon. Instead your body will be used to become my new familiar."

"Impossible!! How can you have my blood!!"

"From when I cut you. Your wound may have healed, but my dagger still has your blood. Along with Fray's blood and Tilgasse's consent as the receiver. You are part of the spell, you have no power anymore. It's all within the array."

"Hah, then I will just kill you in my new form!"

"Wrong again...Tilgasse and Fray will also be a part of the fusion, your minds will mix but Til's will be the dominants as your's and Fray's will take up the rest. Face it demon, you lost!" The array spread as Fray and Glasya-Labolas's body circled into Tilgasse's. The demon screaming out as his power flood out of his body. Releasing into the frenzy and flow of power.
1212111.title: One Spell

choices: Roan and your little brother, barely anyone survived.
Roan and your entire family as well as others, many survived.
12121111.content:
Glasya-Labolas's body burned away into a umbral aura as Fray's became a teal one, but significantly smaller. Both aura's seeped into Tilgasse who began trembling, then shaking harshly, to fully convulsing violently as his body became a bright crimson silhouette. You couldn't bare to watch the pain, but the spell needed to be finished or the three of them would turn break down to nothing. "New life...born from the chaos I have summoned! I offer my blood in pact!" The blood from your exposed cheek was sucked through your skin into Tilgasse's body. He was now screaming violently from the pain. His screams becoming growls and his body giving shape. "I give you the name, Tileos Fraloya!"

With your words the array shattered and formed into Tilgasse's body as well. Creating a dense light that you squint to see from below it, Tilgasse's voice ceased it's cry. The light dropped down with a force that drove the air around it back. His body was being given shape within. First being formless, then reaching out into a manlike form as the light dimmed. His body grew to a great height above you, and still grew. His skin became a dark bronze, and the tattoos that once adorned Glasya-Labolas were now marked upon him in black. Pitch black fur came out of his waist as a tail grew with it. His hair spread back in a black arc with ears atop his head. And claws came from his fingers and toes.

The energy of using the spell was sapping your strength and about to render you unconscious. Before it did though, Tilgasse looked down to you behind him as his form inched higher. Blood welled from his eyes; the left yellow, the right blue. You tried to smile before he turned away and began walking forward. The demon horde about to crash down upon you. You saw him rise higher, towering above the burning town. He bent back and before you slipped completely into the oncoming darkness you said, "...I'm sorry..." A bloodletting howl made the ground tremble. Then the rain came...

Your thoughts were trapped you in your mind. The dark smile of Glasya-Labolas was a distant memory, you knew. You kept your mind set on one, the eyes that cried red tears. In the darkness of your thoughts, you felt your body being lifted as the wind rushed past you. For a few moments you they were open to the same eyes you saw before, looking forward then down to you. They carried a sorrowful and glad light. Trying your best to smile you were about to pass back again.

An echoing voice reverberated from afar as the wind slowed, "...who are you..! Put him down..!"

Then above you, in a more clear tone, "...it's alright dad...it's me..." and the darkness came back.

...

There were no thoughts this time, only feelings. Of what had happened and of what may come. But there was something that you were running to as well. A warmth that held you close, and gave you more comfort then you could imagine being given. You ran to it as the emotions made their way into a long forgotten spot in your heart. Your eyes opened to a brilliant light.

And the warmth was coming from a familiar but new being, holding you like as the only thing it was ever able to care for. "...Til..." you reached out your hand and touched his face as he managed to give a smile. Holding your hand.

"...good morning..." his voice was a hoarse growl, but you could still hear his own behind it. His face was still mostly human, it was fiercer even when in the gentle smile he held. His nose jut out a little, like a muzzle. And his eyes had a greater outline. His teeth were practically perking out of his mouth. His face even twitched a little as it seemed unaccustomed to smiling. His ears had dropped back down but pointed far outward and lost their fur. His hair dropped in a black tangled mess over his dark face. The tattoos of the demon crossed over it as well. And his eyes still glowed even in the bright light.

"Til...I'm...sorry..." His eyes narrowed into a pained look as his mouth stood open. "...I didn't mean for you to be in so much pain..." He was biting his lower lip as red tears started forming in his eyes. "I didn't run after you...because I..."

"No!" he winced his eyes with the bark. Then he buried his head into your chest, "please...don't even think of blaming yourself...I shouldn't have run away from the group..!" his hand clenched on your shirt. You did your best to sit up against what was behind you, and placed a hand in his hair. "I was worried...and scared...I didn't want him to kill...to kill her...my mother..." he was gasping. "Then...h-he...he made me kill...he ordered them not to move and had me...he had me..!"

You wrapped your arms around his head, "Shhh...that wasn't you...that will never be you...Til..." you cradled him as he cried.

"That's when I became this...I can still feel him...and Fray...he's dormant and Fray and I are suppressing him...but now I'm also beginning to remember what he does...I'm starting to know what he knows...it hurts...everything hurts...please...tell me...am I still...am I still human..?" Tilgasse's tears were running through your clothes making them red.

You lift his face to yours, "Til, you've been human all your life and still will be. Your body and mind may change but you are still you. Whether or not what you are on the outside."

He nodded, and you both held each other for a while as dim footsteps came to you. The sky you turned to was clouded, but rays of light came from the holes between. The group coming towards you was...
12121111.title: I'm still human...inside...

choices: "It looks like the demons are after you now."
"They think that Glasya-Labolas is dominant in Tilgasse's body."
121211111.content:
You managed a weak smile as you saw Roan approaching, a solemn look on his face. Your little brother was nearly jumping for joy as he saw you. You manage to straighten yourself up a little, sitting up and leaning back into Til's body as you turned to meet them. Tilgasse quietly held you, though his gaze had turned towards them as well.

"Hey, bro. How are ya holding up?" He nearly broke into tears upon hearing your words. He dashed towards you, his body almost slamming into you as he hugged you tight. You just felt him pressing in, too tired to give any resistance.

"I was afraid I lost you too... I'm so glad you're okay..."

"Relax, Jerek... I'm a mage, remember?" You manage to give your brother a weak squeeze, before the two of you let go. "I can take good care of myself, and I've got people to protect me." You smile and look back at Tilgasse. He shifted a little as he noticed, but his smile returned and he gave you a slow nod.

"B-but... You're the only one I've got left..." His voice cracked a little, and you could feel a bit of the heat leaving your body. You swallowed, but didn't say another word. There wasn't anything else that needed to be said.

"I-I see... We'll have to... Make sure to give everybody a proper funeral after all this is done..." You swallowed, doing your best not to think too much about your parents at the moment. There was already a lot on your mind, and you didn't know if you'd be able to handle the load of it all.

Tilgasse looked up quietly at his father, swallowing and holding you a little tighter as he spoke. You felt your body slipping from your body's grip, still holding onto his hands. Jerek looked at you quietly, as you heard Tilgasse's voice speaking quietly from behind you. "Dad... M-mom also..."

Roan simply nodded as he looked at Tilgasse. "I know." Tilgasse was barely able to contain himself, but his father approached quietly, looking over his body, doing his best to sound understanding. "It's not your fault, Tilgasse. Glasya-Labolas wouldn't have left anybody, regardless of whether or not you're here."

"Til..." He near jumped as he heard your voice, turning to look at you. "We wouldn't still be here if it wasn't for you." Your brother watched in a bit of confusion as your hands held Tilgasse's. "I could only do that magic because you were..." You swallowed, a little uncertain of the consequences. "You were willing to do something like this..."

"Of course I was..." His voice was deep, and despite being close to tears, his voice still had the dark tone of a growl within it. "I always want to take care of you... I was ready to... To give up my life if it meant that you'd end up safe..."

You shook your head and squeezed him tight. "You idiot... I don't want to end up somewhere because you died for me... You already do way too much for me..." You manage a weak smile, holding tight against his hand.

"I'm supposed to now..." He shifted you carefully, letting you rest as he held you. "I'm your familiar now, right... I think it's my job to take care of you, now..." He gave a small smirk as he squeezed your hand. "Does that mean I have to call you 'master' now?"

You had to chuckle quietly as you looked into his shining eyes. Your brother gave a quiet chuckle from your side, and spoke quietly through his tears. "Why not? You're always doing what he asks you to, anyways!"

"Ugh... You guys..." You give a small smile in resignation, too tired to give a proper response to the joke. However, as you heard them laughing, you couldn't help but relax and grin. Even though his visage was quite fierce, it was just good to see Tilgasse laughing again, his eyes lifted and his muzzle bumping lightly against you as he hugged you in.

"It's good to see you two in good condition again. But I'm afraid we don't have time to spare anymore." Roan's words snapped all of you back to attention. "That rain we had seems to have driven the demons away for a little while. I think there was something special about it. That spectacle that you two made probably did something for us, too. But by now, they'll have recovered. They'll be active again, and we don't have the manpower to deal with it anymore. Most of the people who lived here are dead."

Tilgasse seemed to shiver a little in his uncertainty, and your vision seemed to cloud as you tried to get up again. However, Tilgasse's hand held you in place, trying to get you to rest while it was still possible. "Do we still have to fight? I don't know if we... If I can still fight right now..." He asked quietly as he held you with one hand. The other pressed to his forehead, rubbing himself slightly, as though trying to get rid of a headache.

"Maybe. Maybe not. There was a little bit of movement, and I only brought Jerek here so I could keep an eye on all of you. I don't want any of you wandering off, or getting distracted. Right now, this spot seems to be their target."

"Here? Why?" You gasped a little bit, trying to stand up but only feeling your body wobble. Tilgasse managed to grab you before you fell, but Roan's words were quite clear when he spoke.
121211111.title: Not Done Yet

choices: You encounter a bit of trouble on your way.
You all make it through the town mostly unscathed.
1212111111.content:
A cold chill suddenly ran down you’re spine as you lay in still in Til’s arms. “A-are you sure..?”

“You defeated their lord and master who they came to release back onto the world. If they had not come for you because of that then I cannot think of anything else,” Roan spoke sternly.

“Then…we have to go, immediately. Til, it’s okay to let me up. I can’t cast magic well right now but I can at least walk,” you looked up to Til, “help me up.”

“Okay, but remember I’m your familiar now. If you need my help at any time you can ask…Fray says so too…” he helped you up and handed you your staff.

“Alright you…three…let’s go.”

“But where do we go? Those demon’s would be swarming all over by now,” you’re little brother was in a short but reasonable panic.
Roan interrupted, “true enough, that’ why our best option is to go Northeast to Curtwood. It’s the largest town near here and from there we can send a message to the capital of the demon uprising that to…”

“GAGGhhh…!” Til fell over in a heaving gasp. “MY HEAD!!! GET OUT OF MY HEAD!!!”
You watched as Tilgasse rolled and stretched out in agony holding his head as if trying to rip it off his neck. “TIL!!! TILLL!!!” You quickly kneeled down and held him with little use. A fiery red aura emanated from his body. “Til…” As he thrust you away one last time you looked on to him sadly. Looking at what you’d forced him to endure now.

“Get Back! He’s Dangerous!”

“It’s alright Jerek…” you crawled to him as he wailed and thrust his body about. You held your arms over his head then gently brought them down over him as his eyes opened wide and his body stopped. Only quivering slightly as you held him. “Til…I’m sorry I made you go through this. And Glasya, you cannot win you may as well stop trying now.
Your body may have held great demonic power but that was only your body. Your spirit is on equal with theirs, it’s two to one plus me. Stop…you won’t defeat us…” Til slowly let his hands down but still shook slightly.

“H-he’s gone…”

“No, he’ll always be there until the day all three of your souls fully merge.”

“What will happen then?”

“When that time comes all three of your thoughts will become one along with your memories. Instead of the three of you thinking at once you will all be one person.”

Til winced a little, “that must have been what I saw…”

“You saw Glasya-Labolas’s memories?”

“Yes, it was horrible though. It flashed a lot and I didn’t understand what I saw. I think it was his last moments before he was sealed…I saw Ro-I mean dad in it…they were fighting I think, and then he was trapped. I could hear what he was thinking at the time too,” Tilgasse stood back up along with you.

“Do you remember what he said at the time?”

“It as when the mages that were with Roan sealed him, he said something like. ‘Time means nothing, our plans will not fail’. It cut off there.”

“We can talk about that later Til, it’ll come, please try to bear it until it does though. We have to leave.”

“Right,” he nodded as you all began to run towards the woods in the North. Ready for whatever may come. Tears could be shed when you had time to cry. They were coming.
