"YES!" Likax pumped his arm into the air, his face lighting up in jubilation. You looked at the screen, which showed the record now stood at seven wins for you and Javier, with five for Likax.

"Javier!" You turned your head his way with a surprised smirk. "I told you to play for me, not to just let Likax start wailing on my fighter."

"Hey!" Javier responded defensively, "I played my heart out! He's just really good!"

"He's been playing for all of twenty minutes, Javier." You rolled your eyes as he passed the controller back to you. "You've had this game for two years!"

Frowning, he picked back up his laptop, a perturbed look on his face. He muttered something in Portuguese under his breath, which you weren't about to ask him to translate.

As you started playing again, though, you realized that he might have been right. As soon as the round started, Likax's character rushed at you with a flying kick, knocking yours down. The white-clad fighter on the screen leapt into the air and landed on your shirtless samurai warrior, pummeling him with his nunchucks, taking down your health nearly halfway, then quickly jumped back up to his feet. As you tried to lunge out and strike with your character's katana, Likax quickly dodged your attack and delivered another knockdown blow, leaving you with only a sliver of health. You didn't stand a chance from there.

The rest of the rounds faired similarly. At first, you though you might be getting tired, your reflexes slowing, but when you looked over to the bobcat's paws, they seemed to be moving at a faster-than-possible rate, him anticipating your every move and pressing the corresponding buttons to counter before you had even started your attacks. After playing for five minutes, Likax had swept four matches, three of which he didn't even lose any health during, earning a perfect score.

"You see what I told you?" Javier motioned to the screen as it pulled the record up again, Likax now leading nine to seven. "I think he's been hustling us."

Likax's eyes went wide with surprise as his ears started to shift downward. "No!" he protested. "I've wanted to play this game for a while but never got the chance to until today. I swear!"

"Hey," you said, an idea coming to you, "let's see how you fare against other people." You exited back to the menu screen, choosing an online match.

Likax turned to you with a pleading look. "But..." he started, "I've never played a video game online before. I don't want to beat people I've never met."

"This game's over two years old," Javier stated. "The only ones left playing it online are the truly dedicated and hardcore. If you can beat any of these loons, I'd be shocked."

Likax slouched down, his whiskers sagging. "I don't want to play with anyone else though. I want to play with yooooooouuuu." He dragged out this last word as he sat the controller down and stretched across your lap, looking up at you with the sweetest, most adorable eyes you had ever seen. At that moment, you wanted more than anything to play with him too. And you weren't thinking video games.

As another player connected. Likax reluctantly sat up and grabbed the controller again, selecting a large, heavily armored monster of a fighter who weld a massive battle ax. "Be careful," you cautioned Likax, "that character plays a lot different than the last one you used. Are you sure you--" But the match had already begun.

It took a few moments for Likax to get used to the slower, heavier fighter, but once he did, the results ended up being virtually the same as when you and Javier had played against him, Likax winning the match handily. The other player immediately requested a rematch, which Likax accepted, but after they had gone a round and a half without Likax's fighter even being touched, the other player abruptly disconnected, causing the game to go back to the home screen.

"That's why I've never wanted to play online," Likax commented as he put the controller down on the table. "There are some real jerks out there on the internet."

You nodded. Looking over at Javier, you noticed he was still frowning. "I just don't understand," he finally said, "how you can pick up this game a half-hour ago and suddenly be unbeatable."

Likax shrugged. "I don't know. I guess I'm a quick learner. Is that bad?"

Javier didn't answer right away. You started to recall the speed with which Likax had read through your writing binder earlier. You started to mention this but stopped yourself, realizing that your roommate had already grown too suspicious with the changes in Likax's size. Giving him more reasons to distrust the bobcat sounded like a bad idea.

"No," he finally said, his brow still furrowed, "I guess not."

Likax smiled, and you breathed a sigh of relief. As you leaned back against the couch, the bobcat stretched his arms up into the air and yawned loudly. You couldn't help but stare as his fit, muscled stomach was uncovered slightly. Bringing his arms back down, he noticed you watching him, and his eyebrows went up slightly, as he grinned suggestively.

Starting to yawn a little as well, you stood up. "Well," you said, "it's been a long day. I think we all could use some rest." You walked over to the TV and turned it off, along with the Xbox, putting the controllers and game away. "Do you mind sleeping on the couch, Likax?"

"Not at all!" The bobcat's voice sounded eager enough, but you could sense a slight disappointment in his demeanor when you turned back around to face him.

"Ask him up to your room, idiot," you told yourself. But you couldn't. Not tonight. As much as you wanted to, you knew the best thing for the bobcat was to get some rest.

Bringing down blankets and pillows, you tried to make the couch into as much of a bed as possible. As Likax lied down, his feetpaws hung off the edge, but otherwise he looked comfortable enough. He smiled up at you and gave a thumbs up.

"Good night, Carson," he murmured, his eyelids half-closed.

"Good night, Likax," you sighed. Leaving him sleeping on the couch was the hardest thing you had to do all day. Halfway upstairs, you fought the urge to rush back, take the bobcat in your arms, and run straight to your bed, locking the door behind you. Instead, you just trudged into your room and collapsed on your bed, hoping your exhaustion would finally catch up and carry you off to sleep.

Your body had other ideas, though. After an hour of lying there awake, replaying the events of the day over and over in your mind, you decided to just do what you always did when you couldn't sleep. Getting up, you walked over to your desk and sat down, pulled out your favorite pen and a blank sheet of paper, and began to write.

Before you could finish the first paragraph, however, the door behind you creaked open. Spinning around, you saw a figure standing in the doorframe looking straight at you, causing your heart to skip a beat.
122132122222111222.title: Warning Signs

choices: Likax was outside the door, listening to the whole thing.
You go down to talk to him, but Likax was missing.
1221321222221112222.content:
"We need to talk." Your heart had immediately sank when you heard Javier's voice from the doorway. He had his laptop in his hands, and was shooting you a rather harsh glare as he approach. You sighed a little bit as you put your pen down, turning to look at him.

"This is about Likax, isn't it?" You had expected Javier to ask you about the bobcat, but you really didn't know what to say. Sure, the cat was odd, and there was something going on with his body. However, that didn't seem like enough for Javier to have acted as quiet as he had.

"Yes, and no. Likax is troubling, but he doesn't seem bad." You were a little surprised to hear those words coming from his mouth. "Yes, I know. I didn't trust him, and blah blah blah. That can wait for now. What's more important is that you've completely lost it when it comes to dealing with him."

"I've lost it? What's that supposed to-"

"It means," He interrupted, "that you've obviously fallen for the guy." You tried to stammer out a response, but Javier only had a vaguely sardonic look on his face, before shaking his head and chuckling. "Come on, Carson. I've been your roommate how many years, now? You think I wouldn't notice that?"

"I thought I was being discrete..." You barely managed to mutter something, and he gave a rather obvious laugh.

"We'll save that for later. Right now, we have more pressing issues." He sat down on your bed, looking at you. "First off, the obvious. I assume you've noticed he's still growing?"

"Kind of hard to miss it, yeah. He's already having a hard time fitting in the stuff I lent him, and it's only been a few hours."

"It's been slowing down a little bit, but not enough. He's gotten maybe two feet taller. " Javier's voice was starting to get a little anxious as he spoke. "It's slowing down a little, but not enough. As far as I can tell, if it goes at the rate it's been, he'll barely fit through the doorway by tomorrow, worst case. And that's assuming whatever happens to him doesn't pick up or something."

"What? I know he's growing, but it's barely-"

"Carson, he's grown two feet in maybe three hours. In case you haven't noticed, it hasn't exactly been that long." Javier's voice was starting to rise, and you could tell that he wasn't very good at holding back his anxiety by now. "And that's only one thing. I assumed you noticed him playing the game?"

"You're right. He picked it up fast, but it shouldn't be that fast..."

"It's not just learning the game. His reflexes were improving, too. Never mind human reaction speed, he's probably broken some anthro records. I don't know what's happened to his body, but there's something unnatural about it."

"S-so what? He never meant-"

"Carson, this isn't about if he's a good person or not!" Javier's voice was growing louder, and you were afraid that Likax might hear him shouting before the night was over. "This is about the fact that something weird's going on with him! He's the one that told us they were doing some experiment, and we've seen some of the results, right? Who's to say there isn't anything worse? For all we know, he could just randomly burst into flame at any moment!"

"Don't be ridiculous!" You were trying to keep calm, but when Javier was starting to lose his composure, it was usually difficult to keep him calm. "Even if that happens, we'll deal with it. But there's no point in worrying right now, right? If he's got better reflexes or whatever, or if he's bigger, it means he'll be able to take care of himself." Your heart raced a little bit as you spoke, privately hoping that the cat was willing to protect the two of you, as well.

"Fine. Let's assume that for now, he's going to fit in the house and he's not going to cause problems. What about the people after him? I doubt we'll be left alone for a very long time. Even assuming that nobody saw your bring him here, they're going to have a bulletin out on him. It won't be long before people know about him as an escapee, and we won't be able to hide him then!"

"W-we won't have to." You swallowed a little, and Javier gave you a questioning look before he spoke.

"Oh, no. Don't tell me... That phone call?"

"I think it was some guy named Mujexa. He knew my name, and he knew we were keeping Likax here. I think he's a friend, though... He said so, and if he wasn't, we'd already have people breaking down our door, right?"

Javier muttered the name to himself a couple of times, opening his laptop as he thought. The new information seemed to have calmed him for the moment, and it didn't take long before he began typing. "I don't think I've run into that name before... Who is he... Why would Likax know..." He shook his head a little bit, clearly trying to contain himself from the verge of panicking. "What did he say?"

"That... that I should get out of here with Likax tomorrow." Javier's mouth dropped open as you spoke. "I... I think I have to. I don't think he mentioned you, but... But he knew my name, right? That means somehow, he must've seen me pick up Likax in the forest. Unless Likax somehow made contact while we were both distracted, that's the only time we could've been seen together."

"So that's it? You're just going to pack up and leave? Carson, this is insane! Even for a crush of yours, you're just going to-"

"I know that!" You were growing more nervous as you spoke, and the sheer ludicrousness of it all was hitting you hard. "But if there's really someone after me, I don't have any other options, do I?" Javier only stared quietly at you as you spoke. "Besides... I know it's probably stupid, but... But I care for the guy, okay?"

Javier quietly looked at you, staring for a moment before shaking his head. "Figures..." He sighed as he resumed typing, though his eyes seemed to remain focused on you. "When you've made up your mind about something like this, there's just no changing it. I won't waste my time trying." He looked quietly at you. "Just let him know and get yourself packed up. I have to figure out what I'm supposed to do now, too."

You swallowed before nodding to him. You stood up slowly, starting to walk out the room. "Javier... Thanks for putting up with me. I mean, over all the years."

He just gave a small chuckle as he waved to you. "We'll have to see if I have to keep doing it." You couldn't help but smile a little bit as you started to walk out the room, hoping Likax was going to be okay with the news.
1221321222221112222.title: Knowledge

choices: "Likax, I...I love you."
"Likax, there's something...peculiar about me that you should know..."
12213212222211122222.content:
The digital alarm clock on your bedside table read 12:15 when you left your room. It wasn't really that late for you; staying up until two or three in the morning had become commonplace since you had started college. You knew, though, that Likax was probably exhausted and needed his sleep after all that he had been through today. Running away from the police and coming back to life after being seemingly dead weren't exactly everyday occurrences. You second-guessed yourself, thinking about letting him sleep a few hours more.

However, Javier had made it all too clear: the two of you needed to have a plan if you were going to survive, and that plan needed to be put in motion immediately, before the sun rose in the morning. And you realized that you couldn't begin to formulate any sort of plan without the bobcat's help.

You slowly and quietly walked down the stairs, careful not to trip or accidentally miss a step in the dark. As you got to the bottom step, you saw blankets and sheets thrown onto the floor in front of the couch, and you assumed that your furry houseguest had gotten too hot and thrown them off as he rolled over in his sleep.

The couch was situated in such a way that it faced away from the stairs, so you couldn't quite make out if he was asleep or not from where you were. "Likax," you called out, "are you awake?" Not hearing a response, you walked over to the couch. As you bent over the back of it to try and wake him up, your blood turned cold.

The couch was empty.

Breathing faster now, you spun around and darted over to the wall, hitting the light switch. Shielding your eyes as the room illuminated, you scanned around, not seeing any trace of the large feline. "Likax?!" you called out again, more frightened this time. Still, no answer.

"Carson?" Javier called from upstairs. "What's wrong?"

"It's -- it's Likax!" You were on the verge of tears. "He's gone!"

Quickly, Javier ran down the stairs, his face almost as shocked as yours. "Gone?" he asked. "What -- what do you mean?"

"What do you think I mean? He's nowhere to be found!" Your brain and your heart demanded that you start searching for him, but your feet had seemingly frozen in place, unable to cope with the situation. Did you say something offensive to drive him away? Was he afraid Javier was starting to turn against him? Or did someone -- you shuttered as you finished the thought -- did someone sneak into your house and catnap him as he slept?

As you finally got control of your limbs, you began looking in the other rooms of your house. Both the upstairs and downstairs bathrooms were empty, and there was no sign of the bobcat in the utility room or down in the basement. As you started to look through the kitchen, however, you noticed that the screen door there leading out to the backyard had been left open just a crack. Could Likax -- or someone with Likax -- have left through that way?

You ran to the door and flung it open, stepping out onto your back porch, not caring that it was the middle of the night and you were wearing only lounge pants with a simple white undershirt. You scanned your backyard for signs of Likax or anything else that would indicate an unwelcome person having paid you a visit. Finding nothing, you then looked over at the backyards of your neighbors on both sides, still unable to locate any clues.

Tears were streaming from your eyes now, causing your vision to start to blur. "This isn't fair," you said aloud to whoever wanted to listen. "Why would the universe give me someone like Likax, someone so perfect and caring, and then just yank him away from me like that?"

Before you could sink too far into that despair, however, you caught the shape of something or someone moving out of the corner of your right eye. Spinning your head that way, you saw -- nothing, at least at first. Part of you wanted to give up then and there, go back inside, and collapse on your bed again, but the movement you saw gave you a sliver of hope. Could it be--?

You saw it again, a large shadowy shape trying to sneak by undetected near the light of a lamppost. The figure looked to be over seven feet tall with a broad build. "It has to be..." you whispered to yourself, as you felt a glimmer of hope inside you start to light. "It just HAS to!"

Trusting your instincts, you jumped down from your porch and started running barefoot through the grass, trying to catch up with the shadow and not caring who saw you. The figure was moving purposefully but slowly, allowing you to easily catch up with it. As you got closer, you saw the light grey fur and pointed, black-spotted ears that you had come to know so well during this afternoon and evening. It was definitely your bobcat.

Just before you got to him, Likax turned to look at you, his eyes nearly bulging with surprise. You leapt at him, throwing your entire body into his soft, well-kempt fur and his warm, firm muscles underneath it. Even with a full-running start, the large bobcat barely moved when you slammed into him, standing tall and stable. You wrapped your arms around his midsection in a desperate attempt to not let him go, and buried your face into his chest.

"Carson!" he hissed, careful to not let his voice get too loud. "What the hell are you doing?" He wrapped a large powerful arm around you, trying to gently pry you off, but you held tight. Seeing that you weren't going to budge, he decided to gently rest a paw against your back.

"Me?" Close to hysterics, you didn't care nearly as much if you were heard, though the muffling of Likax's chest fur near your mouth helped take care of that for you. "What are YOU doing? Why would you suddenly vanish like that in the middle of the night?"

He didn't answer for a moment, and you looked up to see a pained expression on his face. As close up as you were to him now, you could definitely tell that he had gotten huge. Even clinging to him with your feet a few inches off the ground, he still towered head and shoulders above you. He had to be at least seven-and-a-half feet tall. You realized he was still wearing the clothes you lent him, though the shirt had ripped halfway down the middle of the chest and back, and the shorts looked like they were just about to burst off, barely covering his crotch and upper thighs, nearly skin tight. Of all the emotions swirling in your head right now, the most prominent was an incredible sense of physical attraction, one like you had never felt before. Likax was so big, so strong and powerful, yet so gentle and caring... you felt your affection for him growing stronger with each inch of height he gained.

"Look," he finally answered, shaking his head, "I didn't want you to have to be involved in my predicament anymore. You and Javier did so much for me, and I care so deeply about you, Carson. The very last thing I want is to put you at risk. There's just too much about me you don't know."

"I know enough," you said, a quiet confidence building inside you. "I know you're a kind-hearted cat who's curious, inquisitive, and a joy to be with. I know that you have a passion for what you believe deep down inside you. That passion may have led you to being thrown into prison in the first place, but it also kept you going through all those months of solitary confinement. Most of all, though, I know that the one thing I want to do more than anything in the entire world is to be with you and help you through this."

The bobcat sighed and closed his eyes, opening them after a few seconds with a warm but worried look. "It's not that easy," he said. "There's nothing you can do to help me, any more than you've already done. I have to run away; I just have to! Staying here in Danville is suicide for me, Carson. And--" He covered his face with his paw, and you could tell that he was starting to cry. "--I'm horrible at saying goodbyes. I figured that I'd hurt you only a little by slipping out in the middle of the night rather than getting arrested or shot in front of you and hurting you much much worse, possibly even leading you to getting arrested as well! You gotta believe me that I only left the way I did because I wanted you to be able to disavow any knowledge of where I had gone to. It'd eat me up inside to know that I caused one of the few caring, compassionate humans in the world to get thrown into jail for assisting a fugitive."

You sniffed a little as he said this, turning your back to him for a moment and looking out at the empty alleyway on the other side of your neighbor's fence. You weren't sure which feeling inside you was stronger: hurt for Likax having abandoned you, or awe and understanding that he did it because he wanted you to be safe. You wiped your tears on your sleeve as you tried to put your thoughts into order.

"Likax," you finally said, caressing his cheek as you did, "I believe you. I know you're too honest and caring to lie to me, and, I admit, I'm touched that you wanted me to be safe. But you've got to understand," you turned around to face him and grasped his paw in your hand, "I'd do anything for you. I WANT to help you! EVERY step of the way!"

He shook his head slightly. "I know you do, Carson," he said. "I just don't think it's wise..."

Screw it, you thought to yourself. He has to know; I can't keep it in any longer. You stood as tall as you could and looked him directly in the eye as you said...
12213212222211122222.title: Never Let You Go

choices: "I assume you're familiar with the name 'Mujexa', so you know where to go?"
"We need you to tell us everything. Now."
122132122222111222222.content:
"Likax, there's something... peculiar about me that you should know." You did your best to try to smile as you looked up at Likax, but he seemed to have a small look of worry on his face. "Nothing quite as major as you, though, but..."

The cat shifted away, trying to loosen your grip a little. His hand held yours, and though he tried to pry you off, it was clearly half-hearted. "I... I think you'd have a hard time finding someone as... peculiar as I am right now..."

You managed to give a small laugh, though you really couldn't feel any humor in it. "I think so too. But... I'm odd enough." You slowly let go, your body sliding against his as your feet touched the ground again. "When it comes down to something like this... I really am stubborn."

You saw him shake his head as he looked down at you. "You're calling that odd? I really don't think-"

"I'm telling you this now, because... Like it or not, I'm not letting you go alone. Even if you try to sneak out, I'll follow you. If you aren't with me when I wake up, then I'll do my best to find you. And even if you end up getting caught..." Your throat was dry as you spoke, but you did your best to speak to him. "Then I'll still stick with you."

"No... Carson, it's too dangerous." You could hear Likax's voice faltering, and though he was trying to keep you safe, it didn't seem as though he really liked the idea of what he was trying to do. "There's no reason for you-"

"Don't even try arguing." Likax seemed to jump a little as he heard your voice. Even with his size and strength, the firm tone of your voice had surprised him. "I told you, I'm stubborn. If I make a major choice, I'm sticking through with it until the end."

Likax looked at you, worry clear in his face. "You can be a bit stubborn, fine. But I'm not going to let you just follow for something like this. This is much more dangerous than-"

"I've gotten in trouble because of it before... Had a few fights, given my parents a bit of a time... I think Javier knows as well as anybody after I totaled his car once. But you know what?" You swallow as you just look at Likax, your hands drifting down to hold against his. "I don't regret it. It's a miracle that I'm still in one piece after some of the trouble it's gotten me in, but I'm glad I've done what I've done. And I won't regret this, either."

"You... Why would you-"

You only manage a small noise as you lean in. You do your best to stand on the tips of your feet, reaching up to try to get a good grip on Likax. Though you could barely reach him, you managed to give him a lingering kiss on his cheek before you lost your balance and slid onto him, gripping over his back. "Because I care about you, too, Likax... I care about you too much to just let you leave like this..."

You could see him shifting as he gently held you. It certainly seemed like he wanted to speak, but he was trying to hold everything in. You just held tight against him, your head resting against his chest as you heard and felt his heartbeat. It was racing, but despite whatever had happened to him in the past, it was now going strong and steady. You were just relieved that he was still here in your arms, and that you could still hold him like this.

"Likax... Please... Don't try to run away from me."

"I... I don't want to... I don't..." His voice was faded, and you could feel his arms just hanging over your shoulders as he held you. It certainly seemed like he wanted to stay with you, but he was trying hard not to admit it. "But you can't-"

"I'm coming with you." He tried to respond, but you shook your head. "I'm coming, whether you want me to or not." Despite his misgivings and your worries, your voice was quite clear when you said it. By now, it wasn't a suggestion, or you asking for permission. It was a fact, and despite his worries, Likax had no choice but to accept it. He looked at you in silence, before forcing a small yelp out of you as you felt both of his arms wrapping against your shoulders.

"You... You're crazy, you know that?" Despite all of his worries, Likax couldn't help but break into a smile. He lifted you up in his arms, just letting your weight lean into him as he held you.

"Yes, I think I got that when I almost tackled a seven-foot bobcat." You felt his hand press into the back of your head, your arms softly pressed against his sides as you let him keep you close. "But you wouldn't still be here if I wasn't a little bit crazy, so... I'll just have to deal with that."

Likax nodded softly, and you could feel his face brushing against your head. "Yeah... I'm glad, too... Thanks, Carson."

The two of you held each other silently. You were almost drifting off as you looked at him, and his gentle smile seemed to keep your mind drifting away. You felt his body pressing to yours, and you could swear you felt him growing. Despite holding so still, his fur seemed to push along, and his arms rubbed gently into you. Only the feeling of a stiff breeze snapped you back into reality.

"Come on, Likax... Let's head back for now... Even if it's just for one night, we should rest and figure this out while we can."

You saw him swallow as he tried to make a decision, and just let him hold you tight. It only took a few seconds before you heard him reply in a weak voice.

"Yeah... Let's go back for now. There's no point in me trying to sneak away now, is there?" He just lightly held you as he began walking. Though it felt a bit awkward, it seemed as though the thought of letting you down hadn't crossed his mind. He easily began moving back to your house, creeping as quietly as he could. Though he was certainly large and his weight made it impossible to be completely silent, he still managed to deaden his footsteps and creep back in.

Javier was around the door when the two of you arrived. It took a moment for him to realize that you were there, but he gave an immense sigh of relief as he opened the door for you, muttering something to himself. "Just hurry and get back in here, okay? I can't imagine how you two could stand out more right now."

The two of you simultaneously managed to give him a quick glare, as if both to say, "Don't ruin the moment". However, he ignored it as he turned back inside, leaving it open for the two of you. It was a little awkward for Likax to try to fit in through the doorway, and he took a minute to do it. Although he could probably manage it normally, he still was eager to keep you in his arms. Though he moved about a little, it was only after a few moments of turning and shifting that he managed to get inside.

"Right, then. First things first, before you decide to run off again." Javier was clearly a little irritated by now, and continued speaking as Likax sat on the couch, positioning you in his lap. "I've packed a bit of food and some emergency supplies in that bag." He nodded towards a plain bag on the ground, fastened by a loose string. "Considering we can't really get you any clothes that'll be guaranteed to stay on, I just tossed in a huge blanket. That's everything I could find for you, and I doubt we'd have a chance to get anything else."

You nodded quietly, though Likax looked a little taken aback. He looked back at Javier with a bit of surprise."When'd you have time for that?"

"Just now, I'm willing to bet. He probably did it the moment he saw me catch you. Javier's fairly good at planning things out. He's just panics when he doesn't."

"Heard that." Javier shot you a quick look, but you gave him a small shrug before hearing him resuming his speech. "Anyways, just do your best with that much. You might be able to get some if you're alone, but try not to show up in public places. You already stand out enough as it is." He sighed as he looked at the two of you. Likax seemed to be too distracted to really listen to Javier, but what he heard next quickly drew his attention. "Now, then..."
122132122222111222222.title: Stubborn

choices: They were trying to turn anthros into humans. They were trying to... de-fur us.
They were trying to manipulate our genetics to create super-soldiers.
1221321222221112222222.content:
You could feel Likax’s fur bristle against your skin at Javier’s somewhat-harsh tone. The passion in his eyes seemed to disappear instantly, and you barely made out a low growling sound coming from his chest. Your first instinct was to rebuke Javier, but as you opened your mouth to do so, he cut you off before you even got the chance to speak.

“Look,” he said, “I know it’s not going to be easy to talk about all this right now, but you have to try. Any small bit of information you could give me or Carson could come in handy later saving your lives.”

“But Javier,” you stated with a frown on your face, “I thought you agreed that we wouldn’t talk about this kinda thing until tomorrow.”

Javier pointed to the clock on the DVD player, which now read 12:37. “It is tomorrow. Besides, with how things are going, I don’t think we’re gonna have much more of a chance to talk. You two need to hit the ground running first thing in the morning, if not sooner.”

“But--” you tried to interject again, but Likax took your paw and gave it a firm but gentle squeeze. “It’s okay, Carson,” he said, looking into your eyes. “I’ll do my best to explain everything. I’m a big cat now, after all.” A sparkle appeared for a moment in his eyes, making you hope that he did indeed feel better. He turned to Javier, his expression again serious. “So what do you want to know?”

“Well,” Javier said, “frankly, I’d like to know everything you could possibly tell me, but I don’t think we have the time for that. Let me try to ask the most important questions, at least from my perspective. Then, at the end, you can let me know if there’s any other bits of crucial information that I missed.”

The bobcat nodded. “Okay, I’ll do my best.”

Javier sat down and leaned in close to Likax. “All right, let’s start from the beginning. First off: what lead to you getting thrown in prison? I found a small article online reporting on your arrest, but I’d like to hear it from your own mouth.”

“Was it that article from the Free-Fur Press?” Javier nodded in confirmation. “I read that at the prison library before they transferred me to solitary confinement. Well,” Likax sat back, making sure you had plenty of room in his lap to be comfortable, “the reporter got it more or less right. There’s some details that she missed, like the fact that I did my best to ignore the hecklers until they actually started tearing down some of the loudspeakers we had set up, and the small detail that they all were armed with switchblades, but everything else is pretty accurate.”

“Did you actually assault anyone or instigate violence like the police said?” Javier asked bluntly.

Likax started to shake his head, but then stopped. “N-- well, not really. I never called for anyone in the crowd to attack the hecklers. I just wanted them to get away from our sound equipment. I did scratch up one big burly bald guy’s face pretty bad with my claws, and accidentally knocked down his wife, who was with him, in the process, but, to be fair, he was brandishing a knife and had tried to stab me with it.”

“You see,” you said, smugly smiling at Javier, “the article was right. He was acting in self-defense.”

Javier didn’t respond to you, his thoughts having moved on to something else. After a few second of looking down at the floor in silence, he made eye contact with Likax again. “So what happened after the arrest? I couldn’t find any articles or information about your case going to trial.”

“That’s because there wasn’t any trial,” Likax sighed. “After twenty-four hours in the county jail downtown, I was put in a truck and driven to the maximum-security federal prison a few miles east of LaGrange. No one ever told me why, and believe me, I protested endlessly, demanding to speak to an attorney. I even got knocked out when I struggled with one of the guards while being transported. After that, I found myself unjustly imprisoned without any hope of legal recourse, left there to be a lab rat for those sick fucks’ experiments.”

Hearing Likax swear startled you; the bobcat had been so gentle and pleasant since you had first seen him. You figured, however, that after going through what he had gone through, not having any resentment or feelings of hostility towards his captors would be the real surprise.

Javier, however, seemed unfazed. "There's one thing that doesn't make sense about that, though," he said. "If you were imprisoned without a trial, why didn't any of your friends or family get a lawyer, or go to the media, or protest on your behalf-- anything like that?"

Likax chuckled and shook his head. "It sounds like you don't know much about how anthros are treated in our society, Javier. There's so much repression and brutality, even coming from the police themselves, that I doubt the few that I would consider my 'friends' would have enough courage to go against the system like that." He sighed and closed his eyes, leaning back on the couch. "And I don't have much family to speak of. My father died before I was born, and my mother... let's just say she wasn't cut out to be a parent. I was taken away from her when I was seven and have lived with my grandmother since then. Now she's one powerful old bobcat; she taught me how to be proud of who I am and what I could do, and if anyone tried to find out what happened to me after I was locked away, I imagine it was her. But I don't think she probably would've gotten very far. A teacher's pension doesn't buy you much legal help, and I doubt there were many mainstream reporters willing to listen to her talk about her missing grandson. I... In a way, I feel sorry for what she has probably put herself through, all on my account."

Javier sat quietly, contemplating all that Likax had said. What he described, you knew fairly well, having dealt with or witnessed similar discrimination during your previous relationship. Still, it angered you a little to think about how mistreated anthros still were, and how little you could do to change any of it.

"Okay," Javier finally said after a minute's silence, "I think I have a pretty firm grasp of what was going on before you got arrested. What I need to know now is what you saw in the testing rooms in the prison. What had they done that disturbed you so much?"

Likax sighed and sagged his head a little, but didn't take long to answer. "Okay, Javier. I'll tell you. You're not going to like it, but I guess you need to know. Just... just keep in mind that it's not going to be easy for me to say or for you to hear." He took a deep breath before continuing. "The things I saw... they would turn your stomach to see them. Many of the testing chambers had the bodies of their previous subjects still in them. A few of the anthros looked like they had died in their sleep. But there were several dozen whose..." He stopped again, his voice starting to crack. "...whose bodies were...mutilated. That's the only word to describe it."

Your mouth dropped open in horror. "Mutilated?" you repeated. "You mean, like cut up?"

Likax shook his head. "No. Nothing that simple. Some looked like they had lost any trace of fur, their skin and muscle completely bare. Some appeared as if they had been burned alive, their fur or skin severely charred. A few... a few of the most horrific ones... the only way I can think of to describe them is that they looked like their insides had burst out of their bodies, blood, muscle, and bone all having broken through skin and fur. I... I'm not sure how it all happened, but I'm fairly certain of what the experiments were trying to do."

Javier's eyes lit up at this last sentence, and he leaned forward. "What?!"

Gulping, Likax looked up and stared directly into Javier's eyes. What he said next shocked both you and Javier.
1221321222221112222222.title: Confessions

choices: Go to Louisville, gather friends & family, lead a resistance, & mount a defense.
Head to Atlanta to meet with Mujexa and try to see if he can help you.
12213212222211122222221.content:
An intense silence filled the room. You didn't know what to say to that; it seemed so incredible, so far-fetched that if you were hearing it from anyone other than the bobcat who was holding you in his arms, you wouldn't have believed it.

For his part, Javier didn't seem to be comprehending it either. "H-how could they... I mean, what in the... De-fur you?"

Likax slowly nodded. "It's too hard to believe, right? Too implausible?" He shrugged his shoulders, gently moving you up and down in his arms as he did. "I didn't believe it either when I first heard the rumors, back before I had gotten locked up. I thought it was just the ramblings of an old, demented ex-con. But after seeing what I saw, and going through what I went through… it just fit so perfectly. There's nothing else they really could have been doing."

Your eyes had begun to grow damp, and you buried your face into Likax's chest-fur, partially to dry them, and partially to feel the warmth of his quick-beating heart. A thought crossed your mind: why did Likax not end up like the others? What was so different about the experiments he had gone through, or, perhaps instead, what was so different about the bobcat himself? And what if Likax had been one of the others who hadn't made it? Even though you had only known him for a day, you had grown so close to him in that time that you couldn't imagine what you would do if anything like that happened to him. For a moment, you were thankful that he had somehow managed to escape that torturous place unharmed, but then another, darker realization set in: they were still after him, and there was still a very real chance that Likax could be forced to go back to that awful place, or worse. You shuttered at the thought, and vowed to never let that happen to your bobcat.

Javier had closed his eyes to take all of this in, contemplative as always. After another silent minute, however, he quickly stood up, startling you and Likax. He walked at a quick pace towards the stairs, disappearing from sight. You and Likax looked at each other, both slightly confused. "What was that for?" he asked you.

You shook your head and shrugged. "Beats me," you said. "I have a hard time figuring out what's going through Javier's head sometimes."

You heard what sounded like a large chest creak open, then shut several seconds later. Javier's bedroom door slammed shut, and he quickly shuffled down the stairs. As you turned to look at him, you quickly realized why he had left, and your face nearly went pale.

"Javier!" you exclaimed. "Where the hell did you get that gun?"

He didn't answer you directly, only sticking it out, grip pointing towards you and the barrel facing the side. "Take it," he said, his face firm and serious. "If what Likax says is true, then the people who are after you will stop at nothing to capture him. You need every advantage you can have."

At first, you tried to push away the firearm, but Javier insisted. Reluctantly, you gave in and grabbed it from him, examining the gun closely. It was a modern-enough looking pistol, small but surprisingly heavy, with a black rubber grip and a metallic barrel. Your mind travelled back to the only time in your life that you had ever fired a gun, when you were sixteen. The recoil it had given you then had terrified you and made you never want to touch one ever again.

"Javier…" you murmured lowly. "I don't know what I could do with this."

"Then you better learn quickly," Javier stated, his face rigid and firm. "You're probably gonna have to use it soon."

You looked up at Likax with a questioning look, asking with your eyes if he approved of you being armed. He sighed slowly, closed his eyes, and nodded. With his acceptance, you took a deep breath and turned back to Javier, saying only one word: "Okay."

Javier walked over to the bag he had packed for you and Likax, sticking a small box into it. "The gun's unloaded now," he said, "but this ammunition box is full. It should hopefully get you as far as you need to go. At least to Mujexa's."

At the name 'Mujexa', Likax's claws slid out involuntarily, and his eyes narrowed to slits. "Where have you heard that name?" His voice was deep, almost a growl, and a brief flash of fear came over you.

"Tell him, Carson," Javier motioned to you. Looking up into Likax's eyes with both confusion and panic, you stuttered to speak. "I-I… well…" Gulping, you collected your thoughts, and finally managed to get them out. "Last night, when I got the phone call… it wasn't a wrong number. It was someone on the other end that said 'They're close', and that I needed to tell you that Mujexa wants to meet."

Likax's breathing started to grow faster. "Carson…" He stared at you, as if trying to decide how to respond. "When were you planning on telling me this?"

You shook your head. "I-I'm not sure. I figured it would come up whenever we finally left here. I… I didn't want to upset you, Likax." You avoided looking directly at the bobcat, doing the best you could to try to keep your eyes from watering, without much luck.

Seeing how upset you were, Likax's face softened, and he placed a finger on your cheek, wiping away a tear. "It's okay, Carson. I understand what you were trying to do. It just… it throws a wrinkle in our plans, that's for sure."

The corners of his lips started to turn up in a wry smile, and you fought the urge to bury your face in his chest again. Sitting up, you climbed off of the bobcat's lap, and moved to sit on the other end of the couch. After composing yourself, you asked, "So… is Mujexa someone we can trust? I mean, he did tell me on the phone that he was a friend…"

Likax chuckled a little, looking down at the floor as he did so. "Well, first of all, I doubt you actually talked to Mujexa himself. He would never send out a message or call somebody directly; he has people under him to do that."

After having sat in silence for a few minutes, Javier finally leaned forward again to speak. "Maybe it would help us to know who he actually is."

Likax turned to look at your roommate. "Remember when I told you that during the riots at the prison, a few other anthros escaped? Mujexa was one of them. He's a black-footed ferret, in his forties or fifties, very lean, and a little taller than I am-- I mean, I was…" He grinned sheepishly at this last remark. "Ironically, out of hundreds of anthros who had been unjustly imprisoned, he was probably the only one in the whole place who actually deserved to be locked away."

"Why?" you asked. "What'd he do?"

"You've heard of the Comradity?" Both you and Javier shook your heads. "Well, the quickest way to describe them would be some sort of cross between an anthro fraternity and the mafia. Comradites don't do anything overtly illegal, but they're involved in a lot of shady business. Mujexa runs the Comradity in the southeastern US; he only answers to the First Comrade, who runs the entire organization. Now that Mujexa is out of prison, he's probably already back in Atlanta, where the Comoradity has a very large presence. But can we trust him?" Likax considered this question for only a moment. "I'll say this about him: he's a pretty interesting guy, very intelligent and quick-witted, and extraordinarily charming. But from what I've seen, the way he operated in prison and worked the system, and how he treated people who got in his way, intentionally or otherwise… well, let's just say I'd trust him only as much as I absolutely had to."

Javier nodded, and you leaned back against the couch, absorbing all this information in. A quasi-crime boss didn't sound like the sort of character you necessarily wanted to be associated with; still, he was your only real lead so far, and you knew that you and Likax couldn't handle the police (or his growing situation) for very long on your own. Whatever you decided, whatever route you chose, you knew that you'd have to watch Likax's back, and trust that the bobcat was doing the same for you.

Finally, Javier stood up and started talking as he paced the room. "Okay, so we know what we're up against, and we know what our options are. Now, we just need to form a master plan."

Likax nodded. "I guess you're right. What did you have in mind?"

Spinning around with a determined look in his eye, Javier alternated between looking at you and Likax. "The way I see it," he said, "you can do one of two things:"
