choices: "He mentioned a shelter near the edge of town. We can look for that."
"I'm hoping he'll be able to get another message through by the time we arrive."
122132122222111222222212.content:
"You first option is to head back home." Likax's head gave a slight jerk as he heard it, a little surprised at the suggestion. Javier continued speaking quietly, looking at the bobcat with a quiet expression. "If you know enough people there, they might be able to protect you. Your friends and family could-"

"No way." Likax interrupted with a flat-out refusal, not even bothering to let him finish. "I'm not going to put them at risk." You noticed the bobcat's grip tighten a little bit, the couch creaking a little under his hands. "I've already caused them enough trouble. I had enough qualms with just letting my friends come to my rallies, knowing they might get in trouble, too. I'm lucky they only arrested me and nobody else. If I do anything more serious than that..."

"Right, then. You've probably made your mind up, but I have to ask anyways." Javier's voice was still a bit cool as he spoke, and though you knew he was just trying to make certain, it was clear that Likax was getting a little riled up by him. "You sure this isn't an option?"

"I said no!" His voice had risen to what seemed like a snarl, and though he was doing his best to keep himself calm, he was visibly tense. "Even assuming I know anybody who could somehow help against an armed group, I'm not going to cause any more trouble for them! It's already bad enough for me and for you guys, but I really... I wouldn't be able to stand willingly dragging any more of them into this."

Javier nodded quietly. "Thought so. Something else you might want to keep in mind..." His voice seemed a little unsteady from Likax's outburst, but he tried his best to continue on. "In a situation like this, don't forget you're already considered a criminal." Likax's fur shifted up, bristling visibly as he heard Javier say it so bluntly. "You've escaped prison now, so anybody you stay with is technically a criminal too. If what you've told us is accurate, the last thing we need to do is give them any more opportunities to go after anthros. Worst case, you'd have an open war on your hands, and I don't see that being your goal." He sighed as he sat back, looking up at the ceiling. "Right now, I just wanted to make sure you understood the implications."

"You could've just asked..." Your voice was a little quiet, and you were a bit afraid to speak up. However, Likax seemed too distracted glaring at Javier to respond.

"Sorry, Likax. But if the last few hours haven't made it sink in, me 'just asking' wouldn't, either." Javier shook his head quietly as he thought. "Unfortunately, that means the other option..."

"Going after Mujexa." Likax's eyes seemed to sharpen as he glanced around, shaking his head. "I don't like it."

Your voice was shaking as you spoke, turning up to try to look at Likax's face. "A-are you sure it's worth the risk? It doesn't sound very..."

"It took him all of a few hours to get someone to contact you, right?" Likax's face seemed to show a twinge of fear as he looked down at you. "If he already knows that much, he's probably got someone watching us. If we don't go looking for him, it's only a matter of time before he tries to drag me somewhere the hard way. Right now..."

"It'd be easier to find him and cooperate, rather than wait for him to start causing trouble for you." Javier shook his head quietly as he spoke. "You'd think I could manage to dig up some information if he was really as important as you say, but I haven't found anything on him yet. Either he's been lying to everybody while he's in prison, or he's good at hiding himself. If it's the second, that's something that would definitely come in handy. But if it's the first..."

"I know. I wouldn't put it past him. The problem is, he's the only real option I can think of. I just... I still don't like it. I just got out of prison. But he definitely had someone watching, if he found about your number this fast. He's probably got everything he bragged about. It's just... creepy to think about being watched like that. And, it means that things are probably going to get worse for you, if he already knows about you..." His gaze returned to the ground as he seemed distracted by the thought.

You swallowed as you moved a little closer. He certainly seemed to have a lot on his mind, but you weren't going to let him keep on worrying. "Likax... Even if it's risky, I'm coming with you, okay? So please, don't worry about me. Just do what you have to." You manage to give him a weak smile, and when he turned his face up to look at you, he had a small one on as well.

"Yeah... I know."

"Before you two get too distracted," Javier interrupted, "I'd like to remind you that even if you plan on going after this guy, you'll want to figure out what to do when you get there. Do you really think some underground boss is going to just let you sit around? You do realize the implications of a giant anthro going to shady places to ask for help, right? Somehow, I don't think you'll be getting assistance for free, and I'm fairly sure they could think of a few things for you."

Likax seemed to wince a little at the idea. "Yeah... I know. Look, I don't like that idea of owing him. I mean, I really don't like it. But right now, it's better than nothing. Maybe some other opportunity will show up along the way, but right now, we don't have a better choice."

"I... I guess we know what we're doing, then." You give Likax a small nod as you hold tight against his hand, finally feeling it shifting before he gets a grip on yours.

"You two are still missing something obvious." Javier sighed, his hand pressed on top of his hair as he looked at the ground. "Do you even know where you're going? Carson, while you were on the phone, did he give you any directions? Contact method? Any real way of finding him?"

You felt Likax and Javier both looking at you expectantly. You had to grow a little worried as you turned to Likax, your hand letting go to hold on against your seat. "He said that you would know where to find him." Likax seemed to have a small look of surprise on his face, closing his eyes as he tried to think. "Y-you don't know?"

Likax shook his head as he looked at you. "Nothing too concrete. I mean, we didn't really talk too much while I was in prison. He's not the kind of person you really want to blab to. He... doesn't forget things that might come in handy, and in prison, that's... pretty much anything. He did talk to me once or twice, so I have a few hints, but he was always rather vague." Likax grunted and closed his eyes, trying to think. Neither you nor Javier felt like interrupting his silence, so it was a minute before he finally spoke. "I think we'd better head to Atlanta. It's the only real certain place I know of that's connected to him."

"And then what? You wander around until he finds you?" Javier seemed a little jumpy as he tried to think things through. "You do realize that there's no guarantee he'd spot you before the police did?"

"It shouldn't be that bad..." Likax swallowed and spoke. "We don't have too many options, and getting out of here would be a good start. And, it's a bit of a long shot, but there's still some chance we'll manage it."

"Still some chance? That's... This isn't just some small thing you can do on a moment's notice, you know!" Javier's voice rose as he spoke, rising from his chair and fidgeting a bit. "I'm... I'm doing my best to make sure that you two will be alright, and you're not exactly giving me a lot to work with, here! I mean, it's at least an hour's drive, and he might not even fit into the car that well! Not to mention the fact that you'd be seen... And if you tried by foot, that's easily-"

"Javier, calm down. We know that. There's not too much we can do to help it, okay?" Your voice would a bit difficult to hear over the sound of Likax's quiet growl, or over Javier's rather harsh breathing. And though Likax did have something to add, it did little to help reassure either of you.
122132122222111222222212.title: Dents in the Planning

choices: You wake up in a rest area; Likax has pulled off to get a quick forty winks
You wake up in Atlanta, searching for Mujexa
1221321222221112222222121.content:
“Near the edge of town?" Javier looked at Likax questioningly, then rolled his eyes. “Well, for your sake I hope you guys will end up getting more specific directions than that. Atlanta’s a pretty big city, you know.”

“Yeah,” you sighed, “it is... But I'm confident we will be able to find what we're searching for.” Looking up at Likax, your soft smile became a strong, confident stare. At first, Likax looked unsure of your response, but your confidence seemed to be contagious, and he quickly had a determined expression as well. You didn't quite know where you had found this inner confidence, but it gave you a whole new exhilarated feeling. You and your bobcat were going to make it together-- you were sure of it.

“Fine,” Javier finally turned his back to you and sighed. “Whatever. I just hope you’re ready for what you’re getting yourselves into.”

You exchanged a quick glance with Likax, then jumped up from his lap and walked over to Javier, placing a hand on his shoulder. "Javier, I know you're worried. Don't get me wrong; I'm worried too. But I just have a feeling that this whole mess is going to work itself out somehow. Don't ask me why I have this feeling, I just do."

He turned around to face you again, and you could tell he was fighting back tears, a struggle you too suddenly felt come over you. "You're crazy, you know that?" he asked. For a second, you stayed silent, not quite knowing how to respond, but then Javier began to laugh softly. "Both of you. You're completely insane." He leaned forward and wrapped his arms around you, embracing you tightly, continuing to speak as he did. "I know that nothing I can say will be able to change your mind; you're set in what you plan to do. I can't say that I agree with your course of action, but I know that you're doing what you think is best, and I respect that."

The tears began to flow from your eyes, and you knew that it was useless to hold them back. "Thank you, Javier," you said as you hugged him tightly in return. "I can't begin to repay you for all that you've done for me-- and for us."

Javier broke the hug, and smiled at you, wiping the tears from his eyes as he did. "So is it official, now?" he said, looking back and forth between you and the large bobcat on the couch. "Are you guys an 'us'?"

Feeling your heart skip a beat, you glanced back towards Likax, who seemed to be as hesitant as you were. "Uhh, well…" you said, rubbing your hand on your neck, attempting to stall.

"Never mind," Javier said, "it's not important. What is important is what you two are going to do." He pulled out his cell phone, checking the time on the screen. "It's now only five and a half hours until sunrise; if you leave now, you might be able to make it to Atlanta before then."

"Leave now?" As Javier said this, you felt the entire day and night suddenly catch up with you. It was late; you needed to sleep before you got near the wheel of a car. "Uh, Javier… I think that it's not a good idea for me to drive before morning. I'm… I'm just too tired."

Javier's face began to grow worried again. "But what if someone shows up to the house by then, or is tracking you during the daytime on your way down? Besides, who's to say that in the morning Likax won't be too big for the car?"

"Well…" Javier had a good point, but you were too tired to think things through. You just needed some sleep, to lay your head down on a pillow, and--

"I'll drive." Both of you turned your heads to Likax breaking his silence. He rose to his feet, still with that spark of determination from before, but now, at his full height, the bobcat seemed even more sure of himself.

"What?!" Javier seemed to not like this idea at all. "When was the last time you've driven a car? Do you even know how?"

"Yes, I do," Likax simply nodded in response.

"But," you sputtered, "you have to be even more tired than I am! I mean, you practically died and came back to life today, not to mention having spent the last few days on the run."

Shaking his head, you saw the corners of the bobcat's mouth turn upwards slightly. "Actually, I feel full of energy. I don't think I would be able to sleep even if I tried." Turning towards the door, he picked up the bag that Javier had set aside, and motioned for you to follow him. "So, unless either of you have a better idea…"

You stared at Likax for a few seconds, unsure of whether his plan was a wise one. There were just too many questions: how many years had it been since he last drove, did he even have a driver's license (though you quickly realized that this would be a moot point, since any policeman who tried to pull you over would have much greater concerns), and would he even be able to drive comfortably at his size? But you quickly realized that if the two of you were going to make it through this together, each of you had to trust the other. And if Likax said he was able to drive… well, then so be it.

"All right," you said. "We'll leave now." You turned to look at your roommate one more time, possibly the last time you'd ever see him, you realized. You could tell that he was dying to stop you from going, to keep you from embarking on this fool-hearted quest, but he refrained from interfering. You gave him another final hug, your eyes tearing up again. "Goodbye, Javier. Thank you for everything."

He sniffed a bit, returning the hug. "Stay safe, both of you. And try to get word to me however you can, whenever you can-- as long as it's safe."

"We'll do that," Likax said, turning around to wave goodbye to Javier. "Thank you for saving my life and taking such good care of me tonight. I promise that I'll find some way to repay it-- someday."

Javier closed his eyes and bowed his head down, biting his lip slightly. "You're welcome, Likax," he finally said. "It was nice to meet you."

With that, you and Likax headed out of the door towards your car, you climbing in the passenger seat while Likax squeezed into the driver's seat. It was tight for sure, and he had to adjust the seat controls all the way back and down, but he managed to barely fit. You just hoped that any more growth spurts would wait until the two of you got safely down to Georgia.

"All right, then," you said as you handed him the keys, which he put into the ignition. "Here goes nothing."

Smiling, he turned to you and gave you a quick kiss on the top of your head. "It's your last chance to back out," he said, a sparkle in his eye.

"No way," you grinned back. "You're stuck with me. Now let's get going."

The car pulled out of the driveway, and the two of you were headed on your way. You quickly gave Likax directions to I-75, which, from there, would be a straight five hours drive to Atlanta. Before you even got to the interstate, though, your exhaustion had gotten the best of you, and you started to snooze in your seat. Just before you drifted off, you realized that your head had slumped a little to your left, and was resting on Likax's shoulder. His fur felt soft to the touch, and the warmth of his broad muscles soothed your tired head. Despite everything that had happened during this crazy day, you wouldn't have wanted it to end any other way than this.
1221321222221112222222121.title: Final Arrangements

choices: You try to find a place where Likax can hide and rest for the day.
Likax carries you on foot, trying to search that way as the day comes.
12213212222211122222221212.content:
The drive would be a long one, but Likax seemed to be awake and alert as you watched him pull into the highway. Even as you began to drift off, you felt relaxed. His driving seemed to be smooth, and though he had his eyes on the road, you could see him turn a little to occasionally give you a glance. However, the drive was smooth, and you drifted off easily.

The trip was amazingly smooth. Even with the occasional bumps and jumps that were unavoidable, Likax did his best to move. You occasionally drifted back close to waking again. However, each time, you only saw the streetlights lined up in front of you, and Likax's shoulders against your head.

The long drive was over in what felt like minutes to you. The car had pulled to a complete stop, and Likax gently shook you a little. You yawned as you tried to get your eyes open, looking around in the limited starlight. Your words were a little slurred and drowsy as you spoke, shifting around in your seat. “Mmmmph... Whatime is it...”

“Little past four AM, I think... The roads were fairly empty, so I drove fast. How are you feeling?”

You yawned again and rubbed your eyes before you managed to get them open completely. “Not too bad. It's not a full night, but I'm doing okay. How about you?”

“Still awake and doing alright. A little drowsy, but I can manage until we find somewhere.” He gave you a small smile as he shifted about, struggling a little to get a good grip on the door handle and pushed the door open.

It was a good thing you had arrived a little early. He was now struggling to fit in the car, and had to sit with his head hunched forward and his knees bent up in his lap. He had to turn and just fall sideways to try and move out of the car. It was clear that he had to take extraordinary care not to break anything as he got out.

“I... I think you'd better drive, though. If you're up to it, I mean. I think I'd need to lay down in the back if I want to fit anymore.” He shifted slowly, turning to you. “But all we have to do is look around a little, right? I mean...” He sighed and shook his head. “Mujexa's probably going to be looking around here... I think he said his shelter's just camouflaged on one of the dirt off-roads nearby, so we'd better get looking around...”

“In the dark? You'll have to do all of the searching, you know.”

“Your eyes can't really notice? I guess my eyesight's improved a little, too...”

“Actually, it's more like, 'You're a cat and I'm not.' I can drive around okay, but you'd have to be the ones keeping your eyes open.” You shook your head softly, seeing a momentary blush in his face as he moved into the back.

“Ah... Right. How long do you think you can go for?”

“We have a few hours, tops. While I could look around in the daylight, you'd be exposed. We wouldn't be able to afford that. But if we don't manage it tonight, I think it's safe to say we'll be going on foot tomorrow.”

“Yeah... Let's try to find it.” You started the engine back up as you heard Likax struggling not to slam the door shut too hard. You took off to the roads, just trying to keep it steady. You could hear Likax jumping a little, his head brushing against the roof of your car and shifting each time you hit a stone.

However, even after a couple of hours of searching, you hadn't turned up anything. Although Likax still fit in the back of the car, it was difficult to ignore the sounds he was making as he shook around in the car. It was impossible for you to really get a good view out of the rear-view mirror, and he had trouble trying to turn whenever he needed to look out another window.

“Nothing?” You kept driving as you moved. Although you were still able to drive, the fatigue of an incomplete night's sleep was hitting you fairly hard.

“Nothing. I'm fairly certain I would be able to see it if we find it. We need to keep searching. We've covered a lot of space, but the information we have is pretty vague...”

“I'm not sure I'll be able to...” You tried to suppress it, but you gave a rather obvious yawn as you moved. You noticed Likax's head turn to look at you, both of his eyes gazing at you through the mirror.

“Tired, huh... We'd better stop, then. I don't think you're in any condition to be driving.”

“No, I'll be alright. It's only going to be a little while before dawn, so I can manage for-”

“Carson, you're already pushing yourself a lot. I may not be tired, but you still are. We need to stop now and figure out what we're going to do now.” He signed a little as he gave your shoulder a firm pat, his arm shifting a little to push over the seat. “There's a good chance we won't find anything tonight, so we need to figure out something.”

You nodded softly, just pulling the car over and trying to find a good spot to stop. “Right, then... I've got a couple of ideas on what we could do...”

The slight shaking of the car kept you awake enough as the two of you spoke. However, it didn't take too long before the two of you decided.
12213212222211122222221212.title: Drive

choices: You wake up with a shotgun barrel in your face
You wake up in a different place entirely - where the hell are you?
122132122222111222222212121.content:
“Okay,” you finally said, “if we’re gonna stop for a while, we might as well try and find the safest place possible.” You opened your glove compartment and pulled from it a stack of maps. When you had first gotten the car as a high school graduation present, your mom insisted that you always keep no less than six different maps at any time, "just in case". You had never bothered to really look through any of them, as the extent of your traveling was just from Louisville to Danville and back again, but you were sure glad to have them now.

“Let’s see what we have here,” you said as you flipped through them. “Louisville city map, Kentucky state map, Indiana...” You shook your head. “Nothing specifically for Atlanta or Georgia. I guess we’ll have to make do with Southeastern United States.”

You unfolded the map and held it up so that both you and Likax could get a good look at it. Scanning it, you found Georgia and were relieved to see there was an insert for the Atlanta metro area on the edge of the map. "How ’bout this place?” you asked, pointing your finger. “Chatahoochee River National Recreation Area. It looks big enough and sparse enough that we should be able to find a place there.”

Likax rubbed his chin and slowly started to nod. “And it shouldn't be too far away, either. The last sign I saw said we were six miles from the Route 19 exit, and it looks like the park's only a few more miles north on that highway. Here, give me the map. I'll navigate from back here.”

Agreed, you started the car up again and headed in what you hoped was the right direction. About five minutes had passed when Likax said, “Get off at this exit.” You did as he directed, and a few more minutes later, you saw the signs for the Recreation Area.

As you entered, your heart sank when you saw several cars lined up in a parking lot, fearing that this park was more popular than you had guessed, but as you drove along, you didn't see signs of anyone at all, and there seemed to be enough forested area to provide cover for the bobcat. Maybe this would work as a hiding spot, at least for today.

“There!” Likax’s arm shot out as he yelled, causing you to jump in your seat slightly. He was pointing to a well-hidden dirt path into the woods off the left side of the road that on your own you would almost certainly have missed. You quickly turned, skidding the tires slightly, and jostling both you and the huge bobcat as your car hit the dirt at much too fast of a speed. You heard a loud THUNK, and you looked in the rear view mirror to see that Likax was wincing, having whacked his head against the roof of your car.

“I’m sorry!” you exclaimed, quickly bringing the car to a stop and turning around to make sure he was okay. “I didn't even notice it until you said something!”

“No, it’s my fault,” Likax shook his head, embarrassed, as he rubbed his head with his paw. “I should have pointed it out sooner. And, um, I’m sorry for, uh, that.” He gestured towards the roof, which had a slight but noticeable dent in it now.

“Don’t sweat it,” you said, grinning, as you reached your hand up to help soothe the small bump forming. “Though I’m not sure if ’dented by bobcat skull’ is covered in my insurance.”

After making sure all was well, you continued driving, slower and much more careful this time. You kept your eyes as open as possible, making sure you didn't see anything that would indicate the presence of another human being: a car, a bike, footsteps in the dirt -- anything. As far as you could tell, it seemed like no one had used this path in years. Once you had gotten far enough in that you were satisfied, you stopped, put the car in park, and shut the engine off.

“Let’s stay here for a few hours,” you said, opening the door and getting out of the car, turning to watch Likax struggle to get himself in a position to put his hand on the door handle, without much luck. You quickly opened the door for him, and his legs, which had been bent up in order to fit in the back seat, sprung out of the car, his feet thumping as they hit the ground. You heard a loud ripping sound, and you realized that the shorts Likax had been wearing were now completely gone, and, for better or for worse, he was left naked.

“Um, how do i--” The two of you soon realized that Likax wasn't going to be able to just stand up, at least not without causing some major damage to your car. After a few moments of trying to figure out what to do, he began to slide himself out, slowly, but surely. Eventually, he got far enough out where he could get his balance and lean up and out of the car without hitting his head on the door frame.

As he rose to his full height, you became aware of just how much the bobcat had grown during the drive. You were now eye level with his hips, meaning he had to be over ten feet tall. He truly was an amazing sight to see, but you knew that meant he was now a much bigger target for those pursuing him.

For his part, though, Likax seemed to be not at all fazed. “Let’s hike a little ways into the woods,” he said, "so in case someone comes by they won't see us right away.”

You nodded, and began to walk at his side, but the combination of the bobcat’s much longer legs and your extreme fatigue meant that it soon became a losing proposition to keep up with him. Noticing this, Likax bent over, wrapped his arms around you, and gently picked you up. Your first instinct was to protest this, but you didn't have the energy, and it did feel good to be pressed against his warm chest and hear the loud, healthy beating of his heart inside. Within a few minutes, you were drifting off to sleep, just as Likax found a large tree to sit down and lean against, and just as the sun was beginning to rise.
122132122222111222222212121.title: Resting Place

choices: You were being used as a hostage to negotiate with Likax.
They were asked to help Likax, but are quite suspicious of you.
1221321222221112222222121211.content:
You weren't sure exactly how long you had been asleep. There was barely any light out, so you couldn't have been out for more than a few hours. However, your awakening was hardly peaceful. You snapped up a little as you felt someone shaking you rather violently. You tried to mutter as you moved and opened your eyes, but before you could even speak, you noticed the barrel of a gun pointed right at you.

"Quiet. Don't move, and don't make a sound." You stiffened suddenly, and your hear was racing as you looked at the letting out a nervous, choked noise. You tried to turn, but the firearm was suddenly pressed to your forehead. "Don't make me say it again."

You swallowed before giving a slow nod, trying to shift a little. The feeling of Likax's fur helped confirm that he was still right there with you. However, he wasn't moving at all, even as you felt a couple of hands grabbing your shoulders.

"Your big friend here's asleep.” You heard the voice answer as you were pulled upwards. “We might not be able to put him down for very long, but he won't do anything rash if you're out of his reach."

Even in his sleep, Likax's arms still pressed firmly on you and made it difficult for the men to get you loose. However, he wasn't in a position to resist, and in a minute or so, you were pulled free. You could barely move, and you couldn't even get a good look at your assailants. They were all in street clothes, but each of them was wearing the same vest, adorned with a splotch of white across the chest. However, as you were pulled up and slowly regained enough of your senses to get a better look, your heart sank. It was painfully clear that each of them was human.

You were dragged a short distance away, and you could hear one of them speaking. "Come on. We don't have time to loiter. At his size, the tranqs will only work for ten minutes. Get him secure." You swallowed as you felt the two men holding you pull your body back against a tree. Within a minute, you had been tied against it, and your hands had firmly been bound.

"W-what do you need me for?" You manage to speak out, but feel someone give your head a firm smack. It stung a bit, but you were quick to realize they weren't trying to injure you.

"Quiet. We're not interested in you." You heard one of the guys next to you speaking, keeping a rather disinterested voice. "We only want the bobcat. You're only here to make sure that he doesn't snap at us when he wakes up. If you cooperate, we'll be on our merry way soon enough." You grunted as you struggled a bit, but saw the man with the shotgun approaching.

"W-wha? If you think that I'm going to-"

"You don't even have to do a thing. He wakes up, he sees you like this..." You felt the gun pressed to the side of your head. "Then he'll talk. It'd be impossible for us to talk with him otherwise. All we need is for him to stay still long enough for us to talk. You're just our guarantee to make sure he doesn't run the moment he sees us. So as long as-”

"Grant! He's waking up!"

"Already? Even our conservative estimates said it'd be another minute... I suppose we'll have to keep this in mind." The man with the shotgun was quick to respond, and looked at you. "We're prepared. Get his attention over here."

"Mrrph... You awake, Carson?" Your heart seems to race as you hear Likax's voice. His arm raised up to wipe at his eyes, and he tried to look down in his arms. However, before he had any time to fully wake, you heard the man next to you speaking again, the gun held firmly to you.

"He's right here." One of the men spoke, and the unfamiliar voice quickly snapped Likax awake. His eyes seemed to jump immediately, and were pointing right to you within the span of seconds.

"Carson! Who..." He shook his head violently, standing up suddenly and glaring at Grant. "Who are you, and what do you want?"

"Just your cooperation. Things have been rough enough already. We figured this would be the only way to get close enough and make you listen. Just stay calm, and your little friend here will be free soon enough."

Likax took a heavy step towards you, and this time, you had to swallow. Even though he was clearly worried about you, it was impossible to ignore the threatening expression he had on his face. In addition, it was now clear that he had been growing in his sleep. However, while you had gotten used to the idea of him getting bigger, you simply weren't prepared for seeing the twelve-foot bobcat like this. You could swear the ground was shaking as he moved closer, and his almost rabid expression and bristling fur couldn't help but make you nervous. His entire body was tense and ready, and he looked like he would be ready to maul someone in an instant.

You weren't alone in feeling nervous. Grant kept his gaze on Likax as he spoke again. "D-don't move!" Though he was trying to keep his composure, his voice had clearly cracked a bit as he spoke. "You probably could take us all out right now. But you try, and this guy," he said, nudging you with his elbow, "is gone for good."

Likax kept his glare, and his expression remained tense, but his footsteps stopped as he just looked at the man. "You'd better be telling the truth about letting him go. If you are, I'll talk." He only gave them a silent glare, bending a little to look at them. "What is it?"

You just swallowed quietly as you heard them talking. You weren't completely sure what was going on yet. However, it only took a couple of minutes before you realized...
1221321222221112222222121211.title: Rough Awakening

choices: "You must be initiated into the Enlightened Cabal."
"You must disguise yourself as an anthro."
12213212222211122222221212112.content:
For a few moments, silence filled the air as the two stared each other down. It quickly became clear that Grant was the group’s leader, and judging by his grizzled appearance and gruff demeanor, he seemed like the type of guy who had probably stared down death without blinking at some point in his life. But even he looked to be sweating slightly when faced with handling an adversary more than twice his size, and the rest of the group looked even more nervous. You hoped that they’d all be able to maintain their cool long enough to keep from making any rash mistakes.

Likax seemed to be growing more agitated as the seconds ticked on. “I’ll only ask one more time,” he finally said, breaking the silence, “Who the hell are you guys?”

“Why don't you have a seat,” Grant replied, motioning with his gun, “and I’ll tell you.”

The bobcat growled but complied, sitting back down on the ground, crossing his arms over his knees and leaning forward. He kept glaring at Grant, a fierce anger apparent in his eyes.

“That’s better,” Grant said, relaxing only slightly. “Now we can talk. My name is Grant. I'm with the Enlightened Cabal. I doubt you've heard of our organization.”

Likax shook his head. “No, I haven’t,” he replied.

“Good,” Grant nodded, “Then we’re doing our job as intended. It’s much easier to get our work done when no one knows to look for us.”

“So what do you do, then?” Likax asked, sneering. “Are you with the government?”

Grant burst into laughter. “You're about as far off as you can be with that. No, we're an independent group that exists to, shall we say, help fix things that need fixing, especially when it comes to the anthro community.”

’Fix things that need fixing?’ you thought to yourself as you eyed the various weaponry in the hands of each of your captors. That didn't sound good at all.

Likax seemed to be thinking along the same lines you were. “So is that why you're after me? Come here to ’fix’ me? Perhaps change me into one of your kind?” With each sentence, his muscles seemed to tense up more and more, as his hands clenched into fists. You could tell that he was thinking back to what he had seen before he had escaped from prison, the bodies of anthros who had been the victims of those sick experiments.

Grant smiled, a strange smile that seemed genuine, yet cold and calculating. “No, my dear bobcat, the very opposite is true. The very purpose of our group is to help anthros achieve their destined superiority to humankind.”

Likax appeared puzzled at this, and you didn't blame him. “What?” you said aloud. “A group of humans that fight against humans? That doesn't make any--!”

Your words were cut off as one of the gunmen closest to you leaned over and smacked you across the face with the butt of his gun. “Shut the hell up, vermin!” he yelled, scowling.

Within seconds, Likax leapt from his seated position and lunged towards you, paws raised with claws extended, letting out a deafening roar that seemed even bigger than his already enormous size. With one swipe, he knocked your assailant to the ground, sending his gun flying. Likax quickly pinned him down with one huge paw, ready to slice him into ribbons with the other. The remaining gunmen seemed startled for a moment, but they quickly recovered and raised their weapons at Likax. Just as they were about to fire, though, you heard the sound of Grant’s voice booming throughout the entire forest: “Enough!”

Both Likax and the gunman stopped. Likax turned his head towards Grant, his face still enraged and his breathing heavy, but after a moment, he calmed down, stepping back and sitting down again, obviously struggling with a multitude of emotions boiling inside him. Shaking your head, you eyed Likax warily. You couldn't believe that this was the same bobcat who you had carried out of the woods, frail and half-dead, just the day before. It was awe-inspiring to see him jump to your defense like that, but the ferocity and power he now commanded was undeniably frightening.

The man who had attacked you slowly rose to his feet and scampered back over to the rest of the group, grabbing his gun from where it had landed. Grant shot him a look of apparent disapproval, but after an awkward moment, continued on with the conversation as if nothing had happened.

“Anyways, Mr. Rufalo,” he said, “I promise that we’re here not to hurt you but to help you reunite with a friend. I'm sure you know who we’re talking about, correct?”

Likax’s eyes narrowed as he slowly began to nod. “Mujexa.”

“Yes. Mujexa. You see, the Enlightened Cabal has been allied with the Comradity since both our organizations were founded, and when Mujexa returned from his stay in Kentucky and asked us to bring you in for a chat, we were happy to oblige.”

Your head began to spin as you tried to process all of this. “Wait, so you’re trying to take us to Mujexa?” you said. “That’s exactly who we’ve been looking for!”

Grant walked over to you and shook his head. “No, we’re taking the bobcat to Mujexa. You, boy, are going back to Kentucky.”

For a moment, you felt your blood turn cold. You started to protest, but decided to keep silent as the other gunmen aimed their weapons back at you, hoping not to create another incident like before. But there had to be some other option, right? You had been through too much with Likax for it to end like this; it seemed all completely wrong. But there didn't seem to be anything you could do .

“So, Mr. Rufalo,” Grant continued, turning back to face the bobcat, “if you come with us now peacefully, we’ll take you to see who you were wanting to see anyways, and your human friend will return back home, alive, safe, and no worse for the wear. Everything works out for everyone. Agreed?”

Likax sighed, his shoulders slumping, as he rose to his feet. The gunmen tensed up again, but Likax simply crossed his arms, looking back and forth between Grant and you. He clearly didn't like the terms he was being faced with, but it did seem like it might be the only way for things to end peacefully. You knew that Likax must be as torn up inside over this decision as you were: neither of you wanted to leave each other. But if this was what was best...

“No,” Likax finally said. “We stay together. Either Carson comes with me, or neither of us go.”

A frown crossed Grant’s face for a moment, and he shook his head. “I’m afraid that’s not possible, Likax. For one thing, neither the Comradity nor the Cabal know anything about this kid. There’s no way we can trust him enough to bring him into a base, especially one of such strategic importance as this one.”

Likax closed his eyes and turned his head down. “He saved my life,” he said in a low voice. “I trust him more than anyone else on Earth.”

“This isn’t up for debate, Likax,” Grant muttered. “Comradity tradition says that the only living humans allowed in their bases are members of the Enlightened Cabal. Mujexa would never agree to letting him in with you.”

“Fine. Carson and I will go back home to Louisville and see if we can find someone who can help both of us. Together.” Likax took a firm step towards you, the ground trembling under his feet.

“That’s not going to be possible, either,” Grant said. “If Mujexa has said he wants to meet with you, he will meet with you, the easy way or the hard way. I hope for your sake that it's the easy way.”

Likax kneeled down, bringing his face right in front of Grant’s. He didn't seem angry anymore, but an sensation of intensity emanated from him, something almost indescribable. “Then,” he simply said, “we have a problem.”

They stared each other in the eye for what seemed like an eternity. Finally, Grant turned away from Likax, shaking his head but saying nothing. Likax’s eyes moved from him over to you, softening as they did so. In this moment, looking into the big bobcat's eyes and seeing how much he cared for you, everything seemed to change, and you instantly felt that there was no need to worry. No matter how this situation resolved itself, Likax would be there for you, and you would be there for him. Neither of you were going anywhere without the other.

“Okay,” Grant finally said, breaking the silence. “The two of you can come to see Mujexa together. I have a feeling that it may be the worst decision I've ever made, but so be it.”

A relieved smile filled Likax’s face, and you began to relax. It looked like things might finally be starting to fall into place for the two of you.

“But,” Grant continued, turning back to you, “you’re not going to be able to just waltz into a Comradity base. Like I said before, the only humans that are allowed in are the Cabal.”

“So,” you said, “what does that mean for us?”

“It means,” Grant replies, “that before we head to the base...”
12213212222211122222221212112.title: A Tense Encounter

choices: "Right to the Comradity base. We can initiate you on the way."
"We have to take a detour. The initiation must be held at a specific place."
122132122222111222222212121121.content:
"You must be initiated into the Enlightened Cabal." Grant shook his head quietly as he looked at you, and the men accompany him jerked up to look at him suddenly. He didn't seem to bother giving them a response, but focused on your skeptical expression instead. "I've already told you more than you should know about the cabal. This is the only way you're staying with Likax, understand?"

You gave a small nod, but it seemed as though you weren't the only one who was suspicious of the whole thing. One of the men nearby pitched up, his voice barely containing his disdain. "We just found out about this guy a few hours ago! You know that we can't formally invite someone until at least a half a year! How are we supposed to just go along with this?"

"There are special cases for a reason. It wouldn't be the first time we had someone who urgently needed in." Grant walked closer quietly, and though he had lowered his arms, Likax still shifting a little closer to you when he saw the man approach. "He'll just be an initiate. We can treat him like provisional members. It'll be enough to get him into the Comradity." He moved in, reaching into his pocket and pulling out a small knife. Likax's growl only made him turn his head this time, as he glanced back at the bobcat. "I'm untying him. That's all. He'll be coming with us, so we might as well let him loose."

The bobcat quieted down, only giving a small nod as he approached. You felt the ropes around you falling, though Grant certainly wasn't gentle as he grabbed your arm and pulled at it. "Come on. You can argue more when we're not out in the open."

Likax's paw quickly moved, and you could feel his grip in your free hand. You turned to him, and he certainly didn't look happy with the way you were being treated. However, you gave him a small nod as you walked, his wide strides keeping up with you easily as you were pulled along. "It's alright, Likax. I've been worse."

"Somehow, I can't imagine that." He shook his head quietly, and his eyes shifted sideways, throwing an open glare at the man who had struck you before. The man had the same expression, but it seemed to pointed towards you, and not Likax.

"Hey... I'm going with you. Think that's more important right now..." You manage to give his hand a small squeeze as you walk along, seeing him duck a little to keep under the tree branches that you pass by."

He turned back at you, giving your hand a firm squeeze in return. However, a quick tug from Grant soon brought your mind back to the situation at hand. "Keep quiet. We already attract enough attention without the noise."

Likax's hand seemed to clench for a moment, keeping tight against you. Though he was following quietly, it seemed his nerves were still on end. With everything going on, you couldn't blame him. You cleared your throat a little bit before asking in the quietest voice you could manage. "So, how are we going to be moving? I don't think most vehicles will work now..."

"We've already got something prepared for Likax. We weren't sure exactly when we would find him, so we were ready for him to have grown a lot more than this." Grant continued walking, his tone cool and collected once again.

"That's... good." You kept walking, quietly, glancing around. You were more than a little tense from the constant stares you were getting from the others. "So... I'm supposed to be initiated into your..." You sentences drifted into silence as you stopped yourself from speaking. Your first instinct had been to call them a cult, but
it was more than clear them would be a bad idea. "Your group. What am I supposed to do?"

"Hm. Lucky for you, new initiates are only given tasks and little else until they can be evaluated further. All you have to do for us is to take a few vows to assist anthros, and to follow our tasks without asking questions. We're not foolish enough to trust newbies with anything more than that."

Likax spoke with the sound of a threat in his voice. "He's only joining you because he has to. You'd better force him into anything dangerous, or else..."

This time, Grant gave a small chuckle. "Normally, we have a background check, and watch someone for months before even offering this much. Even then, half of the people we invite get kicked out within a month without even knowing the name of our group. As long as your friend keeps his mouth shut and sticks with you, he'll be fine after all this is over. As for danger..." He spared Likax a small glance, an eyebrow raised. "You realized what's happening, don't you? You should know that he's in enough danger just by staying with you."

Likax seemed to pause, and you had to stop when you felt him hold still. However, you gave his hand a small tug, before nodding to him. "Likax, I told you... I know. So don't worry, okay?" He swallowed, but managed a small smile at you before he resumed walking. You turned back to Grant, speaking firmly as you resumed walking. "Look. Don't push Likax, alright? He has enough on his mind right now." Likax seemed to turn a little to you, but you continued speaking as you tried to keep your eyes from wandering back to the bobcat. "I don't know anything about your whole purpose, but you can be sure that I'm going to help Likax."

The men walking behind clearly disproved, and even Grant gave a small "Tsk", but he nodded. "That'll do for now. If you're busy helping Likax, that's enough. The moment you leave him-"

"Not going to happen." Your voice and Likax's both rang out at the same time, and you couldn't help turning a little to see him. He was glaring straight at Grant, but you could see the slightest hint of a blush on his face, and his hand squeezed yours a little more firmly as he walked. Grant didn't bother to give a response, and the next few minutes passed in silence as you walked.

"Where are we going, anyways?" You eventually broke the silence when your pace seemed to slow, eventually making it through a bit of brush and to the edge of the trees. You tried to look for the vehicle you thought you'd be using, while you heard Grant speak.
122132122222111222222212121121.title: Going Together

choices: On the way over, you're told more of your role in the Enlightened Cabal.
The others refuse to talk to you, leaving more time to discuss things with Likax
1221321222221112222222121211212.content:
"The initiation must be held at a specific place," Grant replied. "Every member of the Enlightened Cabal since my grandfather founded the group seventy-two years ago has been initiated in Holden's Grove; I'll be damned if I'm going to change tradition now."

You could tell Likax didn't like this answer. "Do we really have time for this? Need I remind you, I'm a fugitive on the run."

Without even looking back at the bobcat, Grant dismissively waved his hand. "Don't worry about that. We found you first, so you're going to be fine. Besides, the ones looking for you aren't close enough to find you in the next forty-five minutes; we'll definitely be done by then."

Likax sped up his walking until he was side-by-side with Grant. "And just how do you know that?" he asked.

"Because we do, Likax." Grant didn't seem to want to explain it any more than that, but when Likax started to growl lowly, he sighed and continued. "Look, our surveillance team back at base is hardwired into the tracking systems of both the FBI and the Georgia State Police, so we know where any squad vehicle for either organization is at anytime. No one's even close to this park right now, so unless you plan on suddenly taking off running for the nearest 7-11, then you'll be fine. Besides," he said, seeming to snort in amusement, "half the Georgia State Police are on the Comradity's payroll, so to speak. They'll make sure that no positive progress is made on this case for a while."

The bobcat seemed to accept this answer for now, and the group continued silently for a few more minutes. The trees in this part of the woods seemed to be getting denser and denser, and you started to worry that Likax might not be able to fit easily, or at the very least may start to crawl. He seemed to be squeezing by, however, and soon you arrived at a small clearing of trees, no bigger than fifteen feet across.

"Okay, there's only room enough for me, the 'initiate', and two assistants. He motioned to two of his men, who handed their weapons off to the others and headed into the clearing. "And Likax, the ceremony requires an anthro to sponsor the human for initiation, so seeing as you're the only one here, that'll have to be you."

Frowning, Likax shook his head. "No way, I'm not participating in any of this. We're only doing this so that Carson and I can stay together."

Stepping closer to the bobcat, Grant glared up at him, a feet that seemed both gutsy and unnecessary at the same time. "Look, Likax, I don't like this any more than you do. But if there's one thing that's more important to me than fighting for anthros, it's honoring the traditions of our fore-bearers. And this is a tradition that cannot be changed. Either you do this, or the whole deal's off."

Your heart skipped a beat as you saw Likax start to clench his fists and start to growl again. Quickly approaching his side, you placed your hand on his knee and looked up at him pleadingly. "Likax, I know this isn't what either of us had planned. But it'll be okay, I promise. And besides, I wouldn't want anyone else by my side for this, anthro or not."

"Carson…" As the now fifteen-foot feline looked down at you, the expression on his face soften, and his refusal seemed to melt. He closed his eyes for a moment, taking in a deep breath, before finally saying, "Okay. I'll do it."

"Thank you, Likax," you smiled at him, gently rubbing your hand against the back of his knee. As you did this, you could swear that, for a moment, you heard the large bobcat purr. Or maybe that was just your ears playing tricks on you.

"All right," Grant sighed in relief. "All you have to do, Likax, is to answer "I do" when I ask if any anthro sponsors this human. Try to use your full name, too."

Nodding, Likax stepped into the grove, having to squeeze between two fairly close trees, barely making it.

Once he was gone, Grant turned to you. "Carson, as for you, just follow along and repeat after me when I tell you to, okay?"

"Got it," you answered, trying to appear as positive about this experience as you could.

"One more thing," Grant said as he pulled something out of his pocket. "You'll have to wear this blindfold for the majority of the initiation."

Your eyes went wide in alarm as he handed the long black cloth to you. "Blindfold?"

Rolling his eyes, Grant replied, "Don't worry, nothing bad will happen. It's just--"

"Tradition, yeah." You didn't want him to have to go into another mini-speech again, figuring that the initiation itself would have enough of those. "Whatever." You wrapped the blindfold around your eyes, allowing Grant to tie the knot in the back.

"Initiate," Grant said, his voice suddenly becoming more formal-sounding, "take my arm and follow my lead." You reached out in the darkness, feeling the arm of Grant's jacket, and followed along as he slowly led you into the grove. After a moment, he called out, "Stop!" and you did as instructed, letting go of his arm. You could feel the warmth of your bobcat friend standing right behind you, and you smelled a slight mix of chemicals and smoke, as if someone had just struck a match, but other than that, your senses were completely cut off.

Finally, Grant's voice boomed from directly in front of you. "Initiate! You have been brought here today as a candidate to join our organization. Until now, you have only heard rumors and have received shadowy information about our group, but nothing concrete. You may have even began to question whether or not our group even really exists. Tonight, that shall change. Tonight, you will dedicate yourself to the betterment of all anthros. Tonight begins your journey to becoming Enlightened."

Grant let a few dramatic moments pass before continuing. "However, only those who have already provided service to anthros can begin this journey. Do we have an anthro present who wishes to sponsor this human?"

A few seconds pass before you heard Likax's low voice above you. "I, Likax Rufallo, sponsor Carson Fischer."

"Likax," Grant continued, "what has Connor done to deserve the honor of becoming Enlightened?"

It took a moment before Likax responded again, and you could tell he was considering just how much he should share. "He… He saved my life."

Grant considered this for a moment. "That indeed is a great service, Likax. I will accept your sponsorship. Carson Fischer, do you accept this sponsorship for membership?"

You thought about replying with a smart-aleck comment, but the weightiness of the situation led you to simply reply, "I do."

"Then raise your right hand. Do you, Carson Fischer, accept membership in the Enlightened Cabal, voluntarily and of your own free will…" Grant's voice seemed to get caught up on that last phrase, but he quickly continued, "… and thus will here-forth work to advance the positions of all anthros to their rightful place of power?"

Swallowing, you nodded. "I do."

"Remove the blindfold," Grant ordered one of the assistants. As they did so, you gradually became aware of two candles that the assistants were holding, the only source of light in the grove. "Carson, you are now a member of the Enlightened Cabal. If you do not take on this initiation seriously and with the importance it commands, you will quickly have that membership revoked. But if you keep true to the virtues that have brought you this far, the virtues that have led this collective, then you will surely succeed."

The two of you stared at each other, and you almost got a sense that Grant was reevaluating his prior judgement, trying to decide whether or not you actually might be an asset to the group. Maybe he was just giving you the evil eye, though; he was very difficult to read.

"Okay, then," Grant said as the two assistants extinguished the candles. "We're done here. Let's go see the Comradity."
1221321222221112222222121211212.title: Reluctant Initiate

choices: "We're going by truck.”
“Because of Likax, our ride is a little unconventional.”
12213212222211122222221212112121.content:
The walk away from the grove was just as tense as the walk to it. Although you were now a member of the Cabal, it certainly didn't feel like anything was different from five minutes ago. However, while the ones accompanying you were still grumbling a little about it, Grant looked oddly thoughtful as he walked ahead. You stayed a short distance behind, trying to help Likax out through the path as they moved ahead.

“That... wasn't as bad as I thought it'd be.” Likax spoke again as he managed to get loose from the brush. With an effort, he managed to slide out from the area, a tangle of wood and leaves caught in his fur. “A little more cloak-and-dagger than I would've liked, but it doesn't sound like you're getting pulled in too rough.”

“Not yet, at least.” You held onto Likax's hand as he stood back onto his feet, crouching to try to keep his head somewhat level with yours. “I just hope that they can actually keep you safe, and don't get you involved anything insane.”

“Hey, you're the one who just joined up. You'd better just hope that they have the good sense not to ship you out or something.” He gave a sharp glance up towards the others as he continued to walk, pulling your hand and tugging you a little closer as he moved. “I don't want you getting sent away...”

Grant gave a slight sigh, rolling his eyes a bit before he looked back at the two of you. “You know I've been paying attention, right? It's hard to miss the fact that you two are trying to stick together because you're in love.” The two of you stopped and stared for a moment, both of you starting to try to say something before Grant spoke again. “Fine, close friends. Or crushes. Whatever. It doesn't matter to me. All I know is, you two are gonna keep me busy enough just trying to work around whatever it is you have.”

Likax was too stunned to speak. He seemed a bit dazed after hearing someone else say it. You could see his shy expression, and you knew your expression probably wasn't much better. The two of you stared at each other in silence for a couple of minutes, before you were eventually able to get out a few words. “S-so... What are you planning on having me do?”

“Short term? He'll come along with us. We can say we're introducing him to the Comradity, if we need to. Once we get you into the base, we'll have a bit more time to plan from there. Long term? That's what I'm trying to figure out. As a new member, you normally wouldn't even see Likax. He'd easily count as classified, and we'd normally want to put him somewhere out of casual reach.”

“What? I'm not just going to sit around while you're making Carson do your bidding!” You felt Likax squeeze your hand a little more firmly. He had recovered his voice now, and you could hear a growl coming from him, his entire body rumbling a little bit.

“Bit dramatic, aren't you?” Grant placed his fingers on his forehead as he kept walking. "At the moment, the closest we can get is saying Carson was the one that brought you in. In that situation, we would normally keep the two of you together, and make sure that neither one of you leave.”

“That's fine.” You had responded without a moment's pause. Likax stopped walking to look down at you, and your head turned up to meet his. “It isn't like I was expecting to go out a lot while we were on the run. As far as I'm concerned, if I can keep an eye on Likax, that's enough." Likax blinked a couple of times before smiling at you, and you had to do the same.

“Come on, keep moving.” You had heard one of the men speaking as they went further ahead of you.

“You go on ahead, Jacob. Get our transportation warmed up. Andrew, you head for Carson's car. Keep an eye out for anybody nearby.” Grant slowed down slightly, and the others seemed to hesitate. However, they both gave a small nod before going ahead as Grant turned to speak directly to the two of you. “Look, you two. As much as you two want to stay together, it puts you in a bad spot as far as the Enlightened Cabal is concerned. We don't usually have situations where we need to protect a human. You might be an initiate now, but under normal circumstances, you'd be given a few jobs in the immediate area. If you couldn't handle most of them, you'd be kicked out before the month's out.”

Likax gave a small grunt as stood there, shaking his head. “If Carson gets kicked out, then I'll-”

Grant stopped walking ahead, and turned to face the two of you. “Look. I'm trying,” He replied with irritation, “to account for everything that could happen. And quite frankly, at this phase, I don't know exactly what the Comradity wants to do with you. I don't know how long the Cabal will have to keep their eyes on the two of you. But I'm doing my best to make sure you stay together under our watch. The alternative is letting you get captured or killed or whatever else when you run off. And none of us would want that.”

Likax faltered as Grant spoke, and you had give his arm a bit of a pull. “Come on, Likax. I don't completely know what's going on, but they're definitely trying to keep you safe right now. We can trust them for now, at least.”

Likax gave a small nod as you released his arm. Grant seemed to be satisfied with things, and resumed walking ahead. You sighed and start to move as well, but suddenly felt Likax's arm sweep around your body and lift you up. You made a sharp, startled noise, but turned up quickly to see him looking back at you. “This'll be a bit faster. You don't mind, do you?”

“Of course not.” You blushed a bit, but managed to meet his eyes with a small smile as he resumed walking. His fur was still on end, and his stride was a little rough as he walked. It was easy to tell that he was still a little on edge. It was understandable. Even with his body holding yours, you felt the same way.

Likax easily caught up with Grant, and held you securely in his arms as he moved forwards. Everybody moved silently for a couple of minutes, pushing through the trees as Grant retraced your steps back towards your car. It seemed as though everybody was thinking, but your curiosity made you speak out. “So... If I can't leave to do the Cabal's tasks, then how am I supposed to stay as a member?”

“If we're lucky, we can just stick you on guard duty for Likax. That'll save us a lot of trouble, and it'll give you the excuse you want to move around with him.” Grant sighed a little and shook his head. “If things aren't that smooth... Well, normally, you wouldn't have to do anything too extraordinary to start with. Mostly some scouting out. Keep an eye on a few important figures, and report back with any information that might be valuable. We might be able to figure out something if the Comradity's willing to use you as a go-between."

Likax raised an eyebrow as he heard Grant speak. “That's all? If that was all he needed to do, then there wouldn't be a need for this kind of secrecy, would there?”

“Using a newbie for something like that is already a major risk. Normally, we'd ask him to do something like this once he's trustworthy. Initiates aren't shown much of the organization. Too much of a chance of an information leak." Grant stopped as your car came into sight. “Here. Andrew will take your car for you. Grab everything you want to bring, give him your keys, and then we can hurry off.” He stepped moving towards the brush nearby to speak with Andrew, who was waiting nearby.

Likax let you slide out from his grip and onto your feet. You unlock the door and dig through the glove compartment, putting everything you could spare into your pack. You hesitated for a moment when you saw Javier's gun again, checking the safety on it before dropping it in with the rest of your things. You sighed a little bit as you glanced over the back seat, making sure you didn't leave anything important. “Are you sure that I can't just follow you or something?"

“Not an option. Likax wouldn't fit, and we can't afford you getting lost. Andrew will drive it to a secure spot. You could go with him, but you'll probably want to ride with Likax instead.” Andrew seemed to have a sour look on his face as he approached, but Grant ignored it and continued. “As for our transportation...” Grant glanced over your shoulders, looking into your car as he spoke.
