It had been roughly twenty years since the world went to hell. It's been described any number of ways, but no matter how people try to explain it there's no way to really bring the chaos and horror into focus. Some people say that the pendulum of science and magic finally swung back the other way. Others theorize that our universe crashed into a parallel and another reality bled into ours. As far-fetched as the explanations sound, they still make too much sense. All anyone knows is that one night, when Jason was ten years old, the world flipped while he were sleeping. When he woke up, the world wasn't the world any more. It was some entirely different place.

Looking back on the past two decades, he still found it incredible he survived. Most of humanity couldn't cope with what went down. People changed into walking, talking animals in flashes of light. Entire cities disappeared, only to be replaced by miles of primitive forest. The dinosaurs that populated these alien stretches of land were sentient, with their own cultures. Unfortunately, most of them viewed people only as food. Technology either went haywire or stopped working entirely. The people that were left either couldn't find a way to make it on their own or got taken out quickly by all of these...things they couldn't understand. There were reports that Buffalo had vanished entirely when a person found out they could make nuclear explosions simply by snapping their fingers.

The new society that he found himself in had just started, and even then it had happened in fits and starts. He lived in the western foothills of the Appalachian mountains, and a fairly eclectic town had sprung up in the valley below. People came up to barter for venison jerky or an ever-burning lantern that he had learned to make, and he found himself heading into town twice a month to spend a night at the pub that had just opened, or take care of business that needed to happen. For the most part, though, Jason left the town alone and they left him alone. He liked it that way. It was the first real quiet he had gotten in several years.

Which is why the sorceror was getting ready to blast someone to Kingdom come one night when he heard the most awful, terrified shriek sounding in the darkness. It roused him from a dead sleep just in time for him to hear something scrabbling on the front porch of his one-room cabin. He leaped out of bed and grabbed his wand for focus; he technically didn't need it to cast spells, but it helped when he was running on nothing but adrenaline. He ran to the front window to see if he could make out anything. Just as suddenly as it arose, the sound died. There was nothing out there but trees, the lit spiral of the Milky Way in the sky and the wide grassy field he kept around his property.

Jason opened the door slowly. As soon as he did, something solid and fuzzy slid against his leg. He jumped back and pointed his want at it, felt his will immediately center in his chest and bolt from his fingertips into the wand. The tip of it glowed and sparked before he called it back again, dispelling the fireball he was going to hurl but letting the wand become his light source. Once he discovered what was on his doorstep, he couldn't blast it. It was a person, after all.

More accurately, it was a Rabbit. It was bipedal, probably stood around five feet tall, and covered in white fur. At least, it would have been white if its pelt hadn't been matted with blood. It was completely naked and wheezing, its claws scraping against the wooden floor as it tried to crawl its way inside. One huge, dark eye wavered as it looked up at Jason. He couldn't tell if there was sentience there, or any kind of recognition. But it was clear that help was needed.

"Help...me..." it croaked, then collapsed in the threshold of his house.

A bright pinpoint of light grabbed Jason's attention from the treeline twenty yards away. That speck of fire grew in size and intensity until he could feel the heat of it. That fireball collided with a tree stump in his front yard. A geyser of dirt and splinters roared up from the ground and came crashing back down on his porch, through his front door. All that was left of the stump was a few smoldering roots inside a crater five feet wide and three deep.

Just like that, adrenaline shot through Jason for the second time tonight. He pulled the unconscious rabbit into his cabin and stepped out onto the porch, his wand already vibrating with his will. Whoever these people were, they weren't going to get this Rabbit. They certainly weren't going to get away with blasting away part of his property, either...
1233.title: The Cabin in the Woods

choices: "I'm sure there's something we can do to work things out."
Silence. And then gunfire!
12331.content:
Jason pulled the Rabbit inside his cabin none too gently, letting him drop on his floor. The sharp smell of blood filled his nose, mingling with the frightened scent of his new friend. It only seemed to help focus his adrenaline, to sharpen his response to these intruders. He lifted his wand and felt the rush of magic well inside him. The wood, made from a branch of willow in his own front yard, became an extension of his right arm. He could feel his will being made manifest through it.

"I don't know who you are," he shouted into the night, "but you're trespassing on private property. I'm sure you just didn't know. I'm giving you this last chance to recognize your mistake and walk away. Just step off my land, and I won't think anything of it."

There was silence in the dark for several moments. "You have a Rabbit in there with you, I'm sure. He came this way, and his trail leads right to your front door. Give him up and we'll leave you in peace, stranger."

Jason lit the tip of his wand so that the gunmen could see his face, and so he might be able to see them a little better. He felt his magic draw forth into the light, but he also felt it moving backwards, behind him into his house. That's odd. It had never done that before.

"Who I may or may not have in my own house is no concern of yours. Just get off my land before this goes any further. You should know that I'm a wizard very well-versed in magic, and there's a lot I can do with it."

Silence again. A different voice spoke up this time. "We know what you are, wizard. We don't want any trouble; we just want the Rabbit. He might not look it, but he's extremely dangerous and he needs to be apprehended for our protection."

Jason looked back at the stranger on the floor. Up close, he didn't look as bad off as he did earlier. Most of the blood had dried, and he wasn't as small or scrawny as he seemed outdoors. The Rabbit looked at him with his big, dark eyes, a pleading expression on his face. He didn't have the look of an evil man about him; he didn't look like he could hurt someone if he wanted to. A look passed between them that told him everything he needed to now. He liked to believe that part of his magical ability was the gift of reading someone's nature quickly and accurately. Whoever this stranger was, he was the one in trouble. Not the bullies outside.

"That's an interesting story. Now let me listen to his and be the judge of who's dangerous and who's not. If he's as bad as you say he is, then I'll hand him over tomorrow morning. After he's been patched up."

Jason took the ensuing silence to see if he could find any of the people who were hovering around the edge of the tree-line. Judging by the voices alone, there had to be three or four people out there, tops. It would be difficult, but if he could get them clustered together and got a lucky shot...

"Wizard, this is no affair of yours. Just give up the Rabbit and we'll be on our way."

"And what happens if I don't?"
12331.title: The Unintended Savior

choices: Most of them were badly scorched in the blast.
He hadn't manage to wound them much.
123312.content:
Jason swallowed quietly as he tried to listen for a reaction from the men. There was a small murmuring ahead of him, and he could only pick out a few words from their conversation. He managed to catch something about too much magic flying around and about the Rabbit's reaction. He swallowed, his arm outstretched and at the ready.

The sudden roar of gunfire from ahead made him instinctively jump back from the doorway. Fragments of wood split from the door frame as the shots rang out. He had barely managed to evade the first shots, and he quickly tried to take cover behind the walls as they continued. It was quite clear that the people intruding on his home were no longer interested in negotiations. His grip on his wand tightened, and the light within it seemed to shimmer as he prepared himself.

His gaze passed over the Rabbit as he prepared himself. The creature had dashed to the corner, and was hunched and cowering in fear. He had pulled his ears down over the sides of his face, doing his best to try to shut out the noise. However, his eyes were still open, the fear he held clear as he barely squinted back at Jason. Jason only looked for a moment, before giving the Rabbit a small nod. "Don't worry." The Rabbit stared at him for a moment, but a brief, loud bang made him try to tuck his head down.

Jason cursed quietly under his breath, inching sideways to get closer to the doorway. He moved his arm, careful only to expose the tip of his wand towards the forest. There was no way for him to get an accurate shot from his position. At least, not without exposing himself and risk taking numerous shots. It would be a waste to try to randomly blast at them, so he quickly tried to prepare a different bit of magic.

He tried to focus more of his magic into his wand, the tip glowing brighter as he tried to charge it. The odd feeling in his arm only seemed to grow stronger, the magic within him splitting off into different directions as he let it flow. However, he could at least manage enough for a simpler spell. It was only a few seconds before he closed his eyes, letting a blinding flash of light fill the area.

Shots continued to ring out, but the noise seemed to scatter, fewer bullets shots now firing off wildly. A few still seemed to strike parts of his cabin, but soon enough, Jason's eyes were open again. He knew that he might only have a moment, so he quickly moved his head out, his arm outstretched and already preparing a blast. It only took a moment for him to see most of the men now gathered together, their eyes closed or squinted as they tried to recover. They were still a good distance away, but while it wasn't a great shot for him, the situation was good enough for him to risk a shot. Without a second thought, he let the magic within his wand release.

The blast was clearly rushed. Jason didn't have enough time to properly aim, and the blast had gone off a few feet. He had hoped that the blast would be large enough to catch most of them, but the explosion was smaller than he was used to. He quickly began to move back to cover again, getting a good look as he did to try to gauge his assailants' conditions.
123312.title: Shots In The Dark

choices: Jason tries a spell to stop the rabbit's growth.
Jason holds his ground, fascinated -- or he flees the cabin.
1233121.content:
It took a few moments for Jason's heartbeat to stop ringing in his ears. When it did, and he could properly make out the quiet of the forest once again, he heard the crackle of a few small flames and a chorus of groans. That's encouraging, he thought, and leaned around the door frame to get a better look.

There was a huge scorch mark at the edge of his front yard. A few of the smaller trees had gone up like matchsticks, and he could make out several smoking figures lying prone beneath them. His eyes widened for just a moment, a pang of sympathy stabbing him right in the chest. Then he remembered that these were the same men who just tried to kill him. If it wasn't going to be them, it would have been him and the Rabbit.

Emboldened, the wizard stood in the doorway of his home and raised his arms. The tip of his wand was clearly visible in the moonlight. He wanted them to know that he was ready to defend himself if any of them were in the mood to take potshots. "What you've experienced is just a small demonstration of my power." He spoke in a high, crisp voice. He always loved this part. "If you'd like to taste more, take another shot. However, if you've had enough for tonight just say so. I'll come out to you, heal you to the best of my ability, and send you on your way."

Jason waited for their response. There were no more gunshots, at least. After a few minutes of silence, he could hear a man croak "Please. Help us."

The wizard grabbed his medical kit from its spot near the door and walked briskly to the men. The cool air of the evening was replaced almost immediately with an intense heat, the remnants of his fireball saturating the air with magical energy. It was high enough to make him falter for a moment, but he quickly recovered and reached the spot where these men were sprawled out.

Three of them had died from the blast, and there was nothing he could do for them. The other two had very serious burns, while only one escaped with relatively minor injuries. He helped tend to the other two, and with a combination of magic and field medicine they were able to get them in a condition to hobble back down the mountain and into more expert care. Jason was silent most of the time. There really wasn't much to say at that point.

When the only-slightly burned man turned to leave, however, he spoke. "You have no idea what you're doing," he said, looking remarkably earnest for a man that had just tried to kill him. "That...creature you're harboring in there is very dangerous. You should have let us take him."

Jason shook his head, unmoved. "Let me be the judge of that. I'll come into town tomorrow evening to check on your friends and we'll discuss it more then. Good night." He turned and walked back to his cabin without another word.

He heard the strangers leaving him alone to investigate this strange Rabbit in his house. At first, he couldn't see the creature in the corner where he had left it, but when he looked again he saw it standing with his back towards him. He blinked and walked over to it. Its ears were flat against its head and it was hunched over, clutching its arms. It looked to be in some kind of pain.

"There," he said as soothingly as he could. "It's all over. Just...just come over here and let me take a look at you."

"G...get away." The Rabbit shrugged away from the hand that Jason had offered. As soon as the wizard touched its fur, he felt a strange, sharp tug. It was severe enough for him to pull his hand away and gasp. What was happening here?

"I...just want to take a look at you," he said feebly, but now he took a step back. "What's your name."

"B..B...Benton." The Rabbit spoke through gritted teeth, in a voice low enough to be considered a growl. "I'm sorry I g-got you into this mess. AGH!! Please...step back!!"

Benton hunched further into the corner until he was a white ball of fur, and Jason could feel energies flowing from the air towards him. It was as if the Rabbit were a vacuum sucking the magic right out of the room. Benton whimpered and clutched his sides harder, then cried out. The sound was decidedly unnatural, and Jason took several steps back towards the far wall. His eyes were wide and his wand was out. He mentally prepared another fireball, even though he was certain most of the cabin would be caught in the blast. Maybe the strangers were right after all.

The Rabbit grunted and shivered, and then his hunched shoulders began to widen. That skinny back broadened with muscle that rippled underneath his thick fur, and then those legs grew decidedly thicker, longer, pushing the rabbit's head higher in the corner. Benton's whimpering lowered, drew out into a thickened growl as he grew. It happened in short, punctuated spurts, almost as if every heartbeat made him expand a few more inches.

Jason gasped as he watched, not quite believing what he saw. He could feel the magic swirling around the room now, ruffling pages, moving loose trinkets around on his table. In the center of it was this Rabbit barely five feet tall moments ago, now pushing six and a half feet and growing steadily...
1233121.title: Tide Turned

choices: The Rabbit gives a small nod.
The Rabbit gives a growl in response.
12331211.content:
It was difficult to think with everything happening, but Jason tried to take stock of the situation. With the steady flow of magic and the shifting feeling in the air, it was clear that the Rabbit was draining magic somehow. He took a breath, trying to figure out how his own magical energy felt. It took a moment to accurately gauge things, and the tension of the situation made it difficult for him to be certain, but the magical energy in his body seemed steady. There only seemed to be small traces of magic slipping loose. Did it mean that the Rabbit was only absorbing the magic in the air?

Something was off about that idea. He remembered the odd tug he received when he touched the rabbit. Could that have been the same thing? And he remembered the peculiar feeling that he had whenever he tried to prepare a spell. If the Rabbit had been draining magic somehow, it would explain the odd feeling that he had when he prepared his spells. Any magic that he could try to cast would lose some of his potency. He shook his head and let the fireball he had prepared dissipate. Throwing more magic around carelessly was the last thing he needed to do.

If he was right, that meant the rabbit was reacting any active spells and lingering magic in the room. Jason's eyes widened as he realized something, and he turned suddenly, moving to his front door and slamming it shut. There was still a lot of magic lingering on his front lawn after the fight that had occurred. With luck, closing the door would be enough to keep the remnants from entering his cabin. However, as he turned to look again, the rabbit was still clutching at himself and growling louder, clearly in pain as he surged upwards. The wind around him was picking up. The Rabbit's height was quickly approaching seven feet as he kept growing. There was still more than enough magic in the air to cause him pain.

If the rabbit was reacting to the magic in the room, he would have to do his best to remove it. Dispelling magics had never been a strong point for him, but if there was ever a time to give it his full effort, it was now.

Jason tried to focus himself again, his eyes closed as he tried to gather his energy into his wand. It was more difficult this time, with most of his magic quickly draining away and adding to the turbulent swirl around him that was growing more and more violent with each passing second. The steady surges in the Rabbit's size grew as Jason worked, the rabbit quickly reaching and surpassing the seven-foot mark. It was all Jason could do to remain calm throughout the experience. He just needed a little more time...

There wasn't any visible indication that his spell went off. However, a wave of relief passed over Jason as he felt the magic in the air lessening and the violent vortex surrounding him dying down to a trickle. As his eyes opened, he saw the Rabbit's violent reaction reduce, his body relaxing somewhat. While there was still a gentle flow around him in the air around him, everything felt calmer.

He quietly looked to the Rabbit, letting off a sigh of relief as he heard the Rabbit's strained breathing quiet down and his arms slowly drop from his sides. It was all he could do to try to contain the situation, and the experience left him drained. He had been unable to remove all of the magic in the air, but he had at least dissipated the majority of it. There was still a slight, steady change in the Rabbit's size. However, it was difficult to notice, and while the Rabbit inched upwards ever-steadily, he could tell that most of the magic in the room was gone. The Rabbit would probably absorb the rest in the room, but there was nothing else he could do about that. It was just a relief to hear the creature slowly calming down.

He nearly just collapsed onto the ground, only managing to sit down with an effort. He found himself a few feet away from the Rabbit, nervous to try to approach again. He spoke in a quiet voice, trying to look at the Rabbit as he did. "You okay?"
12331211.title: Magic in the Air

choices: Jason wakes up the next morning to find the Rabbit sleeping in the room.
Jason wakes up the next morning to find the Rabbit gone.
123312111.content:
The Rabbit nodded once, slowly unhunching himself and taking deep breaths. "I'm...I'm fine, thank you."

For a few moments they simply sat there, looking at each other. Jason tried to recover from the effort of dissipating the magic that had built up in the room, and the Rabbit calmed himself down, tensing every once in a while to feel his size increasing with every beat of his heart. He looked a bit sheepish now that the worst of it was over. His ears flicked back and he couldn't look at Jason directly. The wizard would have found it endearing if it weren't for the fact that he was closing in on eight feet tall and showed little signs of slowing. There must have been a lot of residual magic in the room. That, or the Rabbit was converting the magic he already absorbed in a much more manageable way.

Jason was the first to break the silence. "What's your name?"

The Rabbit looked up, then away again. "I...don't have one."

"You don't have one?"

The Rabbit shook his head. Jason noticed that the inside of his ears were turning darker. It was obviously an uncomfortable topic for him.

"Well, I'm sorry to hear that. Would you mind if I gave you one?" Jason did his best to smile reassuringly.

The nameless Rabbit returned the smile, rolled his shoulders. His musculature was improving along with his height, and the bulge of his shoulders, arms and chest were large enough now to be seen through his thick pelt. "I'd like that."

He made a show of considering it, but he already had a name picked out. "How about Rodney?"

The Rabbit's eyes flashed and he leaned in closer, his nose twitching. "Rodney? Sure, that sounds good."

Jason nodded. "Rodney is your name, then."

The Rabbit smiled, the first genuine sense of relief he felt from the creature since he had stumbled onto his doorstep. "Thank you...um, what's your name?"

The wizard laughed and told him. Rodney repeated it a couple of times, committing it to memory. "Would you mind telling me what all of that was about?"

Rodney's features darkened, and he hunched a little more. The growth seemed to be tapering at last, though he was pushing past nine feet tall and closing in on ten. His long ears had long since been bent by the ceiling, and they whispered on the wood whenever he moved. "I would."

Jason raised an eyebrow, and Rodney's expression immediately became apologetic. "I mean, it's just better if you didn't know about it," the Rabbit said.

"Why don't you let me be the judge of that?" Now that he had put the Rabbit at east, Jason felt the need to take control of the situation once more. Maybe it was because he had a nearly ten-foot-tall stranger inside of his house.

Rodney's large brown eyes searched Jason's face for a long time. He then sighed and looked down. "I escaped from a very bad place. Those men were determined to drag me back there."

"Were you being abused?" Jason remembered the condition Rodney was in when he first arrived. The wounds appear to have been healed now, replaced by muscle that was still swelling underneath his pelt. His height had slowed considerably, but he was still gaining considerable mass.

"We all were," the Rabbit's face was earnest, almost young, and it was a distinct contrast from the bass rumble his voice has become.

Jason arched an eyebrow. "All of you?"

"We were...made for that." Rodney looked down at his oversized feet, hunching down to fit more easily into his corner. "But I couldn't do it. I can't live like that. I had to get out..."

Jason held up a hand. The last thing he wanted was this beast to get agitated. "OK, OK, I believe you. Listen...it's really late, and we've both...uh, it's been a difficult day. Why don't we both get some sleep and we'll talk a little more in the morning. If I can do anything to help before sending you on your way, I will."

Rodney smiled, but this time it felt more polite than anything. "Of course. I thank you for saving my life, and for allowing me the hospitality of my home."

Jason barely heard it. He was rapidly fading at this point; draining the magic from the room had finished him off worse than he thought. "It's all right," he murmured, then stood and flopped onto his bed. "Good night."

That was the last thing he remembered before darkness enveloped him.
123312111.title: Relieving the Tension

choices: “I'm just not used to being treated this way.”
“I just don't think I should get used to staying here.”
1233121111.content:
Jason yawned and stretched out on his bed as he slowly awoke. It took an effort to force himself back up, his limbs still slightly numb and a dull headache buzzing in his head. It took him a moment to remember why he felt so stiff, memories of the last night slowly returning to him along with the effects of pushing his magic too far. Shifting up, he stretched out a little, starting to walk a bit as he tried to go grab a bite for breakfast.

He stopped dead in his tracks as he saw the massive ball of fur still curled up in the corner of the room. Jason quietly approached, a little uncertain of what to do. Even curled up as he was now, the Rabbit came up to his chest. As he watched, he could notice the Rabbit's body shivering a little. He slowly reached his hand forward.

Jason stopped halfway, the memory of what happened sticking out sharply in his mind. The last time he had touched the Rabbit's body, it felt as though his magic was being drawn away. Would it really be alright for him to do it again?

Jason shook his head violently, trying to throw off his worry. He had dragged the Rabbit in without any problems, and they had been in contact more than enough then. Touching the Rabbit should be fine, and if it was too much, he could always pull away. Jason swallowed, still feeling a bit of hesitation as he reached forward. Relief came to him when his hands made contact without any issue, pressing against the Rabbit's shoulders and shaking him softly.

“Hey... Rodney... You're gonna get sick if you're not warm enough. You can use a blanket if you need to, you know.”

Rodney stirred a little. His head looked up slowly, seeing Jason's small smile there. However, the moment he was alert, Rodney quickly jumped back, his head nearly slamming into the ceiling and his hands pressing back against the wall in panic. His body was trembling, and his head was pulling back as he nearly shouted in response. “I didn't-”

“Easy, easy!” Jason's hands slipped down as Rodney moved, but he firmly took the Rabbit's arm and gave it a pat. “You're safe here. Take a breath and relax, okay?”

Rodney's breathing was still rough and ragged, but he managed a slight nod as he slumped back into the wall. He turned around a little, looking surprised as he felt his ears brushing against the ceiling and his arms bumping against the wall, his forearms thicker than he had been expecting. He quietly looked over his own arms, holding his hands out in front of him and staring at them as he slowly moved his fingers, looking at them and just trying to confirm exactly what he's seeing.

“You feel alright, Rodney?” Jason's voice is a little more calm as he moves, craning his neck up to look at the rabbit. It felt odd to be comforting a creature when he could only reach up to his hands with easy, but he did his best. Rodney gave a small nod in return, shifting a little. “Try to calm down, okay? I'll get you some food. I don't have too much here, but is there anything you'd like?”

“Um...” Rodney quietly shifted downwards, sitting down and leaning back against the wall. “I... I don't know... Anything's good.”

“Alright. I'll go figure out something. If you're cold, you can take the blanket off of my bed, okay?” Jason's hand lightly gave Rodney's shoulder a pat while it was in reach, before quietly turning into the next room.

“T-thanks...” Rodney's voice was quiet as he spoke, but in the silence of the room, the word was more than audible.

Jason dug through the few bags of fresh food he had, finding a head of lettuce. He brought it up, closing his eyes and beginning to channel some energy into his hands... Before stopping suddenly. He had grown too used to using magic to help do simple chores, like cooking and cleaning. While it helped him live alone, it was something he thought he shouldn't risk with Rodney still sitting in the next room. With a bit of a sigh, Jason quietly brought the lettuce to a bit of water, doing his best to give it a rinse.

When he brought it back, he could see Rodney awkwardly shifting near the bed, still eying the blanket, as if uncertain whether he wanted it or not. “Really, Rodney. Just take it if you're cold. It's not a big deal.”

Rodney turned sharply, the blanket sweeping into his lap as he did. “U-uh... Jason, right... Um...”

Jason nodded quickly, before presenting the lettuce to the Rabbit. “Here. It's the first thing I could find that I figured you could eat. I really don't know enough about what rabbits normally eat, so you'll have to look for yourself. It'll probably be a bit easier that way.

“T-thanks, but... But I shouldn't...” Rodney reached his hands forward, holding them in wait. Jason drops the food into his hands, sitting down on the bed next to him while he watches Rodney munch on a few pieces of it quietly. “I don't... want to overdo it here..”

“Really, it's okay. I'm not that bad off that I can't spare some food for someone in trouble. Just let me know if that's enough, alright?”

“It's... It's not that...” Rodney swallowed his bite, his eyes almost watering as he looked back at Jason. He shook his head a little, his ears standing up a little more as he speaks.
1233121111.title: Still Here

choices: "I go down to the village to see what's happening for myself."
"All of the other Fables are free and safe."
12331211112.content:
"I just don't think I should get too used to staying here." The big Rabbit looked at Jason with another apologetic glance before nibbling a few more bites of lettuce. Rodney was being relatively dainty, eating slowly, but still half the head was already gone.

Jason rolled his shoulders, trying to work out the stiffness in his joints. "Trust me, you won't. I have no intention of keeping you here forever. But while you're here, you shouldn't be nervous about accepting my hospitality. What I give, I give freely. If I don't want you to have it, I won't offer it. Understood?"

Rodney looked at his smiling face, his ears perked forward and nose twitching rapidly. After a moment he nodded and grinned back. "I...understand."

The Rabbit nibbled more of the lettuce and Jason was content to let him eat in silence. He used the time to think about what he had to do today. Going to town would eat up most of his time, of course, and he would definitely be looking into what the people were doing down there. If what Rodney said was true, then chances are something terrible was happening that he would need to step in and stop. He had to find the best way to do that.

"I'm sorry, but it's just...I'm not used to being treated this way." Rodney broke him out of his thoughts, leaning forward to look a bit more closely at Jason. "Everyone else I've ever met has treated me like I'm this tremendous bother. I...know that I've caused you a lot of trouble already, and I don't want to make any more for you."

Jason blinked at that. "Look, all you've done is made my life more interesting. And, well...forced me to remember that there's a world outside of my land. If something is going on down in the village where people like yourself are being abused, then...I can't abide that."

Rodney's eyes grew wide. "You're not thinking about confronting the Company, are you?"

"Of course I'm going to confront the company. It sounds like they're doing bad things to other sentient beings. What kind of person would I be if I stood by and let that happen?"

Rodney gulped once, then stared at Jason for a long time. It looked like the Rabbit didn't quite know what to say. "It's...it's just...everyone in town loves the Company and what they do."

"Do they know what's actually happening in there?"

Rodney looked thoughtful for a moment. "I...don't know."

Jason took a deep breath and sighed. He smoothed his robes in his lap. This one could be awfully obtuse about things when he wanted to be, he thought. It might be best to encourage him to speak as plainly as possible.

"OK. So what's happening in there?" Jason kept his voice as low and soothing as possible. If he was going to stop this...company, then he would need to know everything.

Rodney took a deep breath and looked down into his own lap. Jason saw him look at his legs and heavy paws, and for a moment it looked like the Rabbit was legitimately surprised to see their size. He was enormous, after all -- nearly ten feet tall and well over a thousand pounds. It looked like he had grown a little more in his sleep, but he couldn't be sure.

"I'm not sure how much you know about us, sir, but...we're called Fables. We were created...some time ago to help make use of the magic that had been flooding the world. I don't know much about why I am the way I am, but I've heard that I can pull magic from anywhere around me and just...store it. Most people just call us batteries. They tie us up in a place where there's a lot of energy, and we absorb it. Then they plug us in to...some kind of machine...that drains us until we don't have anything left in us. Sometimes we're taken out to recover, but most of the time we're just...used until..." Rodney trailed off at that point, tears starting to form in his eyes. He kept fiddling with his fingers, tugging on bits of fur or a claw tip. It was obvious that he found this uncomfortable to talk about.

"They're terrible to us, sir. All the time. They tell us how stupid we are, how we're nothing but animals, how the only use we have is our bodies. It...gets to you after a while. You start to believe what they say, even if you don't mean to. Like, you're not worthy of anything. That the only way you can be good is to...hang on for as long as you can so they can take you out of the machine and let you rest so you can do it again. For most of us, that's all we have." He looked up again, at Jason and past him at the same time.

"I've seen Fables draining other Fables to last a little longer. We...don't make friends with each other very much. There's no point. If you're going to die any time you get put into the machine, why would you? Besides, we're all just...worthless. Batteries." He shook his head, his ears whispering along the ceiling. "I never believed that. If that's all they were, then why could we talk or walk or...do anything? Why bother giving us feelings or thoughts or anything, why not just...make batteries? If we're worthless, why are we alive at all?"

He looked down again, one hand picking at the thumb claw of his other hand. "I tried to make friends, but most of the others wouldn't even talk to me. But I managed to make one friend. His name was...Taylor. We talked a lot when we weren't needed, or when we were chained together in the machine. It made me...feel good to know that there was someone who I could talk to. It made everything feel like it had a point, you know? I had something to live for."

Rodney smiled to himself, placing his paws in his lap. Then his expression darkened considerably. "One day, Taylor went for a shift on the machine, and...it felt like he was gone for a really long time. When we're not in the machine, we're put in cages, and...his just stayed empty. I went into the machine myself one day, and they...they chained me right next to him. I thought he might have passed out, so I tried to wake him. But he wouldn't. He was...nothing but fur and bones at that point. Just completely wasted. I heard someone laughing and I looked up, the guards were looking right at me. They...they knew. And they put me there so I would know."

The Rabbit was silent for several moments, sniffling. Jason could see the big tears streaming down the fur of his cheeks, but he didn't know what to do. He was stunned. How could someone do that? It was unbelievable to him. Men couldn't be that cruel.

"After that, I decided that I had to leave." The Rabbit's deep voice was breaking now. "I...didn't know where I would go, or what I would do, but I couldn't stay there any more. It took me four months to do it, but I escaped." He looked up at Jason. "I'm never going back there if I can help it. I would rather die first."

Jason swallowed hard. He didn't doubt the Rabbit meant what he had said. But he couldn't let him leave until he got to the bottom of this. "All of the other Fables are free and safe. When there's a chance, I'll have to head to town, see what I can find out, and see what I can do about getting the others free." You smile and give him a small squeeze. His eyes jump as you say it, and he shakes his head violently.

"Y-you can't! There's... They've got hundreds of people watching the power plant! And even if the villagers aren't directly involved, they don't want their power source gone! You wouldn't ever be able to go down there again! It's not something I can ask you to do!"

"I know that." You lean in, your forehead gently touching Rodney's forehead. "But I'm not the kind of person who can just ignore it when that many are suffering." You stretch out a little, chuckling to yourself. "As for being hated by the town... I don't really go there much to begin with. I'm used to taking care of myself. And I'm not entirely defenseless. I think I might be one of the ones who lucked out a bit after all of the changes happened. You've seen what I can do, haven't you?"

"Woah, Rodney. I never said I'd try something like that!" You chuckle and ruffle his head. "I said I'd try to get all of them out. Doesn't mean I'm planning on charging in through the front door. I might be able to sneak them out, I might be able to organize a breakout... There are plenty of things I can do. I just want to see what's happening for myself before I try to make a more definite plan." You chuckle and give his shoulder a light press. "Though it does mean that you might be here for a while."

Rodney awkwardly fumbles a little with his hands, nodding his head. "Y-yeah... As long as you're sure... I just..." He looks up at you. "Jason... Be careful... I don't want the first nice human I've met to end up getting in trouble because of me..."

You chuckle and shake your head before stepping back. "It's alright, Rodney. I get into trouble well enough on my own." Rodney gives a silent nod before he resumes nibbling the lettuce. "Anyways, that can wait for now. It's still early in the morning, so I can take care of a few things and get a meal before I go take a look. You just try to relax, alright?"

Rodney gives a small nod, still holding onto the remaining lettuce, awkwardly looking at it as you move away. You move to your cabinets, grabbing a few pieces of the smoked meat that you have on hand. You start to make a light snack of it, pausing as you think about what you were told. Rodney awkwardly watches from his spot in the other room, the rabbit still looking too nervous to move.

You grab a small canteen, uncapping it and taking a quick drink from it before glancing back to Rodney. You walk towards him, his eyes turning away from you as he nervously shuffles against the ground. You're about to offer the canteen to Rodney, but you pause for a moment. You think about what Rodney's said before asking, "Hey, Rodney? Come to think of it, do Fables need to eat and drink?"

Rodney shakes his head. "Um... Not really... We can eat and we'll get energy from it like other creatures, so it can help... But we can live purely on magic... S-so... You don't have to worry about food or anything... I mean... I... Uh, you can probably tell, but I've got plenty of magic in me right now..." He paused for a moment, looking at the few bits of lettuce still in his hand. He awkwardly tries to raise his hand, presenting it back to you, his ears drooping a little in guilt. You think about it for a moment before realizing that the lettuce might've been some of the first food that Rodney's ever had. But you chuckle and shake your head before pushing the canteen into his free hand as well.

"It's alright, Rodney. You're a guest here. You're welcome to have a bite once in a while." You give him a nod, a small smile coming to his face as he takes it and takes a small drink. "Honestly, I'm a little surprised. I would've thought that Fables would be able to break out on their own if they get as big as you are now."

Rodney violently shakes his head, the canteen swishing a little in his grip. "They... They aren't. The Company's careful to make sure we're at a manageable size... They never let us get any bigger than around the size of a normal human. It's... It's part of why they drain us dry... To get as much energy as they can out of us, and make sure we can't ever try to get loose..."

"You said that they bring you guys to where there's a lot of magic, though. How can they just keep you small if they expose you to that much magic?"

Rodney shivers with fear. It's clear that he's not exactly comfortable discussing it, but he's forcing himself to speak to you. "M-most times, if there's a lot of magic in the air, they'll bring a whole lot of us... They'll just march us all... By the time we get there, if we aren't dead, we'll be exhausted and nervous... Every Fable will be desperate to try to get enough magic, just so they can survive..."

You swallow the bit of meat you're chewing on, giving him a solemn nod. Even the description of such an event filled you with disgust. But if no Fable had ever gotten close to his current size, it would explain why Rodney's so nervous. It must be an incredibly new experience to him, and you're not even sure if he's aware of how strong he must be now. You hope that he can adjust to it okay. "I'm sorry to bring it up..."

Rodney shakes his head violently. "N-no, it's okay... You're not... You're doing more than enough for me already... I mean, you saved me from those people... And you're giving me a place to rest... Even this magic... A lot of it is yours, isn't it?"

"Don't worry... The magic's not a big deal. I'll be okay after a bit of rest." You put on your best face as you say that, though you're not sure if that estimate is right. You'd normally be fine in a day or two, but your magic certainly isn't recovering as fast as it usually does. You can do your best to try to keep it hidden, but you know that Rodney's probably still draining a little bit from the air in your house. Your recovery would be slower than normal... You'd have to be careful with how much magic you use while the rabbit's around.

"It is! I mean... You saw how big I've gotten... I've never seen any Fable getting this big before... It's enough magic to keep me on my feet for weeks!"

You pause for a moment, tilting your head. Your curiosity gets the better of you as you look up and down over Rodney's body. "Hey, Rodney? How much magic can you handle, anyways? It'd be bad for you if you get overloaded or something, right? Are you sure that you can manage it?"

Rodney swallows before he responds...

1241.content:
Light was streaming from above. And the bitter cold of the winter chill that crept through you was no longer there. You had been running for hours through the northern snowfall, deep into the woods and far up the mountains near your village. Whatever worth you were is long gone. Selling children into slavery for their own benefit was becoming a trend in your back-water town. Your dreams of grandeur in a life far away from it were almost snuffed out. Had it not been for a dear friend’s help you would have been next. You had already guessed as well but the greatest hints come from others. You just hoped that she was okay too.

You were given this help just before they had come to take you away. But they are on your trail as you ran through the empty woods. Thankfully your footprints were being covered slowly by the snow that nearly blinded you. The chill comes naturally with the land and the snow was low so the grass that peaked through helped to cover your path as well.

Where you were running to mattered little, as long as you escaped. But you were in unknown territory. And with the snow and forest life, lost at the time. That’s when your memory becomes vague, because that was the time that you were nearly caught.

Even though you managed to get away, they were still able to follow you through the snow. By then you figured that they were probably professionals at collecting their ‘merchandise’. Many must have run-away before, and they were sent to catch them. Your parents must have already paid.

You had already run out into a clearing that ran over the edge of a cliff. There was no escape where you were now. You ran to the edge to see if you could climb down. But the height was beyond your miniscule climbing ability. You were trapped…

But when you thought your hopes had died, you noticed a ledge below. You walked near it. It was a bit of a ways down, and if you missed… But at this point of desperation you didn’t care. Without a yell or care, you jumped down to the ledge below.

On the way you had lost your footing and stumbled backward, into the mouth of a cave no less. Sliding down you found yourself amongst clear ice crystal. One you had mistakenly bumped into, hard. You were in a partial daze because of it as well.

But even in your daze your greatest fear of the time had come to fruition. Your interlopers saw the ledge and were already entering the cave after you. You backed away in fear, but partly paralyzed from your crash. Their faces were cold but they were enjoying the hunt, you could see it plainly in there malevolent smiles.

As you backed away, you heard a faint cracking. Most of the noise in your ears was a hallowed washing noise like a river. You could not even tell if they were talking or their footsteps were making a similar noise. You just kept moving back until the cracking became a full snap. The ceiling rumbled and then you noticed what you had done. You’d released an icicle so large it connected to the floor from it’s spot. You must have loosened it when you bumped into it. It fell back and crashed into a large wall of ice behind you, cracking the glassy wall.

You only paid attention to the men after seeing the wall crack; it was not as if it would help to kill the three of you in this cavern. You kept your gaze on them. But, to your surprise they had stopped inching closer. In fact they were no longer looking at you but past you. Something behind you was making their blood run cold and you were glad for it.
As they stopped, the ice behind you shattered and a piece slammed into the back of your neck.The last thing you remember before blacking out completely were the men being thrown to the side and you being lifted up. The visions after were dark and blurry, but you remember a strange and comforting dream. Of being surrounded by snow white feathery clouds around you as you were whisked through the sky, the sun falling below its spectral line.

…

Those were the events that led you to this odd environment. You were surrounded by odd white feathers. But they had no stems, anything connecting to the fur, or skin for them to come from. But these feathers were huge and cradling you softly in their warmth. On closer inspection, the fur that made them was almost crystal like; glassy and colorful. If you had to say, they were more like feather scales.

Whatever you were sitting in was drenched in light coming from above. You peeled yourself out of the warm cocoon as best you could to see. When you finally managed to pull away the feather bungalow you found yourself covered in bright light you had to strain to see until your eyes adjusted.

Your real location was in a silvery blue cave in which your feather bed was inside of. The light was coming from a hole high above you. You could see the sky through it, the hole was huge enough to show. But was so high and put at such an odd angle it could not be climbed through. The floor was too far away for you to see, but from where you were already it was still a faraway height.

You struggled upward to see. Thankfully the feathers did not bend easily, only curve. It was odd to stand on something so soft yet strong, but you were able to see at least. The path of feathers led downward to a lake below where the feathers ended in odd prongs. But there was something stranger then the prongs. Something was moving down at the lake. Swishing left and right very slowly.

It had beautiful golden curves and trails coming off of it. Then you saw it suddenly flick upward and the entire trail shifted with it. You heard and felt the rushing of wind from above you. And as you turned to look up, your world was turned with it.

A face stood above you, reptilian in looks. Your thoughts automatically came out as ‘dragon’. And the feathers you had been laying in were its furry scales. To your thanks it was asleep and gently breathed as it did. For whatever reason it had taken you and not eaten you was beyond your knowledge. But your fears would not let you be near it without an explanation for long.

12411.content:
When you saw the huge face above you tripped on the down that you were standing on. Backing away hurriedly and very agitated. But you did dare speak a word or you may wake up the beast. But when you backed away, you noticed that the beast was waking. Its eyes cracking open and move their gaze upon the you backing away. It lifted its head up and open its eyes fully, then smiles. "Glad to see you're awake."

"Y-you talk?!" you stopped backing away but almost fell backward on the fluff of his stomach giving way to your irregular motions.

"Heh, Yes I do," responded the dragon happily, "Are you alright by the way?"

"What? Why would you...gah!" you completely fell backward from the feathers giving way and nearly slid off into the lake below had you not been caught. You found yourself being placed right side up by the dragon in his open palm.

He sat up some and said with lovingness, "have to be careful, wouldn't want you to get hurt now."

You were very surprised at his reactions to you, a monstrous creature of his size...what could he be thinking? "...the only dragons I've ever heard of...are fire breathing creatures that eat people..."

He chuckled softly, "I can understand where your fear would stem from then. But have no fear of me," responding comfortingly, "as I, amongst others, are quite different. Dragons like me are actually quite fond of people, especially the ones who save us. Like you."

"Save..? When did I..?" your mind was in a bit of a mess. But his sincere smile was more comforting to your racing mind then thoughts of being eaten. And now hearing this has stiffened you up to the point that you weren't sure what to think. You sat still in his palm looking up to his smiling face, waiting for an explanation.

"You see, I'm not sure what happened before hand but I was trapped in that glacier which broke apart when you came along. If it weren't for you, I'd have remained trapped there until who knows win," the dragon answered.

"You're what broke out of the glacier?!" you were surprised and bewildered. You were at least able to understand if he may be thankful. But you still weren't sure of his agenda. "Okay, I get that I saved you now. But what is it you intend to do now that you're free?"

"Well, I only would feel right if I were to help protect you. I rather like the company of humans to begin with...but being what I am, and how most of your race presumes us to be...it's not always quite as easy as I'd hope it could be."

You were even more perplexed now, but you heard the solemnity in his voice as he looked down and away from you for a moment. "You really aren't bad at all...sorry I mistook you for something you're not...do you have a name?"

He looks back at you and says in a firm, confident tone, "They call me Nova."
"Nova...like the sun...uhm...it's nice to meet you Nova," you let out your hand in a sort of nervous greeting. Not sure what to expect.

Nova reaches out with his other hand and carefully shakes your hand, "Nice to meet you as well."

His hand was soft and fluffy with much smaller feathery scales then the rest of his body. He was warm to the touch too.

...

After getting to know each other a bit you were finally able to have a comfortable conversation with each other. No longer scared, he was a very pleasant person to talk to.
"Do you remember how or why you got trapped in that glacier?"

"Well...I was with my mother when we were attacked. We had gotten separated but I knew I would only be best off running away, though blindly, rather than trying to look around and find her. I ran into the cave hoping they might leave me alone, or that I might be able to ward them off with the space being less open. But neither occurred and they managed to knock me out," he told his story, "I think I recall a moment of consciousness realizing that I was being trapped , but the shock of it all quickly dragged me back into a coma-like state. Then I was awakened by the destruction of the glacier."

"...I'm so sorry you lost your mom...and you don't know how long you could have been in there either... I was in a pretty bad mess myself..." you told him your story as well while sitting in his palm. Of being chased and ending up in the cave Nova was in. "In a way, you saved me too."

"Perhaps it was fate then," he smiled softly with a somewhat solemn tone, from the sorrowful stories both have as their pasts, "I'm glad that I was also able to save you though."

Nova brought you up closer to his face to say that as meaningfully as he could. You felt his calm breaths warm you up more in the obviously cold cavern, "uhm...Nova...can I pet you? I've never pet a dragon before; I did pet a dog once. But it wasn't mine."

Nova nodded, "Of course you may," he lowered his head.

You carefully placed your hand on his soft fluff above his nose. You pat it as best you could and watched as his eyes softened on you. He was enjoying the feeling, even mesmerized by the time you were done.

He nuzzled your hand gently w/the tip if his nose, smiling. You were a bit stunned by the initial movement, but then you felt the warmth and comfort in his face. He really was kind. "Nova, what do you want to do now that you're free? You're a dragon...they're being hunted around the world...but you shouldn't be. You're actually really nice Nova."
12411.title: One Savior to Another

choices: "I...I had to kill them."
"I chased them away."
124112.content:
Nova looks downcast as he continues. "I trust that you won't do anything to hurt me. And I'm sure there are other humans like you out there who would be kind to me." You nod, trying to be positive. "But the look on your face when you woke up here--if you had a weapon, I might have been hurt, or worse, before I could explain myself."

You want to deny that you would have done that, but thinking back to how you felt when you found yourself in this giant dragon's clutches, you realize that if you had a chance to attack then, you probably would have. "You're right. But I'm happy I couldn't," you add, smiling.

Nova returns your smile before going on. "And even ignoring any physical threats, which I honestly think I can deal with, I just don't want to be forced to defend myself, or constantly explain that I'm not evil and not going to eat people. It just makes the most sense."

You realize that you're basically in the same situation. You have nowhere to call home anymore, and you aren't even sure if you could travel anywhere without a risk of getting caught by the slavers and their bounty hunters. Most importantly of all, you trust Nova. Despite his imposing frame, his face exudes a fundamental happiness that puts you at ease. It's all the more remarkable when you think about everything he's been through. You quietly resolve to help this dragon as much as you can, though you have some doubts about just how much you can help someone many times your size. "I understand," you say after a while. "In that case...do you mind if I stay with you?"

Nova chuckles a little before he answers. "What do you think I meant when I said I would help protect you? Of course that's okay with me. I know we could both use the company."

"Thanks...a lot. I promise to do what I can," you're both silent before you look around the cave once more and realize that you still don't know exactly where you are. "So...where have you taken me?"

"Oh, that's right, I never actually told you, did I? We're in a cave about a half hours flight from the glacier where you found me. I figured it was a perfect hiding spot because the only entrance is that hole up there," he points the the giant hole that allows light to come through. "There might be an exit deeper in the cave, but as you can guess, the caverns can get a little restrictive for someone my size. Regardless, I think we should stay here for now. I'll start a fire when the night comes so we have some source of light and warmth."

Curious, you can't help but ask Nova, "Can you breathe fire?"

"Yeah, but not for that long. Enough to get a fire started, but it's not like I could just provide enough light and warmth myself. We'll have to go get some kindling before the night comes."

"Sounds good." One of your chores in the village was always to go gather kindling and start the fire, so you're totally okay with doing that chore for someone you actually care about. Wanting to continue the conversation, and still curious, you ask Nova, "so, how old are you?"

"In dragon years or human years? I'm afraid we age a bit differently than you. In human years I'd be...17, I think?"

"That's how old I am," you say with a smile. You still can't believe your fortune. A couple of days ago, you were sure that your life was over. Now, thanks to this dragon, of all creatures, you realize that you have a prime opportunity to do all the things you never thought you'd be able to do. You feel you have a new lease on life, all thanks to this beautiful golden dragon.

You realize that Nova never explained what happened to the people chasing after you. "Nova, what happened to the people you saved me from?"

He sighs before he responds...

You got to the center of the blaze, the large gate to the underground site was wide open, many of the intruder's bodies were strewn across the ground. They died while trying to escape, meaning something happened before the fire and explosion. When you looked down to their bodies they were drained of their blood which lay in trails spreading back to the inner bulkhead leading to the lab. As you knelt down you also noticed something was pulling you in. The blood trails were scaling up the crack of the bulkhead doors.

Reaching into the pocket of one of the corpses you pulled out a blood stained key card and ran to the bulkhead's service door to it's side. Opening the door and running up the stairs, the pull was becoming stronger and the hall was becoming darker and hazier by each stair you climbed. 'They even used illusion magic, why would they try to make something so unpredictable?' you thought to yourself. When you got to the top of the stairs you stood before a windowed door leading to the main room. The window itself had shattered, but the shards hung suspended in space as well as drops of blood; frozen in time. You hesitated for a moment before opening the door to a sight more horrible then you predicted going up the stairs.

The concrete walls were covered in blood, swirling about the large chamber. A black haze twisted around in a spiral that nearly blinded you through your glasses. Far below, down the service ladder was a worse sight; a sea of blood seeping out from the cracks of statues in running and frightened positions from what you could tell. The sights and smells so awful you could not bare to look for too long with out the bile rising from your stomach. Holding a handkerchief to your mouth and nose you looked on more. Papers, glass, and pieces of machinery were flung to the air and suspended in space. That's when you saw it, a feint glow at the center of the room where the holding tank was. The plate carved with the letters 'SERF' hanging from loose and twitching wires.

You spared little hesitation and climbed down the stained ladder, slipping before falling into the red sea. You trudged and fell often in the knee deep and glue like entrails of what used to be people. The statues of which hung about in horrific forms, ripped apart by the force and petrified as they were the nearer you came. Terrified screams and tears ran down your face but you pressed on as the power grew stronger at the epicenter.

When you came to the edge of the holding tank, there she was. The woman who ruined your life...what was left... Her body had been ripped apart from the inside out, the pieces suspended in mid air. What was left of her face was in blissful awe as her arms were spread outward. Her eyes had melted off of her face...you couldn't look anymore...never in your life had you ever been thankful to see such horror...

You climbed the few steps to the inner tube where the golden light was it's strongest and the blood rose to the holding tanks lower machine. The glass of the tank was shattered and swirled with the blood and black. And at the center of the light...there he was...fully grown and curled in a painful and twisted form, gasping for air he didn't need to breath... He was long, well built, and covered in crimson seals of the strongest forms of runes and symbols. The blood about entered and exited his body. His own powers leaving him in seething pain as he cried scarlet tears.

"Serf!" you tried to run to him but his eyes snapped open onto you and his powers flung you to the air. You were suspended with your arms outward, his powers were pulling your limbs away. "S-Serf...I know you...gargh...you can understand me...it's me...GAAAAGGHHHH!!!" he twisted your right arm, the bone about to break through your skin. "L-gah-l-look in my Bag!" You tried to reach down to your bag but it was snatched off and thrown to the side releasing it's contents. A single small book...yours and his favorite...the first he ever read...Animals and ABCs... He saw it in the corner of his eye and all the power holding you aloft drifted away making you fall slowly to the platform in pain, "...r-remember Serf? You said...you always wanted to be a Zebra? So we put Zebra DNA into you so you could turn yourself into one?"

His crimson tears ran down in streams as he said in a small squeaking tone, "...P-pa-pa..?"

"Y-yes...Serf...it's me..." you gave him a small smile...

1331.content:
(This story will run differently as it is put in a journal form and the author is given a name. I thought it'd be a nice twist to the views of self.)
March 27, 1793

My name is Renold Johnson, heir to the Johnson Delivery business run by my father. Not necessarily rich, my father's business has kept my family and I wealthy. I live with my father and his two servants in our small manor outside of London. My mother is currently living in London with my younger sister as she goes to school.

I am writing this strange series of events that began three days ago, March 24, when I met and made the most peculiar of friends imaginable. Pardon my speech as you may not believe the words I say and consider me a mad man for saying this. But we humans are not the only people in the world we know. In the walls and floorboards, beneath the ground, and in our sewers lies a world of creatures. Specifically animals with the speech and properties of humans. A rarity in life you may never encounter. But I was perplexed and now proud to say that I have met one such creature. In my house no less!

It was late that afternoon as I returned home from the delivery chambers across town. My father is a bit cold and bitter of a man, which in some cases I am content with as it has made me the better man in the end. He has been bed ridden for a number of days. We fear his time has grown short, but he still prattles on as if he is healthy as ever. We talked over the shipments as I gave him the reasons our men could not take in in time. He gave a sigh of grief and called our workers imbeciles before shutting me out after giving instruction.

As I left and walked briskly down the hall I saw our maid set a block of cheese next to a hole in the wall. I asked her what she had been doing and she snorted out that we had gained mice, the cheese was poisoned. She called them smart little weasels. I could only dream at the time if a mouse had intelligence, even thought it an interesting idea. As she passed and this thought came to fruition I only partially noticed the scurrying of something past my feet. When I jerked my head back there was nothing but the hole and cheese.

Later that afternoon when the sun was just beginning to lower and the sky was turning it's autumn hue I had a descent dinner made by my butler. He complained that a mouse was stealing food from the pantry even though he had locked it. An incredibly large one at that. I laughed heartily at him and had to stop myself from calling him a fool. Still it was odd that all these things had gone on and I simply told him this. "Listen very carefully. If a mouse did have the process to think of a way into a locked pantry for food then he would have to think as a man. Not only this he would have to think of his own mortality like a man as well. Unlike you, our maid, and my father; I would enjoy the company of such a mouse. I may even consider him a compatriot if he had half the mind to be one, hahaha!"

Little did I know that it was these words that sparked a meeting that I would never wish to be a dream. To that end I believed it was at the time.

It was that night while I was falling asleep. Our home stood on a small hill that allowed me the view of London just over the ledge of my window. I fell asleep every night to that view when in my home, it comforted me to see all the hustle quieted by the night. As I began to doze I heard a small rustle in my dreams. A quiet but commanding voice urging at my thoughts. "Compatriot, is that what you said? If you ever met a mouse that could think like you humans, you'd be their partner? Is that the basis of what you said? Mrrrrrrrr... Johnson?"

I thought the voice only a figment of my mind and spoke outwardly, "urh...yes...yes I did say..."

"Then why don't we become partners Mr. Johnson? I have a few good ideas for your service. You seem to need the help."

I saw a glint of a figure just above my face, "yes...it is true that we do need help," I said responding very calmly to the voice.

"Would you put that in writing?" The figure held out a signing sheet much larger then himself, another holding a pen.

"Uh, yes..." I took the pen and signed the sheet.

"Good, it will be nice to work with you Renold. I can't wait to start!" The small figure shook my finger in feverish response. It was odd for a dream. I could feel the tiny man's hand.

And before i even realized it I had sat up like a bolt to a sitting position holding a tiny man that dangled from my finger. He was around eight inches in height sporting a large red cap, orange coat over a white button down shirt, brown pants with a brown bag strapped over his shoulder and a pair of small brown cloth shoes. His face was round and furry, pale white at that with large green eyes. A tail swat back and forth behind him. What broke me from my gasping gaze was his voice laughing, "Hahaha! Easy there Mr. Renold, I'm more fragile then I look."

"W-who are you?"

"I'm Thomas, Thomas Melcrus. Glad to be your partner Renold! I'm doing this as sort of a favor as well. A thank you for saving me. If it weren't for you that cheese may have killed me and my family if you hadn't said anything to the maid."

It was an experience beyond any dream my mind could imagine. A part of me could not believe and a part of me was so excited it had to believe.
