When he tried to reach over your shoulders, his wings pressed against your arms and chest, and it only took a second before he settled for reaching underneath your arms. He only held it for a moment before stepping back. "Did I do that right?"

"Do whatever feels natural for you." You smile before letting go of his shoulder. You glance around, before sitting on a nearby log and looking at him. "Anyhow... I guess we shouldn't get too distracted. What did you want to ask me?"

"R-right. I guess I got a little sidetracked." He tried to shake his worries of, his expression returning as he took a seat next to you. "There's a place that I wanted to take a look at, a couple of days from here. It's supposed to be a sealed ruin, but I think we'd probably be able to get in."

"A sealed ruin? Are you sure about that? If it's really that close, I would imagine someone else would've opened it up already.

Blit shook his head as he spoke. "It's supposed to be tricky to find and to reach. I think I could probably carry you and keep airborne for long enough to get us in."

"Airborne? You mean it'd be necessary for you to f... to glide?" You pause as you speak, hoping he didn't notice. He just shook his head and smiled.

"It's alright. Call it whatever comes naturally. But yeah, I don't think most people can even get close enough to examine it."

"You mean it's hidden? Or is there something else protecting it? Even if it's a little bit hard to find, I can't imagine it getting passed up when it's that close to a town. And I know that most people wouldn't be able to fly in or anything, but someone with some magic might manage it. How can you be sure that nobody else has gone there already?"

Blit shook his head quietly before responding. "There's no guarantee that we'll be the first ones. Still, I'm fairly confident that we'll manage something, since..."
15322112112.title: Past and Present

choices: The next day, you travel slower so Blit can practice carrying you as he glides.
The next day, you find the ruin, and Blit wants to fly you in immediately.
153221121122.content:
"Only to Krethids? How's that work out?" You jerked a little as you looked at him, uncertain how something like that could've come into existence so far from the mountains that they usually dwelled in.

"Not sure. I think it used to be an outpost or a vault or something, back when the Great War was going on." He lightly scratched at his head, a few feathers shifting about as he did. "Anyways, there's supposed to be a special lock near the entrance that ensures only Krethids could get in." You tried to think back, only bits and pieces of history falling into place as you did.

"So, it'll hold something that was used against the Ogres? Do you know what's supposed to be there?"

"That's what interests me. I heard about it a while ago, and since it's something for Krethids I can actually use, I came out to look for it." You were a little surprised as you saw his expression change, holding what you could only describe as a wide grin. "I haven't found out any details, but there's supposed to be an old amulet there, capable of enhancing a Krethid's body."

"You mean, something to make you stronger?" You raised an eyebrow as he nodded, a little surprised. "Huh. I... suppose that would work okay for you." You chuckled as you saw him turn away for a moment. "Hey, if it's something that'll give you an edge, I won't complain."

"I'm just eager to make the best of it." He seemed to hold a momentary look of longing, but quickly hid it as he gave his chest a firm pat. "My wings might not work quite as well, but every other bit of me's just fine. I might as well take advantage of that!"

"Hm. Well, if you want to take a look around there, I certainly don't mind." You stood back up, brushing the bits of bark from your pants as you did. "I'll take a couple of hours to pack, and then we can head out. That sound alright with you?"

"S-sure." He seemed a little surprised to be leaving that soon. Still, he had a wide smile as he watched you walk off. "And, Fermik... Thanks."

"Anytime, Blit." You gave him one more glance before turning away, hoping to move out soon.
__________

Blit was certainly excited this time. He was rushing faster than you could keep up with. Although he never ended up in a full run, he was always keeping ahead a fair distance, and you had to give him more than a few reminders to slow down. Even when he saw other people, he went around and tried to run ahead instead of waiting for you. Keeping up with him was tiring, but you didn't want to dampen his enthusiasm.

But at a certain point, you didn't have too much choice. Even after the sun had set, he was still trying to race ahead, and you had to keep your grip on his arm just to not risk losing him in the darkness. Although you had done your best to keep up, the trek had been tiring, and you needed a chance to rest.

"Easy, Blit..." Your breathing was a little hard, even as you tried to keep marching forward with him in your grasp. "We need to take some rest. This isn't something you want to try while you're exhausted."

"I'm okay, though! I can still go for another few hours, and you're... You're...” He paused as he looked at you for a moment. “You're... right. Sorry..." His face had dropped when he paused, your fatigue a little clearer when he stopped to look. "I forgot I tend to go a little fast...”

"It's okay... Come on, let's try and find a place to set up camp." You gently pulled up your sack, scouting through the area. Although the space was pretty open, it didn't seem like there would be a problem, without any sign of life as far as you or Blit could see. It didn't take too long for you to set up a campfire, and since there weren't any trees around, Blit ended up laying on the ground near you.

Dinner was a quiet affair. It would be difficult to try to hunt in the night, and though Blit had wanted to, you had managed to get him to settle for a few pieces of fruit. Although you had finished rather quickly and tucked yourself into your bedroll quickly, Blit was still awake, his eyes gazing at the fire as he ate.

You gave a loud yawn and felt yourself drifting off when you heard Blit's voice coming from beside you. "Hey, Fermik... Are you still awake?"

"Barely..." You turn over a little, your eyes half-closed as you looked at him. "What's up?"

"I'm sorry for the long walk. It's really one of the few times that I've ever really... Been in charge, I guess. Most times, when I was with other Krethids, my wings dragged me down a lot. I could only do a few things most others could do, and people had to manage around that."

"Blit, you've already apologized for that. Once is enough, you know." You manage a weak smile, your eyes slipping closed as your mouth shifts into it.

"Yeah, I know that. But I don't want to risk messing this up. Most times, other people didn't want to risk letting me plan things out. I mean, I can be a little scatter-minded at times, and I can forget to take flight into mind when things happen. So, if I act foolish, or ignorant, or-"

"Bird-brained?" You grinned a bit, unable to resist the comment. He seemed caught off-guard for it, and fell into a momentary huff.

"Trying to be serious, here! No need to say something like that!"

"I know." You just smiled as you turned onto your back, a few bits of starlight managing to sneak between your eyelids as you spoke. "And I understand, Blit. I'll be the first to let you know if something's off. So don't doubt yourself and don't worry, okay? You were excited about this entire thing, and if I wasn't able to keep up, I would've told you earlier. As long as you keep an eye on me, I'll let you know if there's something you don't notice." You just gave a quiet little sigh as you shifted in. "It's funny, though... I thought you were a lot more experienced than me, but... I guess we've both still got a lot of learning to do, don't we? Still... I'll watch your back if you're around to watch mine. And if I ever need your help, I'll ask, so let me know if you ever need a hand, okay? Even if we're learning, I think we can manage it all together."

You felt his beak nudge in, but your eyes didn't even open this time. It was a moment before he pulled away, and though he still had a bit of worry in his tone, he seemed a bit more relaxed. "Yeah... I guess we can. Thanks, Fermik. I'm glad that..."

You were fast asleep before he had the chance to say anything else.
153221121122.title: Traveling

choices: The place is sealed, but Blit figures out how to open it.
The entrance was forced open, and you see some unsavory people there already.
1532211211222.content:
You weren't sure how Blit had managed it, but despite sleeping later than you, he already had breakfast ready and waiting when you woke. Or, at least, he had tried to have it ready. Although he had managed to catch and skin a couple of rabbits, his attempt at cooking one had left the thing an uneven, burnt mess. He was already eating it when you woke, although there was a slightly pained expression on his face as he tried to nibble it down.

"Morning, Blit. You... need practice cooking, I take it?"

He seemed a little ashamed, his head hanging down as he chewed. "Since most Krethids eat food raw, few of them see the point in cooking, so it's never really taught." He took another bite, an odd crunching coming from his mouth as he chewed. "I've watched you do it a couple of times, so I thought I could manage, but..."

"I get the picture." You just nodded your head as you took the rabbit still remaining. Even if he had trouble cooking, he had done a good job of skinning and cleaning it. "We can split this one, then. I've brought more than enough food for the entire trip, so I don't mind."

You could see Blit's eyes sparkling as he swallowed, nodding eagerly before he stood up. He seemed to stretch his arms and wings as he waited, but you could tell that he would probably jump at the food the moment you were done. Although he waited patiently when you pulled the meat from the flame and split off a large chunk for him, the moment your voice sounded, he was right next to you. "It's rea-"

He had already taken it from you and was happily eating before you had time to finish speaking. It looked as though the burnt bit he was eating had been left aside, forgotten in the dirt as he happily chowed down.

"Gheeze, Blit. Is it really that good for you?" You chuckled as you quietly pulled a piece off for yourself, nibbling contentedly. Blit only gave an eager nod, his mouth too preoccupied to speak. It took a matter of minutes before he had finished, and while he watched you eat when he was done, he seemed contented.

"About ready to go, then? I think we can probably make it before nightfall if we hurry." He carefully began cleaning up as you finished, taking a bit of time not to damage anything as he worked on your bedroll. You gave a nod as you stood up, a leftover piece still in your mouth as you finished. It wasn't long before the two of you set off again.

The travel today seemed a little lighter. Although Blit was still eagerly moving around, he kept a close eye on you, and did his best to regulate his pace so you could keep up. It didn't stop him from rushing ahead every few minutes or so, but he usually managed to catch himself in time to wait for you, without forcing you to constantly dash after him.

Even with that, you had made good time. Although he had estimated a couple of days, you had arrived in the general area after lunch. Blit was eager to make use of the extra time, and while he had asked you to set up camp and rest, he had spent a couple of hours scouring the area and searching for the ruin.

You had finished a snack when you had heard a loud, brief chirping, followed by an echoing caw from a distance away. You jumped up automatically, rushing towards it. While there were normal birds around, you had spent enough time with Blit to distinguish his voice. It was tough to do so, but you could usually manage to figure it out.

"Blit? Is something wrong?" You could see him standing near the edge of a cliff. He seemed to be looking forwards, a raised ledge a fair distance away. Although there was an unusual amount of brush over it, you couldn't make out anything through the distance. "Is... is that it?"

He gave a quick nod, shifting a little bit. "It's definitely there. It might be hard to get there while holding onto you, but I'll do my best." You swallowed at the suggestion, but nodded. The distance was a couple hundred feet away, and while you were fairly sure Blit could make the distance, the platform was still hanging in the air, and a rocky shelf was near the base of it. It was a nearly impossible climb, but if he couldn't land well, it would end up badly for the two of you.

"Are you sure you can carry me?" You swallow as you pulled your bag in over your arm. Most of the heavier things were already unpacked at your campsite, but you weren't exactly the lightest person around. However, you felt him moving close, turning his back to you and motioning as he nodded.

"Think so. Just hold on tight against my shoulders, and be careful not to grab my wings. I should be able to fly like that." You swallowed, but nodded. Even if you could land safely, getting back up would take another hour, and you had at least tested a short flight once. Swallowing your concerns, you move in close, carefully shifting yourself onto his body and holding tight. He seemed a little unsteady, and his hands were unable to help keep you balanced.

Unable to even jump, he moved forward, doing his best to pick up speed with you tight against his body. You had to suppress the urge to shout as you felt the wind suddenly blasting against your face, almost falling into a dive the moment he launched himself off the cliff.

The wind kept pressing into your head and shoulders as he fell, and kept pounding in even as his position stabilized. He managed to pick up enough speed and steady himself, his eyes almost closed but looking ahead as he pulled up a bit, smoothing out his flight. His speed seemed to slow, and you finally managed to breathe a little when you saw the steady motion forward he had.

Things seemed a little easier when you saw the ground close in under you. You had managed to get to the shelf with plenty of room to spare, and as you felt his wings flap, you thought you had managed it. He was slowing down a little, and as the ground approached, it looked like the two of you had arrived without a problem.

"Ow! H-heavy..."

At least, up until the landing.

Although he had managed to slow himself down and land on his talons, he clearly wasn't used to carrying a passenger. He had tried to ease into his descent too late, and although it wasn't enough to cause any serious injury, he had been caught off-balance and fell onto the ground with you on his back. You were still clinging tight against him as you tried to recover your breath, and it took a few seconds before you let go, sliding into the ground.

"What are you looking so nervous for? I told you I could make it!" Blit managed to pick himself off the ground and brush himself off. Although he had a few feathers dis-shelved, he seemed to be in one piece. Your breathing was slowly returning to normal, and you shook your head, trying to shake the worry off.

"That dive really threw me off... I thought we were going to crash!" You shifted, pulling your bag firmly against your shoulder as you spoke. "We almost did, too... Your landing was pretty rough..."

"You don't have to tell me twice..." He winced a little as he brushed himself off, a couple of slight scrapes on his knees. "I've never really carried anything like the weight of another person. I think I can fly okay, but I need to work on a smoother landing..." He winced a little before standing back up. "Still, it's nothing major... We've gotten here in one piece, and we can check the place out!"

You just give him a small smile as you tried to pick yourself up. Even after your rough flight, he was still in a good mood. You followed as he started to move in through the bit of cover that remained, unwilling to bring Blit down from his cheerful state.
1532211211222.title: Drifting to the Destination

choices: "There's a supply room, but there are only a few things left in it."
"There seems to be a vault, but it's trapped."
15322112112221.content:
It took you a short while before you were back onto your feet and capable of moving without a bit of stinging. Still, soon enough, the two of you were both up and around again. Blit quickly took charge again, pushing through the dense brush that still remained between him and his destination. By now, it was clear that his eagerness had overtaken any soreness that he had felt, and he was easily moving and glancing around for his destination. It only took you a few minutes before you found out that Blit's information was good. As you approached, you started to see fewer and fewer trees and brush. The area slowly but surely cleared out, and as you got a view of the place, you gasped a little. You had finally arrived, but what you saw was a surprise to you.

The building there wasn't as tall as the trees, but it stood steady a rather firm bunker a couple of stories ahead. However, its construction was somehow built into the surrounding trees. It seemed as though the wood of the building almost blended in with the taller trees in the area, several supporting the main structure and more than a few trees almost piercing straight through the center of it, the canopy of the trees covering the structure from view. It seemed as though the trees were much thicker than normal, with the branches in between one another connecting and weaving in through each other, forming a nearly complete ceiling over the space.

"That's... a lot bigger than I thought a ruin would be." You swallowed as you tried to get a better view of it all, walking forwards with Blit. "How is a wooden building still up for that long?"

"I think they actually imported some trees for the base, and then had one of our allies work on the construction. The building's part of the tree, so it can stay in good shape as long as the trees are healthy." Blit walked forward steadily, only focused on looking for an entrance near ground level. "I've seen a few buildings like it back home, but they're mostly for travelers. The terrain isn't really suited for something like this."

"Okay, then... What are you looking for?"

"I'm trying to figure out where the main door is, as well as where the... Aha!" He paused as he turned up, pausing at an archway four or five feet up in the air. There were barely a few inches in front of it that you could climb, but it was clear that it had been designed for fliers. A sealed door seemed to be right in front, several foreign marks clawed out of the wood and a single crack running down the middle where it would open."

"Is this it? It doesn't have a handle or anything. How is it supposed to open?"

"By voice. During the war, it was the easiest way to check if the person opening it was a Krethid or someone accompanied by a Krethid. It could be faked, of course, but for outposts like this, it was enough." He tried to cling on against the ledge, his talons managing to slide against the wood. Even as he tried to squeeze, he had trouble making a good scratch for him to cling to. "Sturdy stuff. Could you give me a boost?"

You nodded as you moved in, bending a little as you moved in. "So, should I try to raise you by your feet... talons... whatever?"

"Yeah. Try to get a good grip." You shifted and put your hands in place before you felt him stepping on, careful not to pierce you as he moved. You quickly tried to push him up, and with a bit of effort, he managed to climb onto the ledge, clinging firm against the door as he took a look."

"Hm..." You watched with curiosity, but his thoughts seemed to quickly drift from your comprehension. Even as he muttered to himself, you could hear a quiet chirping and clicking. You couldn't tell if he was just talking to himself, or if he was trying passwords, or even if he was just blabbering on. All you could do was wait for a few minutes before you suddenly heard the door shift open, sliding back and brushing up dust.

"I got it! Come on up!" You could see Blit's head leaning down from the entrance, his arm reached down to try to extend his grasp to you. You reached up to grab at him, and while it took a couple of minutes, you eventually managed to climb up using his arm and the wall in front of you.

There was a lot more room now that the doorway had opened. There seemed to be a long hallway in front, with multiple doorways leading around to various rooms. However, you couldn't get a very good view through the few cracks of light that seemed to scatter from the ceiling. Despite the roof that the tree branches provided, it seemed as though the floor and ceiling here were both at least partially manufactured.

"Wha'd you do to get it open?" You were a bit curious as you stepped in, trying to stand back up. Blit had an eager expression on his face as he looked behind you, watching the door.

"Tried a few of the common passwords. Most of the war ones are pretty straightforward. The one that did it was something like, 'For the good of all, I shall guard this place as my home.' A little stuffy, but I can see why they'd pick something like that." He seemed to be a little jumpy, his enthusiasm clearly taking over as he held on against your hand. The door behind you seemed to slide closed a moment after, making you swallow as the darkness surrounded you. There were a few dim beams of light, but the darkness seemed complete. "So? Can we look around?" Blit seemed to remain eager, the darkness not enough to make him pause for a single moment.

"Hang on, let me get a better light." You sighed and closed your eyes, muttering to yourself under your breath. While you had a lantern in your pack, trying to get it lit seemed like it could be a bit of an affair in the near-darkness. It was much simpler for you to mutter something, a small orb of light appearing in your palm. You touched your fingers to Blit's side, before the seemed to emanate from him. "That should be enough..."

"Wow, cool... I thought magic wasn't supposed to go through our feathers very easily, though. How'd you manage that?"

"Making a light is pretty basic, so it's not too hard to mess around with it and do fancier things. I tried to tweak it a little so it sort of surrounded you. Basically, it's like you're wearing it like a piece of clothing. As long as magic doesn't really have to go through your feathers, it works... well, reasonably well, at any case. It's the same idea behind the bow, too."

"Never knew you could do things like that with it. Magic isn't studied too much back home." He smiled as he tried to move, taking a couple of steps around and testing it, the light moving and shifting with him, though his limbs would often end up casting a shadow on the walls. "Is this enough light for you as well?"

"Yeah. We should stick together while we take a look. So, go ahead." You smiled as you followed close by, watching as he quickly darted into the closest room.

As you explored, it soon became clear that the place had been designed as a small bunker for a variety of different creatures. There were a few areas that were tricky for you to identify, but it was easy enough for you to find a training area, a small kitchen, and a sleeping space. It seemed as though it had been designed to support a variety of creatures, though it was still clear that Krethids were first in mind. There were even a few rooms that had numerous branches and fallen leaves scattered about. Although you weren't quite sure as to the purpose of every space, Blit seemed to acknowledge the rooms one by one, sticking his head in and looking for a couple of minutes, but never spending the time to do any more than a cursory search.

However, that eventually changed when he stopped, pointing at a trapdoor in the ceiling.

"That has to be it!" He gave a firm jump and managed a slight flap, pounding at the door and feeling it slip open before slamming back down. "That's the only place that's tougher for non-fliers, which means it has to hold the storage for Krethids! Fermik, give me another hand here!"

He nearly dragged you with him when he spotted the hatch, and it didn't take too long before he was trying to climb up again. It was difficult to keep him up on your hands when he was doing his best to push the door open, but you managed it. With a bit of a boost, he managed to climb all the way up. Then, for a couple of minutes, you could only hear the sound of his talons clicking against the wooden ceiling above you. However, this time, you couldn't wait quietly.

"Hey! Blit! Everything okay up there?"

His footsteps paused for a moment, followed by the sound of what seemed to be a loud thump. You heard a rather clear "Ow!" from above, but only a moment after, his head soon pushed down from the ceiling. "Y-yeah... Sort of..." He seemed a little off as he spoke, looking down at you. "There's definitely something up here, but..."

"But?"
15322112112221.title: Exploring the Past

choices: He grabs one and immediately begins messing with it.
The pedestal is trapped and destroys all of the medallions when he gets there.
153221121122212.content:
He swallowed again before giving you the news. "There seems to be a vault, but it's well trapped. I... Uh... I kind of figured that out the hard way..."

"Blit, please tell me you aren't injured."

"No, no! I'm okay. Got a bit of a bump, but I'm okay. It was just an odd tree branch or something." He swallowed as he looked at you. "But... But I'm fairly sure that it wasn't natural, so... so there's more than just one trap."

"Can you get me up, then? I want to take a look, too."

“Sure. Just... just be careful, alright?" Both of his arms reached down to grab at you, pulling with an effort. It was difficult for you to reach him, and even when you managed to get a grip on the entryway, you had trouble pulling yourself up.

If there was a vault, it certainly didn't look like it at first glance. The nearby branches and the slight bristle in the leaves seemed to indicate that you were higher up in the trees. Their branches were thick enough to effectively form a ceiling right above your heads, and the two of you both had to crouch just to keep from bumping into it. There were traces of a large scratch in the ground, a tree branch cleanly cut from the trunk of the tree as it lied nearby.

"So that almost hit you?"

"Yeah... I think I tripped a wire or something. It didn't hit me directly, but I bumped my head into the ceiling when I saw it passing by. I'm surprised the trap held after so long..."

"Let me take a closer look, then." You shifted and bumped your head against the ceiling as you stepped forwards, looking at the remains of the branches. You followed it quietly, letting your fingertips brush over it before getting a grip on something. And as you moved, you could see another wooden door at the other end of the room.

"Yeah... I think it's string. I can't see how they'd set up any other types of traps here, though... I don't think there's enough room for anything more mechanically complex. There are probably more traps on the way to the door, though. As long as we find all of the strings, I can probably trip the traps before we get close enough to be in danger. It's a messy way to do it, but it should work."

"Right... Let me try to look, then. If I'm keeping my eyes open, I'm sure I can manage it."

Progress was slow. Even though there was only 100 feet between you and another doorway, the two of you both had to step forward slowly, taking minutes at a time just to be sure you could safely move ten feet. Each time you found a new wire, you would do your best to use a bit of string to get a good distance before tugging and tensing, watching a new branch crash from above you. It was amazing that despite the half-dozen branches that had fell, the ceiling seemed to still remain intact, only small cracks forming in it. It was easily half an hour before you had managed to reach the doorway, but you had done so with nothing more than a couple of scratches from trying to dig through the fallen branches in the cramped space.

"We made it... Do you think this door's got the same type of lock as the front door?"

"Probably. If this space is just for Krethids, then it'll have another lock that's tougher for people to open." He swallowed as he walked up to it again, testing it with a push.

"It looks like it's got the same scratches, as the front door, too... I guess they'd use a different passcode, though."

He nodded, and surprised you when he responded with a bit of chirping. It only took you a few seconds to understand what was going on again as he tested a few words. However, more surprising was the fact that it only took him half a minute before you could hear the door grinding open. A look of wonder appeared on his face as he watched the door move.

"What... What was it?"

He swallowed as he looked in, his eyes gazing upon the prize as he spoke quietly. "Grant me the strength to protect the ones next to me."

The prize in front of him certainly seemed like it had been for such. The room inside was formed into a small dome, with numerous interlocking branches and vines forming the domed roof around it. The light coming from Blit's body seemed to illuminate the entire room as he walked in. Numerous weapons seemed to be strewn about the room, most of it slightly worn with age. A few things looked to be in usable condition, scattered among the shelves and racks in the room. However, despite all of the potential treasures you had found, Blit's eyes were focused on one side of the room. A simple pedestal seemed to have a small pile of medallions on top. There were no strings or straps visible upon them, and they seemed to have been shaped into a variety of different birds. However, Blit quickly dashed towards the shelf.

"That has to be it!" He was nearly jumping for joy as he approached it, his goal well within his grasp.
153221121122212.title: Simple Traps

choices: Blit takes a while to heal, but he eventually wants to settle in at the bunker.
Blit heals fairly quickly, and the two of you leave soon after.
1532211211222122.content:
The pedestal was only a short distance away, and he was happy to quickly approach it. It seemed like the temptation was extremely distracting for him as he moved in closer. Although you could barely notice it, by the time he had gotten within a few feet of the pedestal, there was an audible "click" from nearby.

"Blit! Watch-"

You didn't even have time to finish your warning. A large, dense bundle of branches and stones had crashed through the ceiling, smashing directly into the pedestal. The amulets were shattered into pieces, the pedestal following soon after. Blit was caught in the scattered debris, automatically raising his arms and wings, splinters and shards of wood catching through his feathers.

You rushed forward the moment that you saw it. There was simply no time to act, and Blit had fallen backwards onto the floor. "Blit! Are you alright?"

He only managed a small moan as he lay there, shifting himself up. He had several deep gashes over his arms and sides, and numerous fragments had managed to dig in against his feathers. "O-ow..."

" You're not in any condition to move." You grunted as you reached into your bag, digging through. "Damn it... I've only got a couple..." You dig through your pack for the two healing potions you had managed to afford, and tipped both of them into his mouth. Although the major gashes on his body lessened, he was still dripping blood in places.

You reached in for some bandages and tried to tend to his remaining wounds the best you could. Although he wasn't losing too much blood, there were simply too many pieces of wood. You did your best to get all of his wounds dressed, but he looked like a mess even before you had finished.

He was silent as you worked, and though his eyes were closed, his pulse and breathing both seemed to steady. He didn't seem to be in any danger of dying, but he certainly wasn't in any condition to be moving around. It took a while before you had finished patching him up, and you had his arms, wings and chest in a large sling. Thankfully, he had managed to cover his head when it all happened.

You didn't know what you could do but wait for him to wake. Although the ground here was a little rough, you weren't going to move him on your own. You laid your bag under his head so he could rest upon it. All you could do was try to keep him his wounds clean and try to keep him comfortable.

It was hours before he woke up. You saw him shifting around, but tried to hold his shoulders. It was difficult to avoid the scrapes he had along them, but you held him carefully.

"Keep still, Blit. You were injured pretty badly, and I don't have the supplies for any better treatment."

He gave a small cough, his arm trying to hold his chest as he did. However, with all of the bandages on, he could barely move. "Fermik? That you?"

"Yeah... It's me. You feeling any better?"

He managed shook his head quietly as he sighed. "I took a few dozen pieces of wood all over my front. I don't see how I'm going to be-"

"Blit." You spoke with a serious tone, causing him to stop. He slowly turned his head towards you, looking quietly. "Just rest, okay? This type of lifestyle has risks. I know it, and you know it. But as long as you're still alive, you can always patch yourself up and try again."

He sighed as he nodded, his eyes sliding closed again. "I know... I just... I'm disappointed. We had gotten so close, and then I just had to go and mess up right when my goal was in reach. I... I wanted to be able to do more. This was my first time, and it ended up just being a huge mess."

You sighed quietly as you carefully lifted his hand, holding against it. "There'll be other chances. We've got plenty of opportunities to explore the place, and even if you didn't get an amulet, there's probably plenty of other equipment here that you could use. Don't worry, okay?"

"I'll... try not to." He sighed quietly as he tried to get up. You held him steadily, but didn't really try to keep him still. This was hardly the best place for him to be resting.

"Come on, let's get you back downstairs. I think you're stable enough to move right now. It may not be a normal sleeping spot for you, but I'd like to get you into a bed so you can rest properly."

He sighed and nodded as he carefully leaned into you. The two of you moved slowly and carefully as you tried to get Blit back down onto the main floor. It was an effort to try to move down and somehow catch him gently, but you managed it with a little bit of magic and a fair amount of rope.

"Hey, Fermik?" You head Blit's voice as you finally reached the living quarters, gently laying him down on a bed. He seemed a little awkward as he sunk back in to the only bed with fabric remaining. "Thanks. If you weren't here, I'd be a whole lot worse off right now."

"I'm not about to abandon you, Blit." You chuckled as you carefully let go, sitting next to him. "Even if you're injured, I'd rather stick with you."

He gave a small chuckle as he looked at you, nodding softly. "Lucky me... I didn't think that I'd end up getting this much help from a human."

You shook your head, before leaning in, giving him a gentle nudge. "Hey, don't lump all humans together."

"I don't. At least... I don't think I can lump you in with the rest of them." He gave another small smile before closing his eyes and drifting off again."
1532211211222122.title: Lost Chance

choices: "If you're staying, then I'm staying with you."
"I'll come pick you up before every job."
15322112112221221.content:
Waiting around didn't sit well with either of you, but you didn't have much of a choice. Blit's injuries didn't seem life-threatening, but he certainly wasn't in any condition to move on his own. It was days before he was ready to try walking again, and he still couldn't push himself too hard after what had happened.

So, you did your best to take care of him. There wasn't too much else you could do. Even so, he seemed to be reasonably cheerful, despite his injuries. Though Blit was confined to bed rest, the two of you were comfortable. You managed to clean up enough that you could use one of the other beds, and you found enough spare tools in storage to survive with. Most of the first day just involved you trying to strain your voice to imitate the noises necessary to open the doors, but by the evening, you were able to leave the ruin on your own, even if you couldn't go far.

It was a good thing, too. You were running low on food, and there wasn't any way you could leave the shelf you were on without Blit to help bring you down. You couldn't find any animals within the nearby forest, and the height of your location prevented you from leaving without Blit's help. All you could do was try to gather a few fruits from the forest and hope it would be enough.

His appetite actually seemed to have ramped up a little bit. Although he was injured, he happily ate whatever you found, and you had to cut back a little on your own food. It seemed a little odd, but you weren't going to argue with him too much when he was injured, and it didn't seem to be harming his recovery.

In the end, it was another few days of rest. While you had gone on jobs together, it was the first time that the two of you had spent time together off the job. Although the two of you were always quite casual when you were talking, Blit was usually off in a tree, or frequently dashing off to hide. It was the first time that you two really had a chance for a long, unbroken conversation.
__________

"Aw, come on. It's been four days! Even if I'm not completely healed, I can move without bleeding or injuring myself!"

Blit was sitting in the bed, the sheets tosses over his legs. They had numerous scratches and tears from Blit's use, but they had been intact enough to keep him warm. However, it seemed as though just tucking in was uncomfortable for him.

"Look, I don't want you pushing yourself. I don't know exactly how long it takes for you to fully recover, but until then, you should-"

"Fermik, as much as I might like this place, I've had enough of this room." He gave his wings a flap and bent his arms around, trying to stretch out a bit. "If I stay here any longer, then I'm going to go stir-crazy. I mean, the place is nice to stay in and all. But I can only stare at the inside of a room for so long."

"Fine, fine... You can go outside... Just take it slow, okay?" You sighed as you picked helped him onto his feet. Despite the scratches and bruises that still remained, he seemed to be in good condition. His body hadn't deteriorated during his time off, and he even seemed to be able to stand and walk without too much help. Still, you weren't about to let him off on his own.

He opened the front door for the two of you, and took a bit of time to just walk through the forest nearby. Although you didn't spot anything, he was apparently able to see a few animals, and found a good deal more fruit than you did when you were looking.

"Hehe... Place actually looks liveable."

"Liveable?" You turned a little as you held Blit in, watching as he quickly downed a piece of fruit.

"Yeah... I mean, it's a bit hard to catch, but I can spot enough wildlife here. I'd probably be able to survive if I'm stuck here. "

"Stuck here? Why? Once you recover, you can go down, and..." You paused, turning to look at him. "Blit... This is... about you going home?"

He seemed to hesitate when you spoke, and he seemed quiet for a moment. However, he seemed to nod to you as he looked up. "Yeah... I'm not going to be able to go back anytime soon, so I figured I might as well make this place my home for now." He had a small smile on his face, but it quickly changed when he saw your worried expression.

“You... You can't go back? What do you mean?”

Blit gave a small sigh, turning to look at you quietly. “You know that I came here to look around at this building, right?"

"Yeah... I never really understood why you came to primarily human lands. I mean... In the beginning, I thought it was just best for you to get into town fast. But after... I guess I never really wanted to bring it up."

"I left the mountains months ago to look for this place. I was hoping I'd be able to find this old bunker and head back quickly." He seemed a little depressed as he spoke, quietly shaking his head. "But... things came up. I had asked someone for help to drop me off and pick me up when I was done, but my capture..."

"It messed things up a bit, huh..."

Blit nodded softly, staring into the ground. "The entire trip was only supposed to take a month. I was supposed to get dropped off, explore the place, and then head back. I had to pay someone to make the long journey close to here, and they were supposed to pick me up in the same place a month later. But... I missed that chance.” He quietly sicked at a stone on the ground, watching it roll forwards as he stood there. “I was in a cage when he was supposed to pick me up, and I doubt that Lenken is the kind of guy who'd wait a day for me, never mind a few months. So, unless another willing Krethid shows up, I'm stuck here."

"I... I see..." You gently leaned in, carefully wrapping your arms around his shoulders as you hugged him gently. He seemed to relax a little in your grip. "I... I hope I can make things easier for you..."

"You've already done a lot." You could feel his beak lightly pushing against you, poking softly. "I mean... You helped me get free in the first place. And then, you tried to check on me after. That's more than some people would... Not to mention letting me join you in adventuring. Even if your job... Heck, even if everything's been dangerous... It's been a good time for me." He sighed a little as he returned the hug, wincing slightly but determined to hold you tight. "And... And you came here to help me... I think my family's the only one who's gone out of their way to do that... So... Thanks."

You slowly let go, your face brushing against his before you settled down. "Blit... Don't worry about it, okay? That's what friends do." You let go slowly, letting your hand slide down and off his body.

"Yeah, but... Thanks. I'd still be stuck in a cage if you didn't come. And now, instead... Even if I'm a little beaten up, I've found a place that I can stay."

"So, you're really going to try to live here?" You were a little surprised to hear it come up. You had assumed that he would've returned to town with you and picked out another spot in the trees.

"Yeah. It's not a bad place, and there's a much lower chance that other humans will spot me here. There are plenty of animals nearby, and I can always head out and come back if food gets sparse or something. But... I know it might be a little far away, and that'd make it tough for you, so... So I underst-"

"Stop, okay?" You gave him a light bop on his forehead, just enough to nudge him backwards a little. "I told you already, I'd much rather keep doing this with you. And from the sounds of it, you don't want to give up the jobs we've been getting. I know it's further away now, with the couple of days of travel to town and all. And if you think this place works for you, I sure won't argue. So..."
15322112112221221.title: New Home

choices: Blit seems distracted outside of work
You have trouble earning enough
153221121122212211.content:
"If you're staying, then I'm staying with you." You were afraid that you would have trouble making the suggestion, but the words came out quite easily. Blit was startled by your words, but you managed a small smile as you spoke. “Come on, Blit. I'm not going to leave you alone out here. You're going to be here a while, right? It wouldn't be right if I just left you alone.”

“W-what? I couldn't ask you to...” Blit seemed a bit taken aback by the suggestion. He certainly seemed startled, but he didn't seem to be against the idea.

“Relax. Remember, I'm only just starting as an adventurer. I don't have many things keeping me in town.” You just gently let your hand pat his shoulder a couple of times. “Besides... We're partners, aren't we? It'd be bad if I had trouble getting in contact with you.”

“But... Getting jobs... You'd need to go to town for that, right? It's fairly far away, and you'd have to make that trip every time... Not to mention the fact that you wouldn't even be able to travel without me...” He shifted a little awkward, his gaze falling down to the ground and his hands clenched a little as he spoke.

“I don't mind the walk. I mean, we might have to take jobs that are a little tougher, but I'm sure we can manage it. After all, we've been doing extremely well lately.” You just give him another pat as he stares a bit. “I mean, we've got enough cash to spare. The walk might be a bit much, but I don't think that it's bad enough. And even if it gets too bad, there's enough fruit and enough animals to hunt, right? I'm sure I'll manage okay. Besides...” You give him a gentle squeeze, his eyes moving up to meet yours.

“Normally, yes... But during the colder seasons, it might-”

“Blit. Calm down, okay?” You just shake your head a bit, keeping your grip firm against him to try to comfort him. “I might not be the best off, but I'm sure we'll make it.” You manage to say everything with a calm face, holding him firmly as you spoke.

Quite frankly, you weren't sure. You were well aware that plenty of adventurers had trouble supporting themselves once they had moved a bit further away from the central job hubs. However, it was a risk that you were willing to take, and you didn't want Blit to be the one worrying about your decisions. If things went badly, then you'd take responsibility.

“You're... You're sure?” His grin was quite obvious now, and seeing it removed all hesitation from you. He stepped forward, wincing a little, but his arms wrapped tight against you as held you in his arms. “Thanks, Fermik...”

“It's' not a problem, Blit. You're my partner, right? I have to make sure that we can manage it all together.”

“I.. I am?” He seemed to shift a little bit, his grip against you releasing as he looked at you. He seemed a little surprised at the idea. However, it only took him a moment to accept it, a clear smile appearing on his face.

“Yeah. So just relax, okay? We'll give it a couple more days before we try to find another job. In the meantime... Well, I'm not going anywhere.”

“Thanks...” He just smiled for a moment before slumping over a bit, his body stumbling forward into yours. You barely manage to catch him, but manage to get a hold on him before he fell to the ground.

“Blit... You okay?”

“Just... A little tired...” He managed to push himself back onto his feet, but you kept your hands against him to try to keep him steady.

“I told you before, you don't have to push yourself. It'd be much better if you were healthy before we tried anything else. I wouldn't want you to push yourself too far and up getting yourself killed...”

He sighed a bit, but nodded as he stood back up, beginning to walk back to the shelter. “Yeah... I guess I can't...”

“We can consider leaving here for a job when you can fly again. Until then, just take it easy, alright?”

“A-alright... Thanks, Fermik.” You just slowly help guide him back inside.

It would be a few more days before he would be in any condition to travel. However, by that time, he was able to move and fight without worries. The two of you could finally leave the ledge that you were stuck upon, and you were eager to get back to work.

The trip back to town was actually quite uneventful. It took a little longer than you would've thought, since you tried to take it at an easy pace. However, Blit didn't seem to want to rest, and you actually had to force him to take it easy whenever night fell.

By the time you arrived, it was clear that his injuries wouldn't be any problem. To try to make up for all of the lost time, you accepted a few jobs that wouldn't require too much travel. Three days and four jobs had gone by, and while it was clear that Blit was still doing fine physically, there was something else posing a problem for the two of you.
153221121122212211.title: Sticking With Him

choices: You decide to try a riskier job.
Blit isn't sleeping much and is constantly busy during the nights.
1532211211222122112.content:
Settling in to the new place was a bit of an experience. You only had a few things from home that you wanted to take, and you only needed a couple of trips to bring everything. So, while the two of you were in town, you simply picked up what you could, do whichever jobs you could find, and then haul a few of your things back to base. It was a bit inconvenient, and after the first couple of trips, you were quickly deciding to look into a faster means of transportation. Still, you were quickly settling back into the swing of things.

You weren't exactly doing too badly in terms of work. You were worried about Blit the first few days, but he didn't seem to have any issues traveling. He seemed able to keep pace with you without any issues, and his appetite was quite healthy whenever you stopped for food. He had practiced his archery by hunting for whatever he could along the way, and by the time the two of you saw any combat again, you had no problems with letting him watch your back.

In fact, by now, you didn't have any issues clearing out small camps of bandits or raiders. Somehow, your tactics had shifted to letting Blit take care of most of the enemies, and making sure to keep him safe from their range. You had to admit that you were a bit disappointed with the idea of letting him do most of the heavy lifting, and you never seemed to get too much practice with your blade. But it worked, and it the two of you safe. Blit was glad that he was able to do that much, and you weren't going to complain about it.

However, it was quickly becoming clear that you weren't earning enough. Although you were earning the same amount that you had been, Blit's appetite had sharply spiked ever since the two of you had resumed adventuring. He had never asked for any more food, but the sound of his stomach constantly punctuated your travels. By the first night out, you had picked up on the hint, and given him twice what he was eating before. That seemed to be enough to keep him satisfied for the week, but you couldn't help noticing him looking a little disappointed whenever he finished a meal.

By the day you were returning back to the base, it has become a little worrisome. Blit was easily eating through three times his meals, and there wasn't any way to avoid bringing it up anymore. Most of your budget had gone into buying food, and he knew the reason you were hauling back a heavier pack and a second bag in your arms. The walk back to the base was slower this time, and after a few minutes of awkward silence, Blit finally spoke.

"Are you sure it's okay to get this much food, Fermik? I mean, I can go without that much... I don't want to be a burden on you, and if it costs too much, I can cut back some."

"Hey, we're only going to be able to keep up the pace if the two of us stay in good condition. Part of that's getting enough to eat. I'd rather spend a little more on food than have your stomach distracting you in the middle of a fight." You turned to look at him while you walked, and his downtrodden expression made you pause. "Blit, really. It's fine. Honestly, I was more worried that I'd have to take a job on my own if you needed more time to recover. You might be able to travel and fight and everything, but that doesn't mean you're at a hundred precent right now. I want to be sure that my partner's in good shape, after all." You smile and reach your free hand to his arm, holding it lightly. "Besides, if you want to get stronger, then you'll have to eat a bit more, won't you?"

Blit's gaze suddenly turned from you to the ground. You let out a chuckle and gave his back a pat while the two of you walked, his embarassment a bit obvious this time. Even as he spoke, his eyes didn't pull back up. "Y-yeah... The amulets are gone, but-"

"But there are other ways of getting stronger. If you're really that eager, then do some exercise. And if you're going to worry that much about the trip, then just help me haul some of this stuff." You just give him a prod with one of the bags you were carrying.

Blit finally broke into a smile as he took one of the bags from you, nodding as he held it. "Yeah... I'm lucky enough to still be alive after that trap, so I can't complain. Besides, you'll s-still help me when the next chance comes... right?" He stammered momentarily as he spoke, sounding like he was asking for your help again. But you just gave a quick nod to him, your hand gently pushing his head back up so you can see eye-to-eye.

"Of course. We're in this together."
1532211211222122112.title: Adjusting

choices: “I’ve been thinking about the amulets.”
“I’ve been thinking about you.”
15322112112221221122.content:
Blit was barely ever sleeping, only ever getting a few hours of sleep a night. What he did during that time, you weren’t sure. He was clearly aching to tell you something, opening his beak and then shutting it once you looked. You decided to ask him about it, as he clearly wasn’t wanting to talk about it just yet.

“Hey, is there something you’re trying to show me? I can tell you really want to, I won’t judge.” You asked him, noting him jump a little once you brought up the subject at hand. He turned around, looking at the floor and blushing, “I-I’ve been... practicing... flying...” he said, getting barely audible. “No, Blit, that’s amazing! Sure, the amulets were a setback, but I’m so happy to see you’re trying to get stronger. How much of an improvement is there?” You said to him as he tucked his wings in, embarrassed. “I’m better...” he said, clearly wanting to change the subject. “I tell ya what. Tonight, let’s see if you can fly me up into a tree. Not that far, maybe just 6 or 7 feet up high. I can show you an amazing spot to see the stars!” He perked up as soon as you said stars, and said with poorly masked excitement, “Sure.”

The day came and went, and the two of you talked about your times together. Mostly just banter, but it was nice to relax and talk with each other on a personal level. As the sun went down, you followed Blit to a tree. “I really hope I can do it,” he nervously added, to himself more than you. “You’re amazing Blit, you can do this,” pulling him in and nuzzling him the same way he did so long ago. “Hold on tight, it’ll happen pretty fast.” He started flapping, and slowly moved off the ground, getting faster. He was focused on staying in the air and keeping you safe, so you had to step in when he was near the top of the tree. “Blit, we’re 30 feet off the ground.” you choked out, terrified as you looked down. “I guess we are.” He said, seemingly not tired. He slowly flew the 2 of you down, touching down way better than the previous flight.

“I delivered on flying, show me the stars.” He said, with overflowing excitement. “It’ll be a bit of a walk, nothing too bad though. Probably 15 minutes.” You told him, as he took off the moment you pointed in the direction you were headed.

“Blit... don’t ever... do that again.” You panted. He completely left you behind. Jerk. “Hey, I’m sorry!”

An hour or so later, you’d gone through all the stars you knew. This was the first time you’d really seen Blit at night, and it was a crime you hadn’t seen it before. The starlight seemed to glow on the grey tips of his feathers...
Wait a minute.
Blit is 19 years old, and Krethids age at the same rate as humans. There’d be no reason for him to already be greying already, and that’s not how greying works for them anyways, it’s whole feathers that turn grey, not tips. And the way the starlight glowed on them wasn’t a reflection, it still glowed even when your hand was making a shadow over it. “Um... Blit? Why are your feathers glowing?” you asked, concerned. “What? Woah...” he said, as confused as you were. No sooner had he said that then it stopped. “What just happened?” Both of you said in unison. You walked back wordlessly, and both went to bed, the first night in a while Blit slept through the whole night. Later the next morning...
15322112112221221122.title: Restlessness.

choices: There’s a strange bottle on your right...
Something glows within the rubble...
153221121122212211221.content:
“It just doesn’t make sense. Why would the Krethids destroy something that made them stronger? There’s more to this temple that we haven’t picked up on yet...” Blit said, looking to you for advice. “Should we go back there? Those traps are all single-use.” You told him. “Eh, why not. I can fly us there now, somehow...” he said. How is he able to fly now? He couldn’t progress that much that quickly.


A few hours later, you arrived back at the temple, the locks having been resealed, but with the same passwords. You made your way back to the room, Blit pulling you up through the higher hatches, and made it to the room with the smashed amulets. “Krethids are smart. However, if we see a prize, we’ll go straight after it. We know this about ourselves. A thief would stay sneaky and get to these, because they wouldn’t be calm until they were gone. So if my theory is right...” Blit said as he dug through the rubble, “There we are!” It wasn’t an amulet, but it was a map of these woods, with very noticeable marks. “They’re all labeled different numbers, maybe we have to collect all of them to make the true amulet?” You said, knowing what you were getting yourselves into. As you said that, Blit collapsed as he tried to fly down through the hatch again. His wings may have improved, but he was pushing himself too hard, and he hadn’t allowed enough time for them to get better. Judging by the blood, he tore a tendon in one of them. Now what?
153221121122212211221.title: There’s more to that temple.

choices: A week passes.
1532211211222122112212.content:
Blit’s initial scream of pain continued and morphed into a moan as the impact was replaced by shock. His eyes looked up to you through the hatch, glazed over and still. “Oh, Blit, no, no, no, no...”

...

...

...
The pile of rubble started glowing. Or rather, something inside of it. You tore away at the rocks, trying to ignore the image of Blit’s bloody mess of a back, when you finally reach your prize. It seems to be a golden feather, but it’s hard to tell because of how bright it is. You drop down through the hatch, feather in hand, and start trying to tend to his wound. The feather has a mind of its own, as the blood is drawn out of his feathers, and the wound slowly stops bleeding. The feather turns red, then white, then gold again. You tentatively place it to the would, and watch as the wound slowly shrinks away, and the wing is set back in place. This seems to snap Blit out of his shock, now that his wing is healed again. “What is that?” He asked, somewhat dazed. “I’m not sure, once you fell the debris started glowing and I found this.” You told him, handing him the feather. “Woah... This can’t be what I think it is,” he said, “Only the strongest Krethid warriors are able to use these. Anyone else would be rejected by it. And I think it fixed my wings, for real this time.” “Alright, but I’m not letting you fly us back out of here until we know for sure they’re safe. You just proved yourself wrong when you told me they were better the first time. And I’m keeping the feather.” You said defiantly. “OK, fine...” Blit said, defeated.

choices: 'Sigh' "Okay."
"...I don't think so."
15331.content:
The story starts out one average day at an average grocery store. You had just finished shopping and walked out of the store with a paper bag full of groceries. You turn left and begin making your way down the street and towards an intersection. You're an average and optimistic type of guy. In fact the kind of guy who would continue his daily routine disregarding any kind of sudden change in plans. I guess the best way to say it is, 'if something happens, it happens'. You stop and wait patiently for the light to change. You take a deep breath, "Ahhh... And to think I only came to the grocery store for a loaf of bread. Hah!"

A couple seconds later, the light changes, and you make your way across the street without any harm. You continue your way down a couple more blocks, and then head straight into a long alleyway. It's a bit odd, but it's the way you always go in order to get home, which is located in a forest just behind the other end of the alleyway. Upon entering the alleyway, you come to a stop once you overhear some low yelling. "Huh?"

You listen some more, the yelling starting to get a little louder the longer he listened. "Uh-oh. Sounds like a group of people are mad at someone. Or something! Probably someone's antenna making things blurry on someone's TV screen.

"GET BACK HERE!"

"!" You look straight up to your left at a window on the second story of a two-story building. You stare intently at the window for a moment longer, and then 'Crash!' An unknown figure jumps out through the glass. You quickly turn around and lean your upper body in so you wouldn't get glass in your eyes or face. The figure then falls towards the ground beside you with a loud 'Thud!' "Ah! Huh?" You take a closer look at the unknown figure.

"Say, it's one o' dem furry beings. Or in this case, feathery characters." The figure was a male blue-feathered hawk with a humanoid body. It didn't have any wings and wore a white T-shirt, blue jeans, and white tennis shoes. "Wow! I knew those from The Other Side were peaceful, I didn't know they dressed like us too!" You stare at the poor thing for a while, noticing how hurt and bruised up he was. You sighed, "I can't just leave this poor thing here in its condition."

You set your bag of groceries down. The avian slowly begins to open its eyes, but only enough to see his shadow being picked up by yours. The avian thinks to himself as you start running off home, "Wha...? I'm being helped...? And by...a human? ...... Mm..."

The avian passes out once again on your shoulders, but you don't notice. "Six months of working out in my home gym, don't fail me now!"

Unbeknownst to you, another unknown figure pokes his head from the part of the alley you entered through to see you run off with the injured avian being carried on your shoulders. The figure looked like a masculine anthro, with raccoon ears and a raccoon tail. He holds right arm up to his mouth to speak to a type of wristwatch walkie-talkie, "Guys, looks like some human picked up our feathered pal. He doesn't look like any one of those men in labcoats. Should I chase after him?"

A male voice speaks through the raccoon's watch, "Not one of those lab-coated jerks? Well, yeah, stay on his trail. But DON'T try to stop the human unless he harms our friend."

"Alright." Suddenly, the raccoon overhears a couple police sirens coming his way. "Crap! Better get outta here at least." The raccoon uses his claws and climbs up the building to the roof and sprints off in your direction.

Within an hour, you were now walking up a fairly steep mountain towards a log cabin that lay ahead. You feel the hawk's body starting to weigh down on yours as you begin panting under your breath. In a matter of minutes, you finally make your way up the porch and up to the front door. You kick the door open with your left foot. Upon entering your home, you turn on the light to your living room and lay the poor thing on its back on the green couch. You sit on a small green sofa beside your couch and set your bag of groceries on a small table. You reach into the bag with your left hand, "Ow!" You pull out something from the bag, "Darn it! There's broken glass on my cabbage."

You look at the winged figure with injuries all over, and then let the cabbage fall to the ground. "Mm... I guess that's not really important right now, huh?" You reach into your grocery bag and took out a 500-piece first-aid kit, which you placed on your small table. "Good thing I was planning to go hiking tomorrow."

You are now on your knees in front of the injured hawk. You scan his entire body, noticing a couple scraps and cuts all over his body, along with a few pieces of broken glass. His left arm looked like it was the most injured, looking as if it was popped out of place. "Mm... Maybe I should pull these pieces of broken glass out first."

The one you reach for is jabbed in the avian's hind wrist. You slowly grab a firm hold of the end that stuck out with your index finger and thumb, and then with a quick flick of the wrist, you pull it right out. This causes the avian to flinch as he opens his eyes wide, "!!" With great agility, the hawk jumps right out from the couch and lands on his feet a few feet away. He was panting heavily as he grabbed ahold of his left arm. "Don't you touch ME!"

You stand up, "Hey, he can talk! What am I saying? I already knew that."

"Who the hell are you!?" The avian grips his injured arm a little harder, "Urrrgh!"

You take a step closer to him, "Hey, easy pal! You're arm's not well."

The hawk looks at his arm, and then glares back at you. "!" He notices the first-aid kit that's sitting on the table, and then looks back at you. "...You're...helping me?"

"Well, yeah. Why wouldn't I be?"

The hawk lowers his injured arm a little, "It's just...I never thought I'd get assistance from a human before."

"Buddy, to me, this isn't about a human helping an anthro. You were hurt, so I felt I should help you out." The avian stares at you, still filled with doubt in his expression. "Look, whether or not you trust me, I want to help you."

"......"

You stare at him blankly. "So!? Do you trust me or not!?" The avian glares back at you, and then you bow your head down. "Sorry."
15331.title: Avian in Trouble

choices: “I can't stay here. I have to leave soon.”
“You mean... You're okay with me staying here?”
153311.content:
You hear the avian give a small sigh before turning your head back up, a little curious. He seemed to shake his head to himself, but spoke out quietly. “Okay. Sure beats sitting here with glass all over.”

“You're lucky enough you only got some glass in your arm. If it went in any other place, or it went much deeper than the surface, and you'd need a hospital. I'll try to be thorough, but not a surgeon, r'member.” You just nod at the couch, the bird slowly walking back towards it. You brush off his seat before he sits back down, his arm hanging loosely in front of him. “Lucky for you, I can't see any cuts on your clothes. Don't know how you avoided glass in your body... I wouldn't be able t'do squat about that.”

The bird nods a little bit as you reach forward again, picking up his arm and getting back to work on it. He gave a sharp sound each time you get another shard out. You're quick and precise as you pull, but some of the glass has pierced him deeper than you expected. Disinfecting and wrapping the wounds also took a bit of time, and though he said you could take care of him, he certain didn't want to sit still. The noises distract you a bit as you work, but you're quick and steady with your job.

“There... I think that should be all of the glass.” You carefully look over, making sure to disinfect any other scratches you can find before you finish banding up his arm. “You're still pretty banged up, though.” You drop the last shard you could find onto the table. “You're probably a bit more injured than just that.”

“I'll take care of it myself. Mind if I borrow the kit?” You see him tugging his shirt off, wincing a little as he moves.

“Sure. You need a hand, or something?” He pauses as he looks at you again, as if gauging you somehow. However, he gives his head a small shake. You just stand up and shrug. “If you think so. Shout if ya need help.” You stand up and get a dustpan to try to clean up the shards of glass littered on the table. The hawk sits a little awkwardly as he starts to try to work on himself. It only takes a minute before you've cleaned up the mess, carefully sweeping up all of the glass you could find before carrying it to your kitchen.“Just glad that you're feeling alright. Second story fall through a glass window... Surprised you didn't break anything.”

“I'm... resilient.” He hesitates as he speaks out, probably trying not to make too much noise. You don't see very much as you dump all of the glass into the garbage. You head back for your groceries, noticing the hawk stop when he sees you approaching. He seems to relax a little when he sees you taking the groceries to the kitchen, and you can hear him moving again when you arrive. You start to pull out your things, hoping to figure out which items were still safe to work with. You slowly pull a few packages of food, as well as a bit of the fresher fruits and vegetables. It looked as though almost everything that wasn't in a separate container had gotten glass on it in several places, but most of the packaged foods and tools were still in one piece. You just try to put what you can into your pantry, wondering if you should bother trying to remove the glass or if it would be worth to visit the store again.

Slight grunts of pain come from the other room, confirming that the avian is still there, and apparently still tending to his wounds. It sounds like he was trying to keep quiet, but he must've had a lot more injuries than just what you saw. “What exactly happened to you, anyways? Looked like you were trying to jump through that window. Why'd you need to do that?”

“I was... in a tight spot,” He responds evasively. “It wasn't the stupidest thing I've ever done, but... Thanks for taking me...” He pauses, glancing around the room a few times. He spots the window in the room, squinting his eyes a bit to try to look through it. “Where are we, anyways?”

“My place. A bit deep in the forest near town. Afraid it's the only place I could take you. Not so familiar with the streets.” You leave the glass-ridden groceries alone for now, just walking back to the living room. You could see the bird standing by the window, a number of healed cuts and the remnants of bruises scattered over his body. His eyes seem to widen a little as he turns his head, one of his hands still applying a few new bandages to himself.

“You carried me into the forest? That's... not exactly a short distance...”

“Hey, I make the trip all the time. Bit of a run's not gonna stop me.” You smile at him as you approach. He's a little on edge, but you just stop nearby, looking out the window with him. “More surprised at you. Thought that a bird would be lighter than you are.”

He looks down at his feet a little awkwardly, stepping back as he just sat back onto the couch. “Mmm.” He seemed a little lost in thought as his eyes turned away. You turned to look at him, just shrugging your shoulders. “So, do you know what you're going to do after you recover.”

It takes him a moment before he turns his head a little, looking at you curiously. “A-after?” He swallows quietly, his eyes looking right at you for a few moment. He shakes his head a little more violently than you expect, before speaking again.
153311.title: Patching Up

choices: "So, you wanted to ask more questions?"
"Say, I'm starving."
1533112.content:
You take a drink of some water from a water bottle you were holding. "Of course! I certainly wouldn't wanna let you leave in your current condition.", you say with a smile.

"Uh..." The avian lowers his head and the looks back up at you, "...thanks, I guess."

"Sure! No problem!", you say proudly. There was a pause for a moment, and then you break the ice. "SO, you said you were in a 'tight spot'. So were you like, stuck in the corner of the room and not able to get out or..."

"No..." The hawk looks up at you, "Wait, what?"

You shrug your shoulders, "Sorry I'm, I'm drawing a blank here."

The hawk sighs at you. "Look, I...I don't really feel comfortable talking about that right now."

"Oh. I understand. ... But hey, let's change the subject then! Why don't we spend this time to ask questions and get to know each other better.", you say with slight anticipation.

The avian glances at you. "... Sorry. You may be providing a place for me to stay and got me out of trouble, but I'm not comfortable enough to be talking about my personal life to you."

"Exactly! I want you to be comfortable with me and where you are. You can ask me anything! And I'm not gonna force information out of you. If there's anything I ask, you don't have to answer it.", you say happily.

The hawk looked away towards the ground, still skeptical of the idea. "Mm..."

"Here, why don't you ask me some questions first." You fold your arms, "Go ahead. Ask me anything."

"Um...okay." The hawk looks away, and then looks back at you while squinting his eyes. "Do you have any affiliation with the police, FBI, or CIA?"

"Nope!", you say with a smile. "Well, I have thought about it at one point in my life, but, it didn't really stick out to me." You grin, "Anything else?"

"..." The avian sighs once again. He looks out the window towards the city, which was sitting a few miles away from where they were. The avian turns his head towards you, "Why're you living all the way out here?"

"Provides a great view of the sky, mountains, and the city. Well, I guess mainly at night. Plus there's not too much pitter-pattering and city noise out here." You take another sip of your water.

"Is it just you? I mean, how was this place built up here?", the hawk asks.

This place was mainly my father's idea. I helped built this place from the ground up three years ago." You sigh. "We sure used to spend a lot of time out here."

The hawk grew a bit concerned. "'Used to'? Where is he now?"

You sigh. "He, got arrested two years ago after participating in a rally that was about bringing humans and anthros together. After he was put through trial..." You lower your head a bit. "All I can say is, I won't be seeing him again."

The hawk's expression grew a bit saddened. "Oh... I'm, sorry to hear that."

"Yeah. I still receive calls from him every now and then.", your expression brightening some.

"I see..." The hawk notices something, and looks up at you. "Wha-, wait, how can you receive calls from him if he's dead?"

You look at him with an eyebrow raised, "Huh? Oh no! He wasn't put to death. He was exiled."

The hawk felt a bit awkward. "Oh. ... And you have mom too?"

"Duh! Otherwise I wouldn't be alive helping people like you from falling out of two-story windows." You chuckle.

The hawk squints his eyes at you, "Mmm..."

"I-hi'm sorry. You may need to get used to my personality. But on a serious note, my mom couldn't bare to be away from my dad so long, I said it was okay if she wanted to go with him. And she did.", you explain.

The hawk grew a bit concerned again, "And, you're okay with staying alone up here all by yourself?"

You shift the bottle of water in your had around a few times, "It's got its downsides. But I've got a working job and unlimited long distance talk, so it's not all bad. Plus I'm enjoying the company."

"..." The avian looks away and then blinks looking back at you. "So, am I really here just because you wanted some company?"

You stare blankly at your water bottle for a moment, and then shrug your shoulders, "Well I, um...well... Okay, yes. The moment I saw you were hurt on the ground, I thought of it as being the perfect moment to bring someone home with me to take care of and to enjoy their company.", so say with a smile.

The hawk is staring blankly at you. You still had the same expression on your face. The hawk is still staring blankly at you. Still, you had the same expression on your face. The hawk felt weird, but then gets you, "...That's just your personality talking, isn't it."

You chuckle. "See? Now you're starting to get used to me."

The hawk grins, "Heheh. I guess I am."

You raise an eyebrow, "Whoa. Did you just giggle?"

"Huh!?" The hawk pouts a bit as he looks away. "Y-yeah. So? ......" The hawk looks at you, not trying to look silly, "Okay, you said you wanted to ask me a few questions. Well, what do you want to know?"

You look up at the roof, "Wow... Where do I even begin? ..." You place a hand upon your cheek, "Oh yeah! Your name! In fact, I haven't gotten to properly introduce myself either." You hold out your right hand, "My name's Allen. It's really a pleasure to meet you." There was a fairly long pause, for the hawk was a couple feet away from where you were holding out your hand. "...... Okay, I guess it's fine if you just tell me your name right off the bat--!"

You look down at your hand to feel a soft, feathery palm grabbing ahold of your hand. You look up to see the avian standing right in front of you. "The name's Morgan. I guess I should thank you at least for helping me out and letting me stay. Heh.", Morgan grins warmingly as he tilted his head off to the side a bit.

Your cheeks start to turn a bit red by the feel of Morgan's soft palm shaking with yours. You also notice Morgan is actually a foot taller then you, and you're 5'6. But then you shake your head to shake it off. "Uh, yeah. Sure thing.", you say with a warm smile. It was strange. You and Morgan were just staring at each other, and for some reason, you just couldn't stop.

Morgan speaks up to break the moment,..
